entry.title: æ•°æ®æŒ–æ˜ 5 Outlier Detection
entry.content:
Outlier detection as the task of finding anomalous points in data.

Brief Introduction

Outlier: definition depends on the application. â€œAn object that deviates so much from the rest of the data as to arouse suspicion that it was generated by a different mechanism.â€

Noise VS outliers: Noise is a measuring error. Outlier is a point that belongs to the same distribution.

Different types of outliers:

  • Global outliers: Point that significantly deviate from the data set.
  • Contextual outliers: Points deviate from a subset of points. Context is defined as fixed values in some dimensions.
  • Collective outliers: A set of points might represent an outlier w.r.t. the rest of the points. In this case, a single point might not be an outlier, though such is the whole set.

Methods for outlier detection: supervised and unsupervised.

  • Supervised outlier detection requires labels.
  • Unsupervised outlier detected. âœ… We are interested in this one.

This lecture:

  • Low-dimensional
    • model-based
    • depth-based
    • distance-based
  • high-dimensional
    • angle-based
    • local outliers
    • clustering-based
    • isolation forests

Low-dimensional Outlier Detection

Model-based Methods

It assumes that the data is a sample from a known distribution P(X)P(X)P(X). After fitting the parameters Î¸\thetaÎ¸ of the distribution, return the points having low probability P(x)P(\mathbb x)P(x), i.e., points that are unlikely to be generated by the distribution P(X)P(X)P(X).

The simplest model-based method: assuming data D\mathcal DD belongs to a normal distribution

Dâˆ¼f(xâˆ£Î¼,Î£)=1(2Ï€)dâˆ£Î£âˆ£expâ¡(âˆ’12(xâˆ’Î¼)TÎ£âˆ’1(xâˆ’Î¼))\mathcal D\sim f(\mathbb x|\mu,\Sigma)={1\over\sqrt{(2\pi)^d|\Sigma|}}\exp(-{1\over2}(x-\mu)^T\Sigma^{-1}(x-\mu))Dâˆ¼f(xâˆ£Î¼,Î£)=(2Ï€)dâˆ£Î£âˆ£â€‹1â€‹exp(âˆ’21â€‹(xâˆ’Î¼)TÎ£âˆ’1(xâˆ’Î¼))

A rule of thumb: 3Ïƒ3\sigma3Ïƒ

The Grubbsâ€™ Test provides a statistical confidence whether the point is generated by the same normal distribution. But only with uni-variate å•å˜é‡ data. The testâ€™s null hypothesis H0H_0H0â€‹ is the absence of outliers in the data. Test works as follows:

  1. Compute the Grubbsâ€™ test statistics G=maxâ¡xâˆˆDâˆ£xâˆ’Î¼âˆ£ÏƒG={\max_{\mathbb x\in\mathcal D}|\mathbb x-\mu|\over\sigma}G=ÏƒmaxxâˆˆDâ€‹âˆ£xâˆ’Î¼âˆ£â€‹

  2. Reject the null hypothesis H0H_0H0â€‹ if

    G>nâˆ’1nG\gt\frac{n-1}{\sqrt n}G>nâ€‹nâˆ’1â€‹tÎ±/nâˆ’22nâˆ’1+tÎ±/nâˆ’22\sqrt\frac{t^2_{\alpha/n-2}}{n-1+t^2_{\alpha/n-2}}nâˆ’1+tÎ±/nâˆ’22â€‹tÎ±/nâˆ’22â€‹â€‹â€‹

    where ttt is the ttt-student distribution.

Other model-based approaches generalize to arbitrary distributions, such as Gaussian mixtures. We fit the model parameters using methods such as Expectation Maximization algorithmâ€¦

Pros and Cons

ğŸ‘

  • Strong statistical foundation
  • Output labels for outliers and non-outliers but can also output a score of outlierdness
  • Efficient to compute and easy to interpret

ğŸ‘

  • Often work only in the 1-dimensional case
  • Require fixing a model for the data distribution
  • The Gaussian distribution is affected by the dimensionality

Depth-based Approaches

It search for outliers that stands at the border of the data. One such approach is to run the convex hull algorithm to enclose the points inside a shape. The implicit assumption is that outliers are always located at the border of the data space, while the normal points are inside a convex shape.

The algorithm alternates the convex hull algorithm to the removal of the points at the border. The points are marked with the number of iteration in which they have been removed. The number represents the depth of the point.

Finally, the algorithm marks as outliers all the points at the border. The points are marked with number of iteration in which they are removed. The number represents the depth of the point.

Finally the algorithm marks as outliers all the points having a depth â‰¥t\ge tâ‰¥t.

Although simple, depth-based approaches have severe limitations:

  1. The data is assumed to lie on a convex shape. Not the case for multi-modal distributions in which the data contains many clusters.
  2. Convex hull computation is only efficient on low-dimensional data.

For these reasons, depth-based can only be used in specific settings.

Pros and Cons

ğŸ‘

  • Uses a global reference set for outlier detection
  • Originally outputs a label, but can be extended for scoring easily, take depth as a scoring value for example.

ğŸ‘

  • The data must be uni-modal.
  • Convex hull computation is usually only efficient in 2D and 3D spaces.

Distance-based Methods

A direct formalization of the outlier notion by Hawkins.

A point p\mathbb pp is an outlier if most points are further than Ïµ\epsilonÏµ from p\mathbb pp.

Definition: Given a radius Ïµ\epsilonÏµ and a percentage Ï€\piÏ€, a point p\mathbb pp is an outlier if at most Ï€\piÏ€ percent of the points xâˆˆD\mathbb x\in\mathcal DxâˆˆD are at distance less than Ïµ\epsilonÏµ from p\mathbb pp.

The set of outliers OD\mathcal O_\mathcal DODâ€‹:

OD={pÂ s.t.Â âˆ£{xâˆˆDâˆ£dist(p,x)<Ïµ}âˆ£âˆ£Dâˆ£â‰¤Ï€}\mathcal O_\mathcal D=\{\mathbb p\text{ s.t. }{|\{\mathbb x\in\mathcal D|dist(\mathbb p,\mathbb x)\lt\epsilon\}|\over|\mathcal D|}\le\pi\}ODâ€‹={pÂ s.t.Â âˆ£Dâˆ£âˆ£{xâˆˆDâˆ£dist(p,x)<Ïµ}âˆ£â€‹â‰¤Ï€}

Convient notion of outlier score, easy to implement.

However, Ïµ,Ï€\epsilon,\piÏµ,Ï€ are globally defined, distance-based outliers can not detect outliers with different densities.

Pros and Cons

ğŸ‘

  • Easy to implement
  • Highly interpret-able

ğŸ‘

  • Effectiveness depends on the choice of distance measure distdistdist
  • Cannot detect collective outliers
  • Sensitive to the choice of Ïµ,Ï€\epsilon,\piÏµ,Ï€
  • Sensitive to data density

High-dimensional Outlier Detection

Suffers from the curse of dimensionality. In this case outliers hides within inliers and make analyses harder.

Angel-based Outlier Detection

abbr. ABOD

Curse of dimensionality doesnâ€™t affect angles as much as distances. Because the relative positions of the points do not change in higher dimension.

Idea: The angle formed with any pair of other points is typically small in variance.

è¿™ä¸ªè§‚ç‚¹å¾ˆæœ‰è¶£ï¼Œä¸€ä¸ªå¼‚å¸¸å€¼ç›¸å¯¹äºå…¶ä»–ç‚¹æœ‰åç¦»ï¼Œæ‰€ä»¥è¿™ä¸ªå¼‚å¸¸å€¼å’Œå…¶ä»–ç‚¹è¿çº¿çš„æ–¹å‘éƒ½åº”è¯¥å·®åˆ«ä¸å¤ªå¤§ã€‚ï¼ˆå¼‚å¸¸å€¼ç¦»èšç±»è¶Šè¿œï¼Œè¿çº¿çš„å¤¹è§’è¶Šæ¥è¿‘ã€‚ï¼‰

ABOD works as follows:

  • Consider the angles formed by a point p\mathbb pp with any point x,yâˆˆD\mathbb x,\mathbb y\in\mathcal Dx,yâˆˆD
  • Plot the angles in a chart
  • The variance of the angles represents an indication on whether a point is an outlier or an inlier.

ABOD measures the variance of angles, weighted by the corresponding distances by

ABOD(p)=VARx,yâˆˆD(âŸ¨xâˆ’p,yâˆ’pâŸ©âˆ£âˆ£xâˆ’pâˆ£âˆ£2â‹…âˆ£âˆ£yâˆ’pâˆ£âˆ£2).ABOD(\mathbb p)=VAR_{\mathbb x,\mathbb y\in\mathcal D}\left({\langle\mathbb x-\mathbb p,\mathbb y-\mathbb p\rangle}\over||\mathbb x-\mathbb p||^2\cdot||\mathbb y-\mathbb p||^2\right).ABOD(p)=VARx,yâˆˆDâ€‹(âˆ£âˆ£xâˆ’pâˆ£âˆ£2â‹…âˆ£âˆ£yâˆ’pâˆ£âˆ£2âŸ¨xâˆ’p,yâˆ’pâŸ©â€‹).

A point with a small ABOD denotes an outlier/ The naive computation of ABOD takes O(n3)\mathcal O(n^3)O(n3) due to the number of pairs for each point.

One possible solution is to consider only a subset of pairs, to get a good approximation to exact ABOD.

Pros and Cons

ğŸ‘

  • Global approach to outlier detection
  • Performs well on high-dimensional data

ğŸ‘

  • The naive algorithm runs in O(n3)\mathcal O(n^3)O(n3)
  • Cannot detect collective outliers

Local Methods

A point is a outlier if local density is larger than that of its own neighbors.

Local outliers are defined in terms of nearest neighbors and require only to specify the parameter to define how many neighbor points to consider.

One of local outlier methods is the Local Outlier Factor.

The KNN distance is the distance distk(p)dist_k(\mathbb p)distkâ€‹(p) between a point p\mathbb pp and its k-nearest neighbor.

Reachability distance sets a lower bound between the KNN distance and the distance of a point x\mathbb xx from a point p\mathbb pp

rdistk(p,x)=maxâ¡{distk(x),dist(p,x)}rdist_k(\mathbb p,\mathbb x)=\max\{dist_k(\mathbb x),dist(\mathbb p,\mathbb x)\}rdistkâ€‹(p,x)=max{distkâ€‹(x),dist(p,x)}

The local reachability distance (lrd) of a point p\mathbb pp is the average inverse reachability distance of a point p\mathbb pp from its KNN. The higher the lrd(p)lrd(\mathbb p)lrd(p), the closer p\mathbb pp is to its k-nearest points.

lrdk(p)=1âˆ£Nk(p)âˆ£1âˆ‘xâˆˆNk(p)rdistk(p,x)lrd_k(\mathbb p)={1\over|N_k(\mathbb p)|}{1\over\sum_{x\in N_k(\mathbb p)}rdist_k(\mathbb p,\mathbb x)}lrdkâ€‹(p)=âˆ£Nkâ€‹(p)âˆ£1â€‹âˆ‘xâˆˆNkâ€‹(p)â€‹rdistkâ€‹(p,x)1â€‹

Finally the Local Outlier Factor (LOF) is the average ratio of the local reachability distances of the neighbors of p\mathbb pp and that of p\mathbb pp. The local outlier factor measures the relative density of the neighbors of a point and point it self.

LOFk(p)=1âˆ£Nk(p)âˆ£âˆ‘xâˆˆNk(p)lrdk(x)lrdk(p)LOF_k(\mathbb p)={1\over|N_k(\mathbb p)|}\sum_{\mathbb x\in N_k(\mathbb p)}{lrd_k(\mathbb x)\over lrd_k(\mathbb p)}LOFkâ€‹(p)=âˆ£Nkâ€‹(p)âˆ£1â€‹xâˆˆNkâ€‹(p)âˆ‘â€‹lrdkâ€‹(p)lrdkâ€‹(x)â€‹

If the density of points around p\mathbb pp is less than the density around its neighbors, the LOF will be large.

LOF solves curse of dimensionality. However, LOF struggles in regions with low-density.

Pros and Cons

ğŸ‘

  • Provides a scores of outlierdness
  • Easy interpret-ability
  • Not affected by the curse of dimensionality

ğŸ‘

  • Inefficient due to the computation of the neighbors
  • Requires the correct setting of the parameter kkk
  • Hard to detect outliers in low-density regions

Clustering-based Methods

e.g. in DBSCAN, every object not contained in a cluster must be an outlier.

FindCBLOF. In order to find outliers using clustering techniques we can use a general method called FindCBLOF.

  • Compute clusters using a clustering algorithm
  • Sort the clusters in decreasing order by number of points
  • Assign to each point a cluster-based local outlier factor (CBLOF)
    • If point p\mathbb pp belongs to a large cluster CiC_iCiâ€‹, then CBLOF(p)=âˆ£Ciâˆ£â‹…SCBLOF(\mathbb p)=|C_i|\cdot SCBLOF(p)=âˆ£Ciâ€‹âˆ£â‹…S, where SSS is similarity between p\mathbb pp and the cluster.
    • If p\mathbb pp belongs to a small cluster, then CBLOF(p)=âˆ£Ciâˆ£â‹…SCBLOF(\mathbb p)=|C_i|\cdot SCBLOF(p)=âˆ£Ciâ€‹âˆ£â‹…S, where SSS is the similarity between p\mathbb pp and the closest large cluster.

Pros and Cons

ğŸ‘

  • Detect outliers without requiring labeled data
  • Works on several types of data
  • Clusters can be regarded as summaries of data

ğŸ‘

  • The effectiveness depends on the chosen clustering method
  • High computational cost to compute the clusters

Isolation Forest

abbr. IF is a method to detect outliers based on the notion of separability.

p\mathbb pp is separable if it is easy to find a random hyper-plane that separates the point from the rest. Idea is similar to a decision tree.

The probability of a point p\mathbb pp to be separated from the others in a random split of the data is higher if the point is an outlier. This means that such point with high probability, a leaf close to the root of a randomly-built decision tree.

However, the point p\mathbb pp can also be separated by chance. As such, the algorithm builds a number of trees (forest) and calculates the expected height E(h(p))\mathbb E(h(\mathbb p))E(h(p)) of the root-leaf path and uses such expectation to compute an outlier score

s(p)=2âˆ’E(h(p))/c(n)s(\mathbb p)=2^{-\mathbb E(h(\mathbb p))/c(n)}s(p)=2âˆ’E(h(p))/c(n)

where c(n)c(n)c(n) is the expected path length of a balanced binary search tree with nnn data points used for normalization. An outlier has a score close to 1, i.e. the expected length of the path from the root to the leaf h(p)â‰ˆ0h(\mathbb p)\approx0h(p)â‰ˆ0.

Pros and Cons

ğŸ‘

  • Easy to construct avoiding difficult decisions on if data points are anomalies or not.
  • Can achieve sublinear time complexity and a small memory footprint by exploiting sub-sampling. By eliminating major computational cost of distance calculation in all the distance and density based AD methods
  • Can provide anomaly explanations

ğŸ‘

  • Hyperparameter tuning required such as number of trees, sample size and heights of trees.
  • Requires a high percentage of relevant features to identity anomalies.
entry.summary: Outlier detection as the task of finding anomalous points in data.

entry.title: éšæœºç®—æ³• 5 Streaming Algorithms for Frequency Estimation
entry.content:
Lecture notes adopted from UCB CS270

Streaming Algorithms: Frequent Items

Streaming setting: Data stream x1,x2,â‹¯â€‰,xnx_1,x_2,\cdots,x_nx1â€‹,x2â€‹,â‹¯,xnâ€‹ with xiâˆˆ[m]x_i\in[m]xiâ€‹âˆˆ[m]. The available memory is O(logâ¡cn)O(\log^cn)O(logcn). Sub-linear space.

Algorithm: Approximates frequencies for the top kkk items.

Deterministic Algorithm

To estimate item frequencies fjf_jfjâ€‹ within an additive error of n/kn/kn/k using with O(klogâ¡n)O(k\log n)O(klogn) memory. ï¼ˆlogâ¡n\log nlogn è¿™é‡ŒæŒ‡çš„æ˜¯å†…å­˜çš„æ¯”ç‰¹æ•°é‡ã€‚ï¼‰

  • Maintain set SSS of kkk counters, initialize to 000. For each element xix_ixiâ€‹ in stream
    • If xiâˆˆSx_i\in Sxiâ€‹âˆˆS, increment the counter of xix_ixiâ€‹.
    • If xiâˆˆÌ¸Sx_i\not\in Sxiâ€‹î€ âˆˆS, add xix_ixiâ€‹ to SSS is space is available, else decrement all counters in SSS.

An item in SSS whose count falls to 000 can be removed, the space requirement for storing kkk counters is klogâ¡nk\log nklogn and the update time per item is O(k)O(k)O(k). The algorithm estimates the count of an item as the value of its counter or zero if it has no counter.

ğŸ¤”Claim 1: The frequency estimate njn_jnjâ€‹ produced by the algorithm satisfies fjâˆ’n/kâ‰¤njâ‰¤fjf_j-n/k\le n_j\le f_jfjâ€‹âˆ’n/kâ‰¤njâ€‹â‰¤fjâ€‹.

Clearly, njn_jnjâ€‹ is less than the true frequency fjf_jfjâ€‹. Differences between fjf_jfjâ€‹ and the value of the estimate are caused by one of the two scenarios:

  1. The item jâˆˆÌ¸Sj\not\in Sjî€ âˆˆS, each counter in SSS gets decremented, this is the case when xjx_jxjâ€‹ occurs in the stream but the counter for jjj is not incremented.
  2. The counter for jjj gets decremented due to an element jâ€²j'jâ€² that is not contained in SSS.

Both scenarios result in kkk counters getting decremented hence they can occur at most n/kn/kn/k times, showing that njâ‰¥fjâˆ’n/kn_j\ge f_j-n/knjâ€‹â‰¥fjâ€‹âˆ’n/k.

åœ¨æ‰€æœ‰è®¡æ•°å™¨å‡å°‘å‰ï¼Œè‡³å°‘è¦æ·»åŠ  kkk æ¬¡ã€‚å¯¹äºæ‰€æœ‰è®¡æ•°å™¨çš„å’Œï¼Œæ¯æ¬¡å‡å°‘æ“ä½œéƒ½ä¼šå‡å°‘ kkkã€‚æ‰€æœ‰è®¡æ•°å™¨çš„å’Œæœ€å¤šå‡å°‘ n/kn/kn/k æ¬¡ã€‚æ‰€ä»¥å•ä¸ªè®¡æ•°å™¨ä¹Ÿæœ€å¤šå‡å°‘ n/kn/kn/k æ¬¡ã€‚

ä¹Ÿå°±æ˜¯å½“æ‰€æœ‰ item å‡ºç°çš„é¢‘ç‡éƒ½ä¸€æ ·ï¼ˆéƒ½æ˜¯ n/kn/kn/kï¼‰çš„æ—¶å€™ï¼Œå–ç­‰å·ã€‚

Count Min Sketch

The turnstile model (æ—‹è½¬é—¨æ¨¡å‹) allows both additions and deletions of items in the stream.

The stream consists of pairs (i,ci)(i,c_i)(i,ciâ€‹), where the iâˆˆ[m]i\in[m]iâˆˆ[m] is an item and cic_iciâ€‹ is the number of items to be added or deleted. The count of an item can not be negative at any stage, the frequency fjf_jfjâ€‹ of item jjj is fj=âˆ‘cjf_j=\sum c_jfjâ€‹=âˆ‘cjâ€‹.

The following algorithm estimates frequencies of all items up to an additive error of Ïµâˆ£fâˆ£1\epsilon|f|_1Ïµâˆ£fâˆ£1â€‹ with probability 1âˆ’Î´1-\delta1âˆ’Î´, the â„“1\ell_1â„“1â€‹ norm âˆ£fâˆ£1|f|_1âˆ£fâˆ£1â€‹ is the number of items present in the data set. The two parameters kkk and ttt in the algorithm are chosen to be 2Ïµ,logâ¡(1/Î´){2\over\epsilon},\log(1/\delta)Ïµ2â€‹,log(1/Î´).

Space usage: O(1Ïµlogâ¡n)O({1\over\epsilon}\log n)O(Ïµ1â€‹logn)

The algorithm works as follows:

  1. Maintain ttt arrays A[i]A[i]A[i] each having kkk counters, hash function hi:Uâ†’[k]h_i:U\rarr[k]hiâ€‹:Uâ†’[k] drawn from a 222-wise independent family H\mathcal HH is associated to array A[i]A[i]A[i].

  2. For element (j,cj)(j,c_j)(j,cjâ€‹) in the stream, update counters as follows:

    A[i,hi(j)]â†A[i,hi(j)]+cjâˆ€iâˆˆ[t]A[i,h_i(j)]\gets A[i,h_i(j)]+c_j\forall i\in[t]A[i,hiâ€‹(j)]â†A[i,hiâ€‹(j)]+cjâ€‹âˆ€iâˆˆ[t]

  3. The frequency estimate for item jjj is minâ¡iâˆˆ[t]A[i,h(j)]\min_{i\in[t]}A[i,h(j)]miniâˆˆ[t]â€‹A[i,h(j)].

The output estimate is always more than the true value of fjf_jfjâ€‹ as the count of all the items in the stream is non-negative.

Analysis

To bound the error in the estimate for fjf_jfjâ€‹ we need to analyze the excess XXX where A[1,h1(j)]=fj+XA[1,h_1(j)]=f_j+XA[1,h1â€‹(j)]=fjâ€‹+X. The excess XXX an be a sum of random variables X=âˆ‘iYiX=\sum_iY_iX=âˆ‘iâ€‹Yiâ€‹ where Yi=fiY_i=f_iYiâ€‹=fiâ€‹ if h1(j)=h1(i)h_1(j)=h_1(i)h1â€‹(j)=h1â€‹(i) and 000 otherwise. As h1âˆˆHh_1\in\mathcal Hh1â€‹âˆˆH is chosen uniformly at random from a pair-wise independent hash function family, E[Yi]=fi/k\mathbb E[Y_i]=f_i/kE[Yiâ€‹]=fiâ€‹/k.

E[X]=âˆ£fâˆ£1k=Ïµâˆ£fâˆ£12.\mathbb E[X]={|f|_1\over k}={\epsilon|f|_1\over2}.E[X]=kâˆ£fâˆ£1â€‹â€‹=2Ïµâˆ£fâˆ£1â€‹â€‹.

E[X]=Eh[âˆ‘jâ‰ i,h(i)=h(j)fj]=Eh[âˆ‘jâˆ£jâ‰ ifjâ‹…1h(i)=h(j)]=âˆ‘jâˆ£jâ‰ iE[1h(i)=h(j)]â‹…fj=âˆ‘jâˆ£jâ‰ iPrâ¡[h(i)=h(j)]â‹…fj=âˆ‘jâˆ£jâ‰ ifjkâ‰¤âˆ‘jfjk=âˆ£fâˆ£1k\mathbb E[X]=\mathbb E_h[\sum_{j\neq i,h(i)=h(j)}f_j]=\mathbb E_h[\sum_{j|j\neq i}f_j\cdot\mathbf 1_{h(i)=h(j)}]\\=\sum_{j|j\neq i}\mathbb E[\mathbf 1_{h(i)=h(j)}]\cdot f_j=\sum_{j|j\neq i}\Pr[h(i)=h(j)]\cdot f_j=\sum_{j|j\neq i}{f_j\over k}\le{\sum_jf_j\over k}={|f|_1\over k}E[X]=Ehâ€‹[jî€ =i,h(i)=h(j)âˆ‘â€‹fjâ€‹]=Ehâ€‹[jâˆ£jî€ =iâˆ‘â€‹fjâ€‹â‹…1h(i)=h(j)â€‹]=jâˆ£jî€ =iâˆ‘â€‹E[1h(i)=h(j)â€‹]â‹…fjâ€‹=jâˆ£jî€ =iâˆ‘â€‹Pr[h(i)=h(j)]â‹…fjâ€‹=jâˆ£jî€ =iâˆ‘â€‹kfjâ€‹â€‹â‰¤kâˆ‘jâ€‹fjâ€‹â€‹=kâˆ£fâˆ£1â€‹â€‹

Applying Markovâ€™s inequality, we have

Prâ¡[X>Ïµâˆ£fâˆ£1]â‰¤12.\Pr[X\gt\epsilon|f|_1]\le{1\over2}.Pr[X>Ïµâˆ£fâˆ£1â€‹]â‰¤21â€‹.

The probability that all the excesses at A[i,hi(xi)]A[i,h_i(x_i)]A[i,hiâ€‹(xiâ€‹)] are greater than Ïµâˆ£fâˆ£1\epsilon|f|_1Ïµâˆ£fâˆ£1â€‹ is at most 12tâ‰¤Î´{1\over2^t}\le\delta2t1â€‹â‰¤Î´ as ttt was chosen to be logâ¡(1/Î´)\log(1/\delta)log(1/Î´). The algorithm estimates the frequency of item xjx_jxjâ€‹ up to an additive error Ïµâˆ£fâˆ£1\epsilon|f|_1Ïµâˆ£fâˆ£1â€‹ with probability 1âˆ’Î´1-\delta1âˆ’Î´.

The memory required for the algorithm is the sum of the space for the array and the hash functions, O(ktlogâ¡n+tlogâ¡m)=O(1Ïµlogâ¡(1/Î´)logâ¡n)O(kt\log n+t\log m)=O({1\over\epsilon}\log(1/\delta)\log n)O(ktlogn+tlogm)=O(Ïµ1â€‹log(1/Î´)logn). The update time per item in the stream is O(logâ¡1Î´)O(\log{1\over\delta})O(logÎ´1â€‹).

Count Sketch

Another sketch algorithm with error in terms of the â„“2\ell_2â„“2â€‹ norm âˆ£fâˆ£2=âˆ‘jfj2|f|_2=\sqrt{\sum_jf_j^2}âˆ£fâˆ£2â€‹=âˆ‘jâ€‹fj2â€‹â€‹.

The relation between the â„“1\ell_1â„“1â€‹ and â„“2\ell_2â„“2â€‹ norm is 1nâˆ£fâˆ£1â‰¤âˆ£fâˆ£2â‰¤âˆ£fâˆ£1{1\over\sqrt n}|f|_1\le|f|_2\le|f|_1nâ€‹1â€‹âˆ£fâˆ£1â€‹â‰¤âˆ£fâˆ£2â€‹â‰¤âˆ£fâˆ£1â€‹, the â„“2\ell_2â„“2â€‹ norm is less than the â„“1\ell_1â„“1â€‹ norm so the guarantee for this algorithm is better than that for the previous one.

The algorithm works as follows:

  1. Maintain ttt arrays A[i]A[i]A[i] each having kkk counters, hash function: gi:Uâ†’{âˆ’1,1}g_i:U\rarr\{-1,1\}giâ€‹:Uâ†’{âˆ’1,1} and hi:Uâ†’[k]h_i:U\rarr[k]hiâ€‹:Uâ†’[k] drawn uniformly at random from a pair-wise independent families are associated to array A[i]A[i]A[i].

  2. For element (j,cj)(j,c_j)(j,cjâ€‹) in the stream, update counters as follows

    A[i,hi(j)]â†A[i,hi(j)]+gi(j)cjâˆ€iâˆˆ[t]A[i,h_i(j)]\gets A[i,h_i(j)]+g_i(j)c_j\forall i\in[t]A[i,hiâ€‹(j)]â†A[i,hiâ€‹(j)]+giâ€‹(j)cjâ€‹âˆ€iâˆˆ[t]

  3. The frequency estimate for item jjj is the median over the ttt arrays of gi(xj)A[i,h(j)]g_i(x_j)A[i,h(j)]giâ€‹(xjâ€‹)A[i,h(j)].

Analysis

The entry A[1,h1(j)]=g1(j)fj+XA[1,h_1(j)]=g_1(j)f_j+XA[1,h1â€‹(j)]=g1â€‹(j)fjâ€‹+X, we examine the contribution XXX from the other items by writing X=âˆ‘iYiX=\sum_iY_iX=âˆ‘iâ€‹Yiâ€‹ where YYY is Â±fi\pm f_iÂ±fiâ€‹ if h1(i)=h1(j)h_1(i)=h_1(j)h1â€‹(i)=h1â€‹(j) and 000 otherwise. Note that E[Yj]=0\mathbb E[Y_j]=0E[Yjâ€‹]=0, so the expected value of g1(j)A[1,h(j)]g_1(j)A[1,h(j)]g1â€‹(j)A[1,h(j)] is fjf_jfjâ€‹.

fi^=g(i)â‹…A[h(i)]=g(i)â‹…(g(i)â‹…fi+âˆ‘jâ‰ i,h(j)=h(i)g(j)â‹…fj)=fi+âˆ‘jâ‰ i,h(j)=h(i)g(i)g(j)fj=fi+XE[X]=E[âˆ‘jâ‰ i,h(j)=h(i)g(i)g(j)fj]=E[âˆ‘jâ‰ i1h(i)=h(j)g(i)g(j)fj]=âˆ‘jâ‰ iE[1h(i)=h(j)g(i)g(j)]fj=âˆ‘jâ‰ iE[1h(i)=h(j)]E[g(i)]E[g(j)]fj=0\hat{f_i}=g(i)\cdot A[h(i)]=g(i)\cdot(g(i)\cdot f_i+\sum_{j\neq i,h(j)=h(i)}g(j)\cdot f_j)\\=f_i+\sum_{j\neq i,h(j)=h(i)}g(i)g(j)f_j\\=f_i+X\\\mathbb E[X]=\mathbb E[\sum_{j\neq i,h(j)=h(i)}g(i)g(j)f_j]=\mathbb E[\sum_{j\neq i}\mathbf1_{h(i)=h(j)}g(i)g(j)f_j]\\=\sum_{j\neq i}\mathbb E[\mathbf1_{h(i)=h(j)}g(i)g(j)]f_j=\sum_{j\neq i}\mathbb E[\mathbf 1_{h(i)=h(j)}]\mathbb E[g(i)]\mathbb E[g(j)]f_j=0\\fiâ€‹^â€‹=g(i)â‹…A[h(i)]=g(i)â‹…(g(i)â‹…fiâ€‹+jî€ =i,h(j)=h(i)âˆ‘â€‹g(j)â‹…fjâ€‹)=fiâ€‹+jî€ =i,h(j)=h(i)âˆ‘â€‹g(i)g(j)fjâ€‹=fiâ€‹+XE[X]=E[jî€ =i,h(j)=h(i)âˆ‘â€‹g(i)g(j)fjâ€‹]=E[jî€ =iâˆ‘â€‹1h(i)=h(j)â€‹g(i)g(j)fjâ€‹]=jî€ =iâˆ‘â€‹E[1h(i)=h(j)â€‹g(i)g(j)]fjâ€‹=jî€ =iâˆ‘â€‹E[1h(i)=h(j)â€‹]E[g(i)]E[g(j)]fjâ€‹=0

The random variable YiY_iYiâ€‹ are pairwise independent as h1h_1h1â€‹ is a pair-wise independent hash function, so the variance of XXX:

Var(X)=âˆ‘iâˆˆ[m]Var(Yi)=âˆ‘iâˆˆ[m]fi2k=âˆ£fâˆ£22k.Var(X)=\sum_{i\in[m]}Var(Y_i)=\sum_{i\in[m]}{f^2_i\over k}={|f|_2^2\over k}.Var(X)=iâˆˆ[m]âˆ‘â€‹Var(Yiâ€‹)=iâˆˆ[m]âˆ‘â€‹kfi2â€‹â€‹=kâˆ£fâˆ£22â€‹â€‹.

By Chebyshevâ€™s inequality,

Prâ¡[âˆ£Xâˆ’Î¼âˆ£>Î”]â‰¤Var(X)Î”2.\Pr[|X-\mu|\gt\Delta]\le{Var(X)\over\Delta^2}.Pr[âˆ£Xâˆ’Î¼âˆ£>Î”]â‰¤Î”2Var(X)â€‹.

The mean Î¼=0\mu=0Î¼=0 and the variance is âˆ£fâˆ£22k|f|_2^2\over kkâˆ£fâˆ£22â€‹â€‹, choosing Î´=Ïµâˆ£fâˆ£2\delta=\epsilon|f|_2Î´=Ïµâˆ£fâˆ£2â€‹ and k=4/Ïµ2k=4/\epsilon^2k=4/Ïµ2, we have

Prâ¡[âˆ£Xâˆ’Î¼âˆ£>Ïµâˆ£fâˆ£2]â‰¤1Ïµ2kâ‰¤14.\Pr[|X-\mu|\gt\epsilon|f|_2]\le{1\over\epsilon^2k}\le{1\over4}.Pr[âˆ£Xâˆ’Î¼âˆ£>Ïµâˆ£fâˆ£2â€‹]â‰¤Ïµ2k1â€‹â‰¤41â€‹.

For t=Î¸(logâ¡(1/Î´))t=\theta(\log(1/\delta))t=Î¸(log(1/Î´)), the probability that the median value deviates from Î¼\muÎ¼ by more than Ïµâˆ£fâˆ£2\epsilon|f|_2Ïµâˆ£fâˆ£2â€‹ is less than Î´\deltaÎ´ by a Chernoff Bound. That is, the probability that there are fewer than t/2t/2t/2 success in a series of ttt tosses of a coin with success probability 343\over443â€‹ is smaller than Î´\deltaÎ´ for t=O(logâ¡(1Î´))t=O(\log({1\over\delta}))t=O(log(Î´1â€‹)).

Arguing as in the count min sketch the space required is O(1Ïµ2logâ¡1Î´logâ¡n)O({1\over\epsilon^2}\log{1\over\delta}\log n)O(Ïµ21â€‹logÎ´1â€‹logn) and the update time per item is O(logâ¡1Î´)O(\log{1\over\delta})O(logÎ´1â€‹).

Remarks

  • The count sketch approximates fjf_jfjâ€‹ within Ïµâˆ£fâˆ£2\epsilon|f|_2Ïµâˆ£fâˆ£2â€‹ but requires O~(1Ïµ2)\widetilde O({1\over\epsilon^2})O(Ïµ21â€‹) space,

  • while the count min sketch approximates fjf_jfjâ€‹ within Ïµâˆ£fâˆ£1\epsilon|f|_1Ïµâˆ£fâˆ£1â€‹ and requires O~(1Ïµ)\widetilde O({1\over\epsilon})O(Ïµ1â€‹).

  • The approximation provided by the sketch algorithm is meaningful only for items that occur with high frequency.

entry.title: æ•°æ®æŒ–æ˜ 4 Hierarchical and Subspace Clustering
entry.content:
When data has high dimensions or clusters have different densities, methods like DBSCAN and kkk-means might fail.

Hierarchical clustering partitions the space in progressively smaller clusters.

  • Hierarchical agglomerative clustering å±‚æ¬¡å‡èšèšç±»:single-link, complete-link and average-link strategies to merge clusters and form larger clusters.
  • OPTICS clustering that order density reachable points to find cluster structures
  • BRICH that summarizes the data to understand similarities

Subspace finds different clusters in different subsets of the dimensions in which the data lies.

  • CLIQUE: A clustering algorithm which divides the space into grids and exploit the apriori principle on density to compute dense subspaces
  • SUBCLU: Similar to CLIQUE but uses DBSCAN
  • PROCLUS: A projected clustering which finds the best dimensions for each clusters.

Agglomerative Hierarchical Clustering

Dendrogram: one of the main visualization tools for hierarchical clustering.

  • A tree, in which the root is a cluster containing all the points in the dataset D\mathcal DD and the leaves are clusters of single points.
  • Can be constructed bottom-up (agglomerative) by progressively merge smaller clusters into large one or top-down (divisive) by splitting larger clusters.
  • Height of a branch in the dendrogram show the distance.
  • Cut-off value as a vertical line identifies a partition of the data points.

Agglomerative hierarchical clustering takes a bottom-up approach.

  • Small clusters are progressively merged to form larger clusters.
  • Require the choice of a distance function.

Pseudo-code of Agglomerative Hierarchical Clustering

Input: dataset D\mathcal DD, clustering distance distdistdist

  • tâ†1t\larr1tâ†1

  • Ctâ†{{x}xâˆˆD}\mathcal C^t\larr\{\{\mathbb x\}_{\mathbb x\in\mathcal D}\}Ctâ†{{x}xâˆˆDâ€‹}

  • while Ctâ‰ D\mathcal C^t\neq\mathcal DCtî€ =D do

    • for each Ci,CjâˆˆCtC_i,C_j\in\mathcal C^tCiâ€‹,Cjâ€‹âˆˆCt do
      • Compute dist(Ci,Cj)dist(C_i,C_j)dist(Ciâ€‹,Cjâ€‹)

    // merge the clusters with the minimum distance

    • Ci,Cjâ†argâ¡minâ¡Ci,CjâˆˆCtdist(Ci,Cj)C_i,C_j\larr\arg\min_{C_i,C_j\in\mathcal C^t}dist(C_i,C_j)Ciâ€‹,Cjâ€‹â†argminCiâ€‹,Cjâ€‹âˆˆCtâ€‹dist(Ciâ€‹,Cjâ€‹)

    // Create a new level in the dendrogram

    • Ct+1â†(Ctâ•²Ci)â•²CjâˆªCjâˆª(CiâˆªCj)\mathcal C^{t+1}\larr(\mathcal C^t\diagdown C_i)\diagdown C_j\cup C_j\cup(C_i\cup C_j)Ct+1â†(Ctâ•²Ciâ€‹)â•²Cjâ€‹âˆªCjâ€‹âˆª(Ciâ€‹âˆªCjâ€‹)
    • tâ†t+1t\larr t+1tâ†t+1

  • return C\mathcal CC

Distance Among Clusters

The choice of distance metric determines the quality of the clustering

  • Single-link distance distsl(Ci,Cj)=minâ¡xâˆˆCi,yâˆˆCjdist(x,y)dist_{sl}(C_i,C_j)=\min_{\mathbb x\in C_i,\mathbb y\in C_j}dist(\mathbb x,\mathbb y)distslâ€‹(Ciâ€‹,Cjâ€‹)=minxâˆˆCiâ€‹,yâˆˆCjâ€‹â€‹dist(x,y): compute the minimum distance among two clusters
  • Complete-link distance distcl(Ci,Cj)=minâ¡xâˆˆCi,yâˆˆCjdist(x,y)dist_{cl}(C_i,C_j)=\min_{\mathbb x\in C_i,\mathbb y\in C_j}dist(\mathbb x,\mathbb y)distclâ€‹(Ciâ€‹,Cjâ€‹)=minxâˆˆCiâ€‹,yâˆˆCjâ€‹â€‹dist(x,y): compute the maximum distance among two clusters
  • Average-link distance distal(Ci,Cj)=1âˆ£Ciâˆ£âˆ£Cjâˆ£dist(x,y)dist_{al}(C_i,C_j)={1\over|C_i||C_j|}dist(\mathbb x,\mathbb y)distalâ€‹(Ciâ€‹,Cjâ€‹)=âˆ£Ciâ€‹âˆ£âˆ£Cjâ€‹âˆ£1â€‹dist(x,y): compute the average distance among two clusters

OPTICS

DBSCAN performs poorly when the clusters have different densities.

OPTICS abbr. for Ordering Points To Identify the Clustering Structure, solves the problem.

DBSCAN have fixed value of Ïµ\epsilonÏµ, a point might have a very large Ïµ\epsilonÏµ-neighborhood NÏµ(x)N_\epsilon(\mathbb x)NÏµâ€‹(x). Observation: the possibility to define the minimum distance under which a point is a core point. This distance is called the core distance cdistcdistcdist.

Core distance: the smallest distance s.t. x\mathbb xx is a core point

cdist(x)={MinPtsâˆ’thÂ smallestÂ distanceÂ dist(x,y)Â ifÂ âˆ£NÏµ(x)âˆ£â‰¥MinPts?Â otherwisecdist(\mathbb x)=\begin{cases}MinPts-th\text{ smallest distance }dist(\mathbb x,\mathbb y)\text{ if }|N_\epsilon(\mathbb x)|\ge MinPts\\?\text{ otherwise}\end{cases}cdist(x)={MinPtsâˆ’thÂ smallestÂ distanceÂ dist(x,y)Â ifÂ âˆ£NÏµâ€‹(x)âˆ£â‰¥MinPts?Â otherwiseâ€‹

Reachability distance: the distance of the closest point reachable to x\mathbb xx.

rdist(x)={dist(x,y)Â ifÂ dist(x,y)>cdist(y)cdist(y)Â ifÂ dist(x,y)<cdist(y)?Â ifÂ dist(x,y)>Ïµrdist(\mathbb x)=\begin{cases}dist(\mathbb x,\mathbb y)\text{ if }dist(\mathbb x,\mathbb y)\gt cdist(\mathbb y)\\cdist(\mathbb y)\text{ if }dist(\mathbb x,\mathbb y)\lt cdist(\mathbb y)\\?\text{ if }dist(\mathbb x,\mathbb y)\gt\epsilon\end{cases}rdist(x)=â©âªâªâ¨âªâªâ§â€‹dist(x,y)Â ifÂ dist(x,y)>cdist(y)cdist(y)Â ifÂ dist(x,y)<cdist(y)?Â ifÂ dist(x,y)>Ïµâ€‹

OPTICS is built upon the idea of core distance and reachability distance.

  • OPTICS maintains a basic data structure that stores the shortest reachability-distance seen so far
  • OPTICS visits each point once and moves to the next point based on the smallest reachability distance
  • OPTICS outputs the order of points, the core and the reachability distance of all points in a reachability plot.

Pseudo Code of OPTICS

  • for each xâˆˆD\mathbb x\in\mathcal DxâˆˆD do

    • if x\mathbb xx is not processed then

      • insert (x,?)(\mathbb x,?)(x,?) into CLCLCL

    • while CLâ‰ âˆ…CL\neq\emptyCLî€ =âˆ… do

      • select first element (x,rdist)âˆˆCL(\mathbb x,rdist)\in CL(x,rdist)âˆˆCL

      • retrieve NÏµ(x)N_\epsilon(\mathbb x)NÏµâ€‹(x) and cdistâ†cdist(x)cdist\larr cdist(\mathbb x)cdistâ†cdist(x)

      • x.processedâ†True\mathbb x.processed\larr Truex.processedâ†True

      • Write (x,rdist,cdist)(\mathbb x,rdist,cdist)(x,rdist,cdist) to file

      • if x\mathbb xx is a core object at distance distâ‰¤Ïµdist\le\epsilondistâ‰¤Ïµ then

        • for each pâˆˆNÏµ(x)\mathbb p\in N_\epsilon(\mathbb x)pâˆˆNÏµâ€‹(x) do

          • if p.processed=\mathbb p.processed=p.processed= false then

            rdistp=rdist(p,x)rdist_p=rdist(\mathbb p,\mathbb x)rdistpâ€‹=rdist(p,x)

            if (p,_)âˆˆÌ¸CL(\mathbb p,\_)\not\in CL(p,_)î€ âˆˆCL then

            • insert (p,rdistp)(\mathbb p,rdist_p)(p,rdistpâ€‹) into CLCLCL

            else if (p,old_rdist)âˆˆCL(\mathbb p,old\_rdist)\in CL(p,old_rdist)âˆˆCL and rdistp<old_rdistrdist_p\lt old\_rdistrdistpâ€‹<old_rdist then

            • update (p,rdistp)(p,rdist_p)(p,rdistpâ€‹) in CLCLCL

  • return CLCLCL

Finding a density based clustering w.r.t. Ïµâˆ—â‰¤Ïµ\epsilon^*\le\epsilonÏµâˆ—â‰¤Ïµ and MinPtsMinPtsMinPts is easy:

  • start with x\mathbb xx with cdist(x)â‰¤Ïµâˆ—cdist(\mathbb x)\le\epsilon^*cdist(x)â‰¤Ïµâˆ— and rdist(x,_)>Ïµâˆ—rdist(\mathbb x,\_)\gt\epsilon^*rdist(x,_)>Ïµâˆ—
  • continue while rdist(x,_)â‰¤Ïµâˆ—rdist(\mathbb x,\_)\le\epsilon^*rdist(x,_)â‰¤Ïµâˆ—

Running time. OPTICS running time is bounded by the running time of DBSCAN, Î©(n4/3)\Omega(n^{4/3})Î©(n4/3). OPTICS only maintains additional data structures, that do not affect the overall time complexity.

Analysis of reachability plot. The reachability plot shows both reachability and the core distance. Contiguous areas in the plot with large reachability and core-distance indicate regions with low density. At the same time, low reachability-distance indicates high-density areas. A jump in the plot occurs when the next point in order falls outside the current cluster.

OPTICS is relatively insensitive to parameter settings, and results are goods if the parameter are large enough.

Pros and Cons

ğŸ‘

  • Doesnâ€™t require the number of clusters to be known in advance.
  • Very robust
  • Computation complete hierarchically
  • Good visualization
  • A flat partition can be derived, e.g. dendrogram or reachability plot

ğŸ‘

  • No backtracking, greedy splits and merges
  • May not scale well. It examines many objects in order to split and merge. Runtime for standard methods is O(nlogâ¡n)O(n\log n)O(nlogn), OPTICS without indexing is O(n2)O(n^2)O(n2)

BRICH

Balanced Iterative Reducing and Clustering using Hierarchies.

It first summarizes the data and then clusters the summarized data with any clustering algorithm.

Can cluster huge datasets that do not fit into memory, with only very small loss in accuracy.

Incremental algorithm for accommodating new data points.

2 main phases of BRICH

  1. (Summarize) Scan the dataset D\mathcal DD to build an in-memory Clustering Feature tree. CF-tree is a multi-level compression that preserves inherent clustering structure,
  2. Use an arbitrary clustering algorithm to cluster the leaf nodes of the CF-tree.

BRICH scales linearly O(n)O(n)O(n) in the size of the dataset. To improve quality, BRICH can optionally scan the data multiple times.

Fast, but can only deal with numerical data.

Basic Idea of BRICH

  • Constructs a partitioning of the data into micro-clusters using an efficient index-like structure
  • The micro-clusters are representations of multiple points described by Clustering Features
  • CFs are organized hierarchically in a balanced tree
  • A standard clustering algorithm is then applied to the leaf entries of the CF-tree.

Clustering Features

A clustering features CF=(N,LS,SS)CF=(N,LS,SS)CF=(N,LS,SS) of a micro-cluster CâŠ†DC\subseteq DCâŠ†D consists of

  • N=âˆ£Câˆ£N=|C|N=âˆ£Câˆ£: Number of points in the micro-cluster
  • LS=âˆ‘xâˆˆCxLS=\sum_{\mathbb x\in C}\mathbb xLS=âˆ‘xâˆˆCâ€‹x: Linear sum of the data points in CCC
  • SS=âˆ‘xâˆˆCxi2SS=\sum_{\mathbb x\in C}\mathbb x_i^2SS=âˆ‘xâˆˆCâ€‹xi2â€‹: Square sum of the data points in CCC

Note that both LSLSLS and SSSSSS are vectors. The CF representation, although quite simple, is enough to compute a number of statistics about a cluster, such as centroids, measures of compactness, and distance measures of clusters.

Additivity Theorem: CFs satisfy additivity theorem that allows CFs to be computed incrementally on unions of micro-clusters. If two clusters are merged the CF of the new cluster is simply the element-wise sum of the respective CFs.

CF-tree

The CF-tree is an index similar to a B+ tree that contains the CF representations of the micro-cluster.

The tree-structure can be easily updated without scanning the entire data, by virtue of a nice data organization.

A CF-tree with parameters B,L,TB,L,TB,L,T is a tree-like structure, s.t.

  • An internal node contains at most BBB entries [CFi,childi][CF_i,child_i][CFiâ€‹,childiâ€‹]
  • A leaf node contains at most LLL entries [CFi][CF_i][CFiâ€‹]
  • The diameter or radius of all entries in a leaf node is at most TTT according to a user-defined distance metric
  • Leaf nodes are connected via prev and nxt pointers

The tree is constructed bottom-up in the following manner:

  • Transform point x\mathbb xx into CF vector CFx=(1,x,x2)CF_x=(1,\mathbb x,\mathbb x^2)CFxâ€‹=(1,x,x2)
  • Insert x\mathbb xx in the same way as in a B+ tree.
  • If threshold TTT is violated by insertion, then split the leaf node and reorganize tree, analog to that of B+ tree.

The BRICH Algorithm

  1. Scan all data points and build in memory CF tree using given amount of memory and recycling space

  2. (optional) Condense into desirable length by building a smaller CF tree.

  3. Global clustering with any clustering algorithm on the CF features vectors.

  4. (optional) refine with more passes

Pros and Cons

ğŸ‘

  • Compression factor can be tuned to the available memory
  • Efficient construction of a micro-clustering O(n)O(n)O(n)
  • Good clustering result for the partitioning iterative refine clustering algorithm such as kkk-means and kkk-medoid when applied to only the leaf nodes of a CF tree.

ğŸ‘

  • Only for data from a euclidean vector space
  • Handles only numeric data
  • Sensitive to the order of data records
  • Entries are limited by disk page size
  • Different parameters to tune

Subspace Clustering

Problem with high dimensional data: curse of dimensionality

A general phenomenon that occurs on points as the number of dimensions increases:

  • Sparsification: the data points grow further apart with dimension
  • Incomparability: the probability that points fall into a sphere of a certain radius becomes negligible, thus the distances of points from a center or another points become closer with the dimension.

A cluster in low dimension might not appear as such in higher dimension.

Subspace clustering attempts to tackle this problem by clustering the points in different subsets of the dimensions. Intuitively, in 3D it is like projecting the points on some of the coordinates.

The selection of the coordinates where to project is the main difference between the subspace clustering algorithms.

Another major difference is the clustering algorithm employed in the subspaces.

CLIQUE

One of the first algorithms for subspace clustering.

Density-based: divide the space into n/hn/hn/h cubic regions, prune regions that have less than a certain number of points Î¾\xiÎ¾ (density threshold) in low dimension and repeat the process on subspaces obtained by aggregating dimensions that contains at least one cluster.

The naive approach computes clustering for subsets of dimensions. However this approach considers O(2d)O(2^d)O(2d) clusters, which is prohibitive.

CLIQUE exploit the monotonicity of density for which a dense cluster in dimension ddd is dense in every subset of the ddd dimensions. A cluster is the union of dense regions. Therefore, we can construct a greedy algorithm based on pruning regions that are not dense.

The idea starts with an initial empty set of dimensions and iteratively include dimensions that are not pruned in the previous step.

The greedy algorithm in CLIQUE first finds 1-dimensional R1R_1R1â€‹ candidate regions, then generate 2-dimensional R2R_2R2â€‹ from the 1-dimensional candidates, prune the candidates using the monotonicity of density, and repeat the process increasing the dimension until no candidate is generated.

Pseudo Code of CLIQUE

Input: dataset D\mathcal DD, regions size hhh, density threshold Î¾\xiÎ¾

  • R1â†R_1\larrR1â€‹â† Candidate regions in 1-dimension

  • dâ†2d\larr2dâ†2

  • repeat

    • Rdâ†R_d\larrRdâ€‹â† Generate all candidate ddd-dimensional cells from Rdâˆ’1R_{d-1}Rdâˆ’1â€‹

    // Prune cells with fewer than Î¾\xiÎ¾ points

    • Rdâ†{R:âˆ£Râˆ£â‰¥Î¾}R_d\larr\{R:|R|\ge\xi\}Rdâ€‹â†{R:âˆ£Râˆ£â‰¥Î¾}
    • dâ†d+1d\larr d+1dâ†d+1

  • until Rdâ‰ âˆ…R_d\neq\emptyRdâ€‹î€ =âˆ…

  • Câ†\mathcal C\larrCâ† Compute clusters from each RiR_iRiâ€‹

  • Summarize cluster

// In the last two steps, CLIQUE computes the cluster from the dense regions and summarizes them.

Compute clusters from the union of adjacent candidate regions. Compute a graph for each candidate subspace in dimension ddd. The graph has a node for each dense region and an edge if two regions are adjacent. The connected components of the graph represent the clusters. This steps takes O(2dn)O(2dn)O(2dn) for each candidate subspace.

Summarizes cluster with a minimal number of inequalities, by defining boundaries on the regions. Since each region is represented by a number of dimensions, its boundaries are values of the dimensions that describe the regionâ€™s hypercube.

Pros and Cons

ğŸ‘

  • Automatic detection of subspaces with clusters
  • Automatic detection of clusters
  • No assumptions about the distribution of data
  • Insensitivity to the order of the data
  • Good scalability w.r.t. to the number nnn of data points

ğŸ‘

  • Accuracy of result depends on the number of partitions h/nh/nh/n
  • Requires heuristics to avoid constructing all subspaces

SUBCLU

CLIQUE might miss clusters due an early pruning of the regions that cross the clusters.

SUBCLU remedies to CLIQUEâ€™s deficiency by using DBSCAN as the basis to find dense clusters in a subspace. Without entering into details the definition of core-objects, density reachability and connectivity can easily adapt to subspaces. Similarly, SUBCLU exploits the monotonicity of density connectivity:

  • If x,y\mathbb x,\mathbb yx,y are density-connected in ddd-dimensional space, all their projections in kâˆ’1k-1kâˆ’1 are also density-connected.

The algorithm iteratively applies DBSCAN at each step to generate ddd-dimensional clusters as in CLIQUE

Pros and Cons

ğŸ‘

  • Automatic detection of subspaces containing clusters
  • Automatic detection of clusters
  • No assumptions on data distributions (density-based approach)

ğŸ‘

  • Parameter setting highly affects clustering results
  • Inherits the drawback of DBSCAN, such as the sensitivity w.r.t. clusters with different densities.
  • At least O(n2)O(n^2)O(n2) time. Typically worse depending on max-dimensionality of the subspace containing clusters.

Projected Clustering

It tackles the curse of dimensionality differently from subspace clustering.

Main idea: To project each point individually into the only subspace in which the point is clustered.

The goal of projected clustering is correctly identify the right projections, s.t. each point is assigned exactly to one cluster. Projected clustering avoids rediscovering the clusters in multiple subspaces but at the same time, might miss clusters.

PROCLUS

A representative method for projected clustering.

Top-down approach that iteratively refines clusters and projections starting from an initial clustering of the data in the full dimension.

PROCLUS uses kkk-medoid algorithm to find clusters.

Projection cluster: a set of objects CCC and a set of dimension DDD, s.t. the objects in CCC are closely clustered in the subspace defined DDD.

Closely clustered: A cluster CCC is closely clustered if it is compact under the Manhattan segmental distance

d(x,y)=1âˆ£DCâˆ£âˆ‘iâˆˆDCâˆ£xiâˆ’yiâˆ£d(\mathbb x,\mathbb y)={1\over|D_C|}\sum_{i\in D_C}|x_i-y_i|d(x,y)=âˆ£DCâ€‹âˆ£1â€‹iâˆˆDCâ€‹âˆ‘â€‹âˆ£xiâ€‹âˆ’yiâ€‹âˆ£

that measures the Manhattan distance of the objects in the projected dimensions DDD of cluster CCC.

PROCLUS requires the specification of the number kkk of clusters and the average number d^\hat dd^ of dimensions. PROCLUS follows a multi-step approach in three phases

  1. Initialization: selects the initial set of medoids

    Select a sample of representative data points from the entire dataset, where the sample should ideally characterize the entire dataset and should contain at least kkk medoids. In practice, since finding such an ideal a sample is hard, PROCLUS greedily selects Aâ‹…kA\cdot kAâ‹…k well-separated points.

  2. Iterative: refines the medoids and computes the projections.

    Main body of PROCLUS that determines the best set of dimensions for a set of candidate medoids

    • Choose random set of kkk-medoids from representative points
    • Determine optimal set of dimensions for each medoid
    • Assign all objects to the nearest medoid
    • Update current clustering if it is better than the previous until termination

    The iteration continues from step 2. By replacing bad medoids with random medoids from the sample of representatives until the clusters do not change anymore.

    First issue: how to determine an optimal set of dimensions for each medoid?

    PROCLUS proposes a score ZijZ_{ij}Zijâ€‹ that measures the reduction in dispersion of the cluster CiC_iCiâ€‹ on dimension jjj as opposed to the full dimensionality ddd.

    For each medoid mi\mathbb m_imiâ€‹ calculate the average distance XijX_{ij}Xijâ€‹ on dimension jjj of objects in the hyper-sphere Li\mathcal L_iLiâ€‹ with radius the distance from mi\mathbb m_imiâ€‹ to its nearest medoid. The dispersion of cluster iii is the average distance XijX_{ij}Xijâ€‹ for all the dimensions Yi=1dâˆ‘j=1dXijY_i={1\over d}\sum_{j=1}^dX_{ij}Yiâ€‹=d1â€‹âˆ‘j=1dâ€‹Xijâ€‹. The deviation Xijâˆ’YiX_{ij}-Y_iXijâ€‹âˆ’Yiâ€‹ is negative if the clusters on dimension jjj are correlated to those in the full dimension

    The score ZijZ_{ij}Zijâ€‹ is normalized deviation Xijâˆ’YiX_{ij}-Y_iXijâ€‹âˆ’Yiâ€‹: Zij=1Ïƒi(Xijâˆ’Yi)Z_{ij}={1\over\sigma_i}(X_{ij}-Y_i)Zijâ€‹=Ïƒiâ€‹1â€‹(Xijâ€‹âˆ’Yiâ€‹) where Ïƒi\sigma_iÏƒiâ€‹ is the empirical standard deviation of XXX in cluster iii.

    \sigma_i=\sqrt

entry.title: éšæœºç®—æ³• 4 Karger's Min Cut Algorithm
entry.content:
Lecturer this time: Ioannis Caragiannis

Lecture notes is based on Kargerâ€™s Min Cut Algorithm by Sanjeev Arora, Sanjoy Dasgupta

Kargerâ€™s min cut algorithm and its extension. Itâ€™s simple for finding the minimum cut in a graph.

Clustering via Graph Cuts

The minimum cut of an undirected graph G=(V,E)G=(V,E)G=(V,E) is a partition of the nodes into two groups V1,V2V_1,V_2V1â€‹,V2â€‹ (s.t. V=V1âˆªV2V=V_1\cup V_2V=V1â€‹âˆªV2â€‹ and V1âˆ©V2=âˆ…V_1\cap V_2=\emptyV1â€‹âˆ©V2â€‹=âˆ…) so that the number of edges between V1V_1V1â€‹ and V2V_2V2â€‹ is minimized.

Variant of cut problem:

  1. Minimum global cut: å°†å›¾åˆ†æˆä¸¤ä¸è¿é€šéƒ¨åˆ†æ‰€éœ€çš„æœ€å°å‰²

  2. Minimum s-t cut: åˆ†å¼€æºç‚¹ s å’Œæ±‡ç‚¹ t æ‰€éœ€çš„æœ€å°å‰²

    size of minimum s-t cut = value of maximum s-t flow

    Algorithm: Ford-Fulkerson algorithm (compute then remove augmenting paths in a residual network è®¡ç®—å¢å¹¿è·¯å¾„), Edmonds-Karp algorithm (O(nâˆ£Eâˆ£2)O(n|E|^2)O(nâˆ£Eâˆ£2))

ä¸€ä¸ªå¾ˆè‡ªç„¶çš„è®¡ç®— minimal global cut çš„ deterministic ç®—æ³•ï¼š

  1. é€‰æ‹©ä¸€ä¸ªå›ºå®šæºç‚¹ s fix a node s

  2. å°†å…¶ä»– nâˆ’1n-1nâˆ’1 ä¸ªç‚¹åˆ†åˆ«å½“ä½œæ±‡ç‚¹ tï¼Œä½¿ç”¨ EK ç®—æ³•æ‰§è¡Œ nâˆ’1n-1nâˆ’1 æ¬¡ï¼Œåˆ†åˆ«è®¡ç®— s åˆ°è¿™äº› t çš„æœ€å¤§æµ the global should disconnect node s from any other node t.

  3. è¿”å›è¿™äº›æœ€å¤§æµçš„æœ€å°å€¼ return the minimum s-t cut in all these executions

    æ—¶é—´å¤æ‚åº¦ä¸º O(n2âˆ£Eâˆ£2)O(n^2|E|^2)O(n2âˆ£Eâˆ£2) Itâ€™s the algorithm we wanna beat today.

    O(n4)â‰¤O(n2âˆ£Eâˆ£2)â‰¤O(n6)O(n^4)\le O(n^2|E|^2)\le O(n^6)O(n4)â‰¤O(n2âˆ£Eâˆ£2)â‰¤O(n6)

Kargerâ€™s Algorithm

Randomized algorithm for finding the minimum cut:

  • Repeat until just two nodes remain:
    • Pick an edge of GGG at random and collapse its two endpoints into a single node.
  • For the two remaining nodes u1,u2u_1,u_2u1â€‹,u2â€‹, set V1={nodesÂ thatÂ wentÂ intoÂ u1}V_1=\{\text{nodes that went into }u_1\}V1â€‹={nodesÂ thatÂ wentÂ intoÂ u1â€‹} and V2={nodesÂ thatÂ wentÂ intoÂ u2}V_2=\{\text{nodes that went into }u_2\}V2â€‹={nodesÂ thatÂ wentÂ intoÂ u2â€‹}.

The algorithm has running time O(n2)O(n^2)O(n2)

  • linear time to update node/edge information after a contraction
  • nâˆ’2n-2nâˆ’2 contraction in total.

Analysis

Some facts help to analyze the algorithm.

Fact 1

If degree(u)degree(u)degree(u) denotes the number of edges touching node uuu, then

âˆ‘uâˆˆVdegree(u)=2âˆ£Eâˆ£\sum_{u\in V}degree(u)=2|E|uâˆˆVâˆ‘â€‹degree(u)=2âˆ£Eâˆ£

Obviously, each edge contributes twice w.r.t. 2 nodes it connects.

Fact 2

If there are nnn nodes, then the average degree of a node is 2âˆ£Eâˆ£n2|E|\over nn2âˆ£Eâˆ£â€‹.

A very straightforward conclusion.

When we randomly pick a node XXX at random:

E[degree(X)]=âˆ‘uâˆˆVPrâ¡(X=u)degree(u)=1nâˆ‘uâˆˆVdegree(u)=2âˆ£Eâˆ£n\mathbb E[degree(X)]=\sum_{u\in V}\Pr(X=u)degree(u)={1\over n}\sum_{u\in V}degree(u)=\frac{2|E|}{n}E[degree(X)]=uâˆˆVâˆ‘â€‹Pr(X=u)degree(u)=n1â€‹uâˆˆVâˆ‘â€‹degree(u)=n2âˆ£Eâˆ£â€‹

Fact 3

The size of the minimum cut is at most 2âˆ£Eâˆ£n2|E|\over nn2âˆ£Eâˆ£â€‹.

Consider the partition of VVV into two pieces, one containing a single node uuu, and the other containing the remaining nâˆ’1n-1nâˆ’1 nodes. The size of this cut is degree(u)degree(u)degree(u). Since this is a valid cut, the minimum cut cannot be bigger than this. i.e.,

âˆ€uâˆˆV,mincutâ‰¤degree(u)â‡’mincutâ‰¤minâ¡uâˆˆV(degree(u))â‰¤avguâˆˆV(degree(u))=2âˆ£Eâˆ£n.\forall u\in V, mincut\le degree(u)\\\Rarr mincut\le\min_{u\in V}(degree(u))\le\text{avg}_{u\in V}(degree(u))=\frac{2|E|}{n}.âˆ€uâˆˆV,mincutâ‰¤degree(u)â‡’mincutâ‰¤uâˆˆVminâ€‹(degree(u))â‰¤avguâˆˆVâ€‹(degree(u))=n2âˆ£Eâˆ£â€‹.

Fact 4

If an edge is picked at random, the probability that it lies across the minimum cut is at most 2n2\over nn2â€‹.

This is because there are âˆ£Eâˆ£|E|âˆ£Eâˆ£ edges to choose from, and at most 2âˆ£Eâˆ£n2|E|\over nn2âˆ£Eâˆ£â€‹ of them are in the minimum cut.

By facts above, we can easily analyze Kargerâ€™s algorithm.

Each time an edge is collapsed, the number of nodes decreases by 111. Therefore,

Prâ¡(finalÂ cutÂ isÂ theÂ minimumÂ cut)=Prâ¡(firstÂ edgeÂ notÂ inÂ mincut)Ã—Prâ¡(secondÂ edgeÂ notÂ inÂ mincut)Ã—â‹¯â‰¥(1âˆ’2n)Ã—(1âˆ’2nâˆ’1)Ã—â‹¯Ã—(1âˆ’24)Ã—(1âˆ’23)=nâˆ’2nâ‹…nâˆ’3nâˆ’1â‹…nâˆ’4nâˆ’2â‹¯24â‹…13=2n(nâˆ’1)=(n2)âˆ’1\Pr(\text{final cut is the minimum cut})=\Pr(\text{first edge not in mincut})\times\\\Pr(\text{second edge not in mincut})\times\cdots\\\ge(1-\frac{2}{n})\times(1-\frac{2}{n-1})\times\cdots\times(1-\frac{2}{4})\times(1-\frac{2}{3})\\={n-2\over n}\cdot{n-3\over n-1}\cdot{n-4\over n-2}\cdots{2\over4}\cdot{1\over3}\\={2\over n(n-1)}=\left(\begin{array}{c}n\\2\end{array}\right)^{-1}Pr(finalÂ cutÂ isÂ theÂ minimumÂ cut)=Pr(firstÂ edgeÂ notÂ inÂ mincut)Ã—Pr(secondÂ edgeÂ notÂ inÂ mincut)Ã—â‹¯â‰¥(1âˆ’n2â€‹)Ã—(1âˆ’nâˆ’12â€‹)Ã—â‹¯Ã—(1âˆ’42â€‹)Ã—(1âˆ’32â€‹)=nnâˆ’2â€‹â‹…nâˆ’1nâˆ’3â€‹â‹…nâˆ’2nâˆ’4â€‹â‹¯42â€‹â‹…31â€‹=n(nâˆ’1)2â€‹=(n2â€‹)âˆ’1

Kargerâ€™s algorithm succeeds with probability pâ‰¥2n2p\ge {2\over n^2}pâ‰¥n22â€‹. Therefore, it should be run Î©(n2)\Omega(n^2)Î©(n2) times, after which the smallest cut found should be chosen.

Another way to implement Kargerâ€™s algorithm:

  • Assign each edge a random weight
  • Run Kruskalâ€™s algorithm to get the minimum spanning tree
  • Break the largest edge in the tree to get the two clusters.

Why does Kruskalâ€™s algorithm work?

Waiting for Iannis to tell me â€¦

Run Multiple Times to Bound Error Probability

In order to boost the probability of success, we simply run the algorithm â„“(n2)\ell\left(\begin{array}{c}n\\2\end{array}\right)â„“(n2â€‹) times.

The probability that at least one run succeeds is at least

1âˆ’(1âˆ’(n2)âˆ’1)â„“(n2)â‰¥1âˆ’eâˆ’â„“.1-\left(1-(\begin{array}{c}n\\2\end{array})^{-1}\right)^{\ell(\begin{array}{c}n\\2\end{array})}\ge 1-e^{-\ell}.1âˆ’(1âˆ’(n2â€‹)âˆ’1)â„“(n2â€‹)â‰¥1âˆ’eâˆ’â„“.

Setting â„“=clnâ¡n\ell=c\ln nâ„“=clnn, we have error probability â‰¤1nc\le{1\over n^c}â‰¤nc1â€‹.

Itâ€™s easy to implement Kargerâ€™s algorithm so that one run takes O(n2)O(n^2)O(n2) time. Therefore, by running the algorithm O(n2logâ¡n)O(n^2\log n)O(n2logn) times, we have an O(n4logâ¡n)O(n^4\log n)O(n4logn) time randomized algorithm with error probability 1poly(n)1\over\text{poly}(n)poly(n)1â€‹. Still better than EK algorithm for not very sparse graphs.

The Number of mincutmincutmincut

Theorem: Any graph has at most n(nâˆ’1)2n(n-1)\over22n(nâˆ’1)â€‹ distinct global cuts of mincutmincutmincut.

Recall that we fixed a particular minimum cut and proved the probability 2n(nâˆ’1)2\over n(n-1)n(nâˆ’1)2â€‹.

Denote by CiC_iCiâ€‹ the event that the iii-th minimum cut is returned in an execution by the contraction algorithm, Prâ¡[Ci]â‰¥2/n(nâˆ’1)\Pr[C_i]\ge2/n(n-1)Pr[Ciâ€‹]â‰¥2/n(nâˆ’1).

Faster Version

Proposed by Karger and Stein.

Key idea

In the initial merging, itâ€™s very unlikely we merged an edge in the mincutmincutmincut. Towards the end of the algorithm, our probability of selecting an edge in the mincutmincutmincut grows.

For a fixed minimum cut Î´(S)\delta(S)Î´(S), the probability that this cut survives down to â„“\ellâ„“ vertices is at least Câ„“2/Cn2C_\ell^2/C_n^2Câ„“2â€‹/Cn2â€‹. Thus, for â„“=n/2\ell=n/\sqrt2â„“=n/2â€‹ we have probability â‰¥12\ge{1\over2}â‰¥21â€‹ of succeeding.

Detail in slides page 91.

Improved algorithm: From a multi-graph GGG, if GGG has at least 666 vertices, repeat twice:

  1. run the original algorithm down to n2+1{n\over\sqrt2}+12â€‹nâ€‹+1 vertices.
  2. recurse on the resulting graph.

Return the minimum of the cuts found in the two recursive calls.

The choice of 666 instead of other constant will only affect the running time by a constant factor.

T(n)=2T(n/2)+O(n2)=O(n2logâ¡n).T(n)=2T(n/\sqrt2)+O(n^2)=O(n^2\log n).T(n)=2T(n/2â€‹)+O(n2)=O(n2logn).

Since we succeed down to n/2n/\sqrt2n/2â€‹ with probability â‰¥12\ge{1\over2}â‰¥21â€‹, we have the following recurrence for the probability of success, denote by P(n)P(n)P(n):

P(n)â‰¥1âˆ’(1âˆ’12P(n/2+1))2P(n)\ge1-\left(1-\frac{1}{2}P(n/\sqrt2+1)\right)^2P(n)â‰¥1âˆ’(1âˆ’21â€‹P(n/2â€‹+1))2

Inner term is probability that the sub-instance preserved mincutmincutmincut AND recursive call found this optimum.

probability of success = 1 - probability of failure.

probability of failure = probability of both subroutines fails

probability of both subroutines fails = square of (probability of a subroutine fails)

probability of a subroutine fails = 1 - 1/2 * one successful recursive call

This solves to P(n)=Î©(1logâ¡n)P(n)=\Omega({1\over\log n})P(n)=Î©(logn1â€‹). WHY???

Set Q(h)=P(2h/2)Q(h)=P(2^{h/2})Q(h)=P(2h/2)

This inequality becomes Q(h)â‰¥Q(hâˆ’1)âˆ’Q(hâˆ’1)24Q(h)\ge Q(h-1)-{Q(h-1)^2\over4}Q(h)â‰¥Q(hâˆ’1)âˆ’4Q(hâˆ’1)2â€‹

It suffices to show inductively that Q(h)â‰¥1h+1Q(h)\ge{1\over h+1}Q(h)â‰¥h+11â€‹

Observe that the RHS of the inequality is increasing in Q(hâˆ’1)Q(h-1)Q(hâˆ’1).

By induction hypothesis, Q(hâˆ’1)â‰¥1hQ(h-1)\ge{1\over h}Q(hâˆ’1)â‰¥h1â€‹, the inequality implies that

Q(h)â‰¥1hâˆ’(1/h)24â‰¥1hâˆ’1h(h+1)=1h+1Q(h)\ge{1\over h}-{(1/h)^2\over4}\ge{1\over h}-{1\over h(h+1)}={1\over h+1}Q(h)â‰¥h1â€‹âˆ’4(1/h)2â€‹â‰¥h1â€‹âˆ’h(h+1)1â€‹=h+11â€‹

as desired.

Hence, similar to the earlier argument for the original algorithm, with O(logâ¡2n)O(\log^2n)O(log2n) runs of the algorithm, the probability of success is 1âˆ’1poly(n)1-{1\over\text{poly}(n)}1âˆ’poly(n)1â€‹.

There fore in O(n2logâ¡3n)O(n^2\log^3n)O(n2log3n) total time, we can find the minimum cut with probability 1âˆ’1poly(n)1-{1\over\text{poly}(n)}1âˆ’poly(n)1â€‹.

entry.title: å…¬å¹³åˆ†é… 2 Relations of Fairness Properties
entry.content:
Objective: Investigate relations between several fairness properties and their approximations.

Activities: Read and present the paper Multiple birds with one stone (2020).

Abstract

Algorithm proposed, achieves (Ï•âˆ’1)(\phi-1)(Ï•âˆ’1)-EFX and 2Ï•+2\frac{2}{\phi+2}Ï•+22â€‹-GMMS. (Ï•=5+12\phi={\sqrt5+1\over2}Ï•=25â€‹+1â€‹)

Previous work: 121\over221â€‹-EFX. 121\over221â€‹-GMMS. EF1 + 232\over332â€‹-PMMS.

GMMS PMMS EFX allocation always exist when # of goods â‰¤2Ã—\le2\timesâ‰¤2Ã—# of agents.

Introduction

Relaxation of fairness notion: EF â†’ EFX, EF1

Approximation of relaxed fairness notion: Î±\alphaÎ±-EFXâ€¦

A good approximation of any one of EF1, EFX, MMS, PMMS doesnâ€™t necessarily imply particularly strong guarantees for any of the others. Thus itâ€™s desirable to achieve approximation of several fairness notions simultaneously.

Main Contribution

Algorithm proposed in this paper:

  1. 0.6180.6180.618-EFX
  2. 0.5530.5530.553-GMMS
  3. EF1
  4. 0.6670.6670.667-PMMS

Algorithm is based on draft algorithm, envy-cycle elimination. (parametric version)

GMMS PMMS EFX always exist and can be found efficiently when # of goods â‰¤2Ã—\le2\timesâ‰¤2Ã—# of agents. non-trivial problem

Related Work

Skipped here

Preliminaries

N={1,2,â‹¯â€‰,n}N=\{1,2,\cdots,n\}N={1,2,â‹¯,n} set of nnn agents.

MMM set of mmm indivisible items.

Valuation function should be monotone and additive: âˆ€SâŠ†M,vi(S)=âˆ‘gâˆˆSvi(g)\forall S\subseteq M,v_i(S)=\sum_{g\in S}v_i(g)âˆ€SâŠ†M,viâ€‹(S)=âˆ‘gâˆˆSâ€‹viâ€‹(g) and (\forall i\in N)\and(\forall g\in M),v_i(g)\ge0.

Assume that we have already know the valuation function for each agent.

All the goods should be allocated, i.e., no free disposal.

Allocation: A=(A1,â‹¯â€‰,An)\mathcal A=(A_1,\cdots,A_n)A=(A1â€‹,â‹¯,Anâ€‹) where Aiâˆ©Ajâ‰ âˆ…A_i\cap A_j\neq\emptysetAiâ€‹âˆ©Ajâ€‹î€ =âˆ… and â‹ƒiAi=M\bigcup_iA_i=Mâ‹ƒiâ€‹Aiâ€‹=M.

  • AiA_iAiâ€‹ is the bundle allocated to agent iii,

Î n(M)\Pi_n(M)Î nâ€‹(M): set of all partitions of a set MMM into nnn bundles.

Fairness Concepts (Review)

Family of Envy-freeness

  • EF, EF1, EFX, Î±\alphaÎ±-EFX

  • EF â†’ EFX

Family of Maximin Share (worst-case guarantee)

  • Maximin Share Î¼i\mu_iÎ¼iâ€‹

    • To find an allocation A\mathcal AA s.t., for each agent iii it maximizes minâ¡AjâˆˆAvi(Aj)\min_{A_j\in\mathcal A}v_i(A_j)minAjâ€‹âˆˆAâ€‹viâ€‹(Ajâ€‹)

      â‡”Î¼i(n,S)=maxâ¡AâˆˆÎ n(S)minâ¡AjâˆˆAvi(Aj)\Lrarr\mu_i(n,S)=\max_{\mathcal A\in\Pi_n(S)}\min_{A_j\in\mathcal A}v_i(A_j)â‡”Î¼iâ€‹(n,S)=maxAâˆˆÎ nâ€‹(S)â€‹minAjâ€‹âˆˆAâ€‹viâ€‹(Ajâ€‹)

  • Î±\alphaÎ±-MMS âˆ€iâˆˆN,vi(Ai)â‰¥Î±â‹…Î¼i(n,M)\forall i\in N,v_i(A_i)\ge\alpha\cdot\mu_i(n,M)âˆ€iâˆˆN,viâ€‹(Aiâ€‹)â‰¥Î±â‹…Î¼iâ€‹(n,M)

  • Î±\alphaÎ±-P(Pairwise)MMS: For each pair i,jâˆˆN,vi(Ai)â‰¥Î±â‹…Î¼i(2,AiâˆªAj)i,j\in N,v_i(A_i)\ge\alpha\cdot\mu_i(2,A_i\cup A_j)i,jâˆˆN,viâ€‹(Aiâ€‹)â‰¥Î±â‹…Î¼iâ€‹(2,Aiâ€‹âˆªAjâ€‹)

  • Î±\alphaÎ±-G(Groupwise)MMS: For each subset Nâ€²âŠ†NN'\subseteq NNâ€²âŠ†N, âˆ€iâˆˆNâ€²,vi(Ai)â‰¥Î±â‹…Î¼i(âˆ£Nâ€²âˆ£,âˆªjâˆˆNâ€²Aj)\forall i\in N',v_i(A_i)\ge\alpha\cdot\mu_i(|N'|,\cup_{j\in N'}A_j)âˆ€iâˆˆNâ€²,viâ€‹(Aiâ€‹)â‰¥Î±â‹…Î¼iâ€‹(âˆ£Nâ€²âˆ£,âˆªjâˆˆNâ€²â€‹Ajâ€‹)

    Thus, GMMSâ‡’\Rarrâ‡’MMS, MMSâ†’Ì¸\not\rarrî€ â†’PMMS (GMMS is for all the subset of agents, MMS is only for all the agents)

Known EF1 Algorithms

Envy-cycle Elimination Algorithm

Partial allocation PâŠŠM\mathcal P\subsetneq MPâŠŠM.

Envy graph GP=(N,EP)G_\mathcal P=(N,E_\mathcal P)GPâ€‹=(N,EPâ€‹) where (i,j)âˆˆEP(i,j)\in E_\mathcal P(i,j)âˆˆEPâ€‹ iff agent iii currently envies agent jjj.

In each step, an agent that no one envies receives the next available good.

Tie-breaking: lexicographically order.

â—ğŸ¤”Theorem 1: Let P\mathcal PP be any EF1 partial allocation and Mâ€²=Mâ•²âˆªi=1nPiM'=M\diagdown\cup_{i=1}^nP_iMâ€²=Mâ•²âˆªi=1nâ€‹Piâ€‹. Then,

(a) At the end of each iteration of the for loop, the resulting partial allocation is EF1. Thus the algorithm terminates with EF1 allocation.

(b) Fix an agent iii, let AiA_iAiâ€‹ be the bundle assigned to iii at the end of some iteration of the for loop. If Aiâ€²A_i'Aiâ€²â€‹ is assigned to iii at the end of a future iteration, then vi(Aiâ€²)â‰¥vi(Ai)v_i(A_i')\ge v_i(A_i)viâ€‹(Aiâ€²â€‹)â‰¥viâ€‹(Aiâ€‹) MONOTONICITY!

(Proof by additive and monotone valuation function.)

Pseudo code for Envy-cycle Elimination(N,P,Mâ€²)(N,\mathcal P,M')(N,P,Mâ€²) Mâ€²M'Mâ€² denotes set of unallocated goods.

  1. Construct the envy graph GPG_\mathcal PGPâ€‹.

  2. for every gâˆˆMâ€²g\in M'gâˆˆMâ€², in lexicographic order do

    • While there is no node of in-degree 0 in GPG_\mathcal PGPâ€‹ do

      • Find a cycle j1â†’j2â†’â‹¯â†’jrâ†’j1j_1\rarr j_2\rarr\cdots\rarr j_r\rarr j_1j1â€‹â†’j2â€‹â†’â‹¯â†’jrâ€‹â†’j1â€‹ in GPG_\mathcal PGPâ€‹
      • B=Pj1B=P_{j1}B=Pj1â€‹
      • for k=1k=1k=1 to râˆ’1r-1râˆ’1 do
        • Pjk=Pjk+1P_{jk}=P_{jk+1}Pjkâ€‹=Pjk+1â€‹
      • Pjr=BP_{jr}=BPjrâ€‹=B.

      // find a envy-cycle and eliminate it iteratively.

    • Let iâˆˆNi\in NiâˆˆN be a node of in-degree =0=0=0

    • Pi=Piâˆª{g}P_i=P_i\cup\{g\}Piâ€‹=Piâ€‹âˆª{g}

    • Update GPG_\mathcal PGPâ€‹

  3. return P\mathcal PP

Round Robin Algorithm

Round-robin(N,P,Mâ€²,â„“,Ï„)(N,\mathcal P,M',\ell,\tau)(N,P,Mâ€²,â„“,Ï„) also outputs EF1 allocation: â„“\ellâ„“ denotes an order of NNN, Ï„\tauÏ„ denotes number of steps

  1. k=1k=1k=1

  2. while Mâ€²â‰ âˆ…M'\neq\emptysetMâ€²î€ =âˆ… and Ï„>0\tau\gt0Ï„>0 do

    • g=argâ¡maxâ¡hâˆˆMâ€²vâ„“[k](h)g=\arg\max_{h\in M'}v_{\ell[k]}(h)g=argmaxhâˆˆMâ€²â€‹vâ„“[k]â€‹(h)

      In the while loop, each round player â„“[k]\ell[k]â„“[k] get currently the maximal value of good.

    • Pâ„“[k]=Pâ„“[k]âˆª{g}P_{\ell[k]}=P_{\ell[k]}\cup\{g\}Pâ„“[k]â€‹=Pâ„“[k]â€‹âˆª{g}

    • Mâ€²=Mâ€²â•²{g}M'=M'\diagdown\{g\}Mâ€²=Mâ€²â•²{g}

    • k=(k+1)modâ€‰â€‰nk=(k+1)\mod nk=(k+1)modn

    • Ï„=Ï„âˆ’1\tau=\tau-1Ï„=Ï„âˆ’1

  3. return (P,Mâ€²)(\mathcal P,M')(P,Mâ€²)

Draft and Eliminate Algorithm

Draft and Eliminate(N,M)(N,M)(N,M) also outputs EF1 allocation: Combination of ECE & RR

  1. (â„“,nâ€²)=(\ell,n')=(â„“,nâ€²)= Preprocessing(N,M)(N,M)(N,M)
  2. Let A=(A1,â‹¯â€‰,An)\mathcal A=(A_1,\cdots,A_n)A=(A1â€‹,â‹¯,Anâ€‹) with Ai=âˆ…A_i=\emptyAiâ€‹=âˆ… for each iâˆˆNi\in NiâˆˆN
  3. (A,Mâ€²)=(\mathcal A,M')=(A,Mâ€²)= Round-robin(N,A,M,â„“,n)(N,\mathcal A,M,\ell,n)(N,A,M,â„“,n)
  4. Reverse â„“\ellâ„“: â„“R=(â„“[n],â„“[nâˆ’1],â‹¯â€‰,â„“[1])\ell^R=(\ell[n],\ell[n-1],\cdots,\ell[1])â„“R=(â„“[n],â„“[nâˆ’1],â‹¯,â„“[1])
  5. (A,Mâ€²)=(\mathcal A,M')=(A,Mâ€²)= Round-robin(N,A,Mâ€²,â„“R,nâˆ’nâ€²)(N,\mathcal A,M',\ell^R,n-n')(N,A,Mâ€²,â„“R,nâˆ’nâ€²)
  6. A=\mathcal A=A= Envy-cycle Elimination(N,A,Mâ€²)(N,\mathcal A,M')(N,A,Mâ€²)
  7. return A\mathcal AA

â—ğŸ¤”Theorem 2

Let â„“\ellâ„“ be any ordering of NNN and Pâˆ…=(âˆ…,â‹¯â€‰,âˆ…)\mathcal P_\empty=(\empty,\cdots,\empty)Pâˆ…â€‹=(âˆ…,â‹¯,âˆ…), Round-robin algorithm produces an EF1 allocation in polynomial time.

âœ‹Time complexity analysis:

  • Number of loop iterative is â‰¤minâ¡(m,Ï„)â‰¤O(m)\le\min(m,\tau)\le O(m)â‰¤min(m,Ï„)â‰¤O(m)

  • argâ¡maxâ¡\arg\maxargmax is O(âˆ£Mâ€²âˆ£)=O(m)O(|M'|)=O(m)O(âˆ£Mâ€²âˆ£)=O(m),

  • The rest part in the loop should be O(1)O(1)O(1).

    Thus total complexity should be O(m2)O(m^2)O(m2)

A Simple Universally Fair Algorithm

Draft and Eliminate Algorithm. It suffices to run only two rounds of the round-robin algorithm, once w.r.t. â„“\ellâ„“ and once w.r.t. reverse of â„“\ellâ„“. (WHY?) Finally it runs the envy-cycle elimination algorithm on the remaining instance.

Preprocessing

Preprocessing(N,M)(N,M)(N,M) step is facilitate the presentation and the analysis of the algorithm:

  1. L=âˆ…;A=N;k=1L=\empty;A=N;k=1L=âˆ…;A=N;k=1

    //LLL contains the agents that get to pick first in 1st round-robin at the expense of not choosing a second good in 2nd round-robin.

  2. while Aâ‰ âˆ…A\neq\emptyAî€ =âˆ… do

    • Let iii be the lexicographically first agent of AAA

    • hi=argâ¡maxâ¡gâˆˆMvi(g)h_i=\arg\max_{g\in M}v_i(g)hiâ€‹=argmaxgâˆˆMâ€‹viâ€‹(g)

    • ti=mâˆ’âˆ£Mâˆ£+1t_i=m-|M|+1tiâ€‹=mâˆ’âˆ£Mâˆ£+1

    • Let R=(Nâ•²(AâˆªL))âˆª{i}R=(N\diagdown(A\cup L))\cup\{i\}R=(Nâ•²(AâˆªL))âˆª{i}

    • j=argâ¡maxâ¡tâˆˆRvi(ht)j=\arg\max_{t\in R}v_i(h_t)j=argmaxtâˆˆRâ€‹viâ€‹(htâ€‹)

    • if Ï•â‹…vi(hi)<vi(hj)\phi\cdot v_i(h_i)\lt v_i(h_j)Ï•â‹…viâ€‹(hiâ€‹)<viâ€‹(hjâ€‹) then here: Ï•=5+12â‰ˆ1.618\phi=\frac{\sqrt5+1}{2}\approx1.618Ï•=25â€‹+1â€‹â‰ˆ1.618

      //If an agent envies someone that chose before her by a factor grater than Ï•\phiÏ•, then she is moved to a position of high priority in the ordering that is created.

      //The agents moved to the first positions during this process are guaranteed a good of high value in first round-robin. To counterbalance their advantage, they are not allowed to pick a second good later in second round-robin.

      • hi=hjh_i=h_jhiâ€‹=hjâ€‹
      • L=Lâˆª{i}L=L\cup\{i\}L=Lâˆª{i}
      • â„“[k]=i\ell[k]=iâ„“[k]=i
      • k=k+1k=k+1k=k+1
      • A=(Aâ•²{i})âˆª{j}A=(A\diagdown\{i\})\cup\{j\}A=(Aâ•²{i})âˆª{j}

    • else

      • A=Aâ•²{i}A=A\diagdown\{i\}A=Aâ•²{i}
      • M=Mâ•²{hi}M=M\diagdown\{h_i\}M=Mâ•²{hiâ€‹}

  3. for every iâˆˆNâ•²Li\in N\diagdown LiâˆˆNâ•²L in order of increasing time stamp tit_itiâ€‹ do

    • â„“[k]=i\ell[k]=iâ„“[k]=i
    • k=k+1k=k+1k=k+1

  4. return (â„“,[L])(\ell,[L])(â„“,[L])

â“ After preprocessing, have we AâˆªL=NA\cup L=NAâˆªL=N?

This preprocessing part reorders NNN so that the first few agents are quite happy with their pick in the first round of the round-robin subroutine. For the remaining agents, we make sure that they get a second good before we move to the envy-cycle elimination algorithm. To do so in a balanced way, these agents pick goods in reverse order.

The resulting partial allocation, where everyone receives one or two goods, turns out to have all the fairness properties we want to achieve at the end e.g. itâ€™s (Ï•âˆ’1)(\phi-1)(Ï•âˆ’1)-EFX w.r.t. currently allocated goods. Starting from there and then applying the envy-cycle elimination algorithm on the remaining instance maintains these properties.

Fairness Guarantees of Draft-and-Eliminate

About Preprocessing Step

â—ğŸ¤”Lemma 1: At the end of the execution of preprocessing with input (N,M)(N,M)(N,M), each agent iii is associated with a single good hih_ihiâ€‹, so that

a) vi(hi)>Ï•â‹…vi(g)v_i(h_i)\gt\phi\cdot v_i(g)viâ€‹(hiâ€‹)>Ï•â‹…viâ€‹(g), for any iâˆˆLi\in LiâˆˆL and gâˆˆMâ•²âˆªk=1n{hk}g\in M\diagdown\cup_{k=1}^n\{h_k\}gâˆˆMâ•²âˆªk=1nâ€‹{hkâ€‹}.

Fix some iâˆˆLi\in LiâˆˆL and consider the last iteration of the while loop where iii was the lexicographically first agent of AAA. During which iii was added to LLL.

The initial good associated with iii: hioldh_i^{old}hioldâ€‹ during this iteration.

The final good associated with iii: hih_ihiâ€‹.

âˆµ\becauseâˆµ iii was added to LLL eventually. âˆ´\thereforeâˆ´ condition â€œÏ•â‹…vi(hi)<vi(hj)\phi\cdot v_i(h_i)\lt v_i(h_j)Ï•â‹…viâ€‹(hiâ€‹)<viâ€‹(hjâ€‹)â€ was true, i.e.,

iiiâ€™s favorite good among the ones associated to an agent not in LLL, say hjh_jhjâ€‹, was more than Ï•\phiÏ• times more valuable than hioldh_i^{old}hioldâ€‹, we have vi(hj)>Ï•â‹…vi(hiold)â‰¥Ï•â‹…vi(g)v_i(h_j)\gt\phi\cdot v_i(h_i^{old})\ge\phi\cdot v_i(g)viâ€‹(hjâ€‹)>Ï•â‹…viâ€‹(hioldâ€‹)â‰¥Ï•â‹…viâ€‹(g) for any good ggg that was not associated to an agent at the time.

Number of unassociated goods during the execution only decreases, thus the last inequality also holds for any good ggg that was not associated to any agent till the end.

By hi=hjh_i=h_jhiâ€‹=hjâ€‹, we conclude that vi(hi)>Ï•â‹…vi(g)v_i(h_i)\gt\phi\cdot v_i(g)viâ€‹(hiâ€‹)>Ï•â‹…viâ€‹(g) âˆ€gâˆˆMâ•²âˆªk=1n{hk}\forall g\in M\diagdown\cup_{k=1}^n\{h_k\}âˆ€gâˆˆMâ•²âˆªk=1nâ€‹{hkâ€‹}.

b) Ï•â‹…vi(hi)â‰¥vi(hj)\phi\cdot v_i(h_i)\ge v_i(h_j)Ï•â‹…viâ€‹(hiâ€‹)â‰¥viâ€‹(hjâ€‹) for any i,jâˆˆNâ•²Li,j\in N\diagdown Li,jâˆˆNâ•²L.

Fix some i,jâˆˆNâ•²Li,j\in N\diagdown Li,jâˆˆNâ•²L. Note that both i,ji,ji,j may be considered multiple times during preprocessing, i.e., they may be removed and added back to AAA in several times.

Consider 2 cases:

  1. Last time iii was considered before last time jjj was considered (ti<tjt_i\lt t_jtiâ€‹<tjâ€‹ at the end)

the desire inequality is obvious as agent iii is associated with her favorite good among the available goods, hih_ihiâ€‹, before agent jjj, i.e., vi(hi)â‰¥vi(hj)v_i(h_i)\ge v_i(h_j)viâ€‹(hiâ€‹)â‰¥viâ€‹(hjâ€‹).

  1. Last time iii was considered after last time jjj was considered (ti>tjt_i\gt t_jtiâ€‹>tjâ€‹ at the end)

suppose that Ï•â‹…vi(hi)<vi(hj)\phi\cdot v_i(h_i)\lt v_i(h_j)Ï•â‹…viâ€‹(hiâ€‹)<viâ€‹(hjâ€‹). Then during the last iteration that iii was considered, the if statement is true and iii would be irrevocably added to LLL, which contradicts the choice of iii.

Q. E. D.

â—ğŸ¤”Lemma 2: The partial allocation produced in first round-robin is ({h1},{h2},â‹¯â€‰,{hn})\mathcal (\{h_1\},\{h_2\},\cdots,\{h_n\})({h1â€‹},{h2â€‹},â‹¯,{hnâ€‹}), where hih_ihiâ€‹s are in Lemma 1.

The preprocessing step can be combined with 1st round-robin!

Observation: â„“\ellâ„“ is used in first round-robin subroutine is not the same with the order that goods get assigned to agents during the preprocessing step, even when one takes into account that moving agents into LLL is similar to changing their order.

First, using induction, we show that agents in LLL get assigned to them the same goods they would if there were to choose first according to â„“\ellâ„“.

For agents in Nâ•²LN\diagdown LNâ•²L. First observe that, on termination, agents in Nâ•²LN\diagdown LNâ•²L all have distinct time stamp assigned in second round-robin.

By time stamp of agent iii, name the final value of tit_itiâ€‹. Now fix some iâˆˆNâ•²Li\in N\diagdown LiâˆˆNâ•²L.

  • In preprocessing, agent iii gets assigned her favorite good available if we exclude the goods assigned to some agents in LLL, and to all the agents in Nâ•²LN\diagdown LNâ•²L with time stamp less than tit_itiâ€‹.

  • In round-robin, agent iii receives her favorite good available if we exclude the goods allocated to all the agents in LLL, and to all the agents in Nâ•²LN\diagdown LNâ•²L with time stamp less than tit_itiâ€‹. However, in this scenario the extra agents from LLL that pick before iii choose goods that iii does not find attractive enough. Indeed those goods are available in the first scenario, yet iii does not prefer them to hih_ihiâ€‹.

    Therefore, in this scenario iii also picks hih_ihiâ€‹ and Ai={hi}A_i=\{h_i\}Aiâ€‹={hiâ€‹} after first round-robin.

ğŸ¤”Proposition: Draft-and-elimination returns an EF1 allocation.

By Theorem 2, it suffices to show that the partial allocation produced after second round-robin is EF1. Fix two distinct agents i,jâˆˆNi,j\in Ni,jâˆˆN. If jâˆˆLj\in LjâˆˆL, then Aj={hj}A_j=\{h_j\}Ajâ€‹={hjâ€‹}. Clearly, vi(Ai)â‰¥vi(Ajâ•²{hj})=0v_i(A_i)\ge v_i(A_j\diagdown\{h_j\})=0viâ€‹(Aiâ€‹)â‰¥viâ€‹(Ajâ€‹â•²{hjâ€‹})=0. On the other hand, if jâˆˆNâ•²Lj\in N\diagdown LjâˆˆNâ•²L, then Aj={hj,hjâ€²}A_j=\{h_j,h_j'\}Ajâ€‹={hjâ€‹,hjâ€²â€‹}. Since agent iii picked hih_ihiâ€‹ when hjâ€²h_j'hjâ€²â€‹ was still available, vi(hi)â‰¥vi(hjâ€²)v_i(h_i)\ge v_i(h_j')viâ€‹(hiâ€‹)â‰¥viâ€‹(hjâ€²â€‹). So we have vi(Ai)â‰¥vi(hi)â‰¥vi(Ajâ•²{hj})v_i(A_i)\ge v_i(h_i)\ge v_i(A_j\diagdown\{h_j\})viâ€‹(Aiâ€‹)â‰¥viâ€‹(hiâ€‹)â‰¥viâ€‹(Ajâ€‹â•²{hjâ€‹}).

Envy-freeness up to Any Good

â—ğŸ¤”Theorem 3: The allocation A\mathcal AA returned by Draft-and-elimination is a (Ï•âˆ’1)(\phi-1)(Ï•âˆ’1)-EFX allocation. âš ï¸

Consider the allocation A\mathcal AA returned by algorithm, and fix two distinct agents i,jâˆˆNi,j\in Ni,jâˆˆN. If âˆ£Ajâˆ£=1|A_j|=1âˆ£Ajâ€‹âˆ£=1, then clearly, vi(Ai)â‰¥maxâ¡gâˆˆAjvi(Ajâ•²{g})=0v_i(A_i)\ge\max_{g\in A_j}v_i(A_j\diagdown\{g\})=0viâ€‹(Aiâ€‹)â‰¥maxgâˆˆAjâ€‹â€‹viâ€‹(Ajâ€‹â•²{g})=0.

So assume that âˆ£Ajâˆ£â‰¥2|A_j|\ge2âˆ£Ajâ€‹âˆ£â‰¥2 and let hhh be the last good added to AjA_jAjâ€‹. At time this happened, AjA_jAjâ€‹ may belonged to an agent jâ€²j'jâ€² other than jjj. Finally, let Aiold,Ajâ€˜oldA_i^{old},A_{jâ€˜}^{old}Aioldâ€‹,Ajâ€˜oldâ€‹ be bundles of iii and jâ€²j'jâ€² respectively, right before hhh was allocated. (i.e. hâˆˆAjâ€²oldh\in A_{j'}^{old}hâˆˆAjâ€²oldâ€‹ at first)

Note that AioldA_i^{old}Aioldâ€‹ may not necessarily be a subset of AiA_iAiâ€‹ due to the possible swaps imposed by envy-cycle elimination. But part (b) of theorem 1 implies vi(Ai)â‰¥vi(Aiold)v_i(A_i)\ge v_i(A_i^{old})viâ€‹(Aiâ€‹)â‰¥viâ€‹(Aioldâ€‹).

We consider 4 cases, depending on whether iâˆˆLi\in LiâˆˆL and on the type of step during which hhh was added to Ajâ€²oldA_{j'}^{old}Ajâ€²oldâ€‹.

  1. iâˆˆLi\in LiâˆˆL and hhh added in second round-robin.

We have Aiold={hi}A_i^{old}=\{h_i\}Aioldâ€‹={hiâ€‹}, as well as jâ€²âˆˆNâ•²Lj'\in N\diagdown Ljâ€²âˆˆNâ•²L and Aj={hjâ€²,hjâ€²â€²}A_j=\{h_{j'},h'_{j'}\}Ajâ€‹={hjâ€²â€‹,hjâ€²â€²â€‹}. This immediately implies that vi(Aiold)â‰¥maxâ¡{vi(hjâ€²),vi(hjâ€²â€²)}v_i(A_i^{old})\ge\max\{v_i(h_{j'}),v_i(h'_{j'})\}viâ€‹(Aioldâ€‹)â‰¥max{viâ€‹(hjâ€²â€‹),viâ€‹(hjâ€²â€²â€‹)}. Thus vi(Ai)â‰¥maxâ¡gâˆˆAjvi(Ajâ•²{g})v_i(A_i)\ge\max_{g\in A_j}v_i(A_j\diagdown\{g\})viâ€‹(Aiâ€‹)â‰¥maxgâˆˆAjâ€‹â€‹viâ€‹(Ajâ€‹â•²{g}).

  1. iâˆˆLi\in LiâˆˆL and hhh added in envy-cycle elimination.

By the way that envy-cycle-elimination chooses who to give the next good to, we know that right before hhh was added, no one envied jâ€²j'jâ€². In particular, vi(Aiold)â‰¥vi(Ajâ€²old)v_i(A_i^{old})\ge v_i(A_{j'}^{old})viâ€‹(Aioldâ€‹)â‰¥viâ€‹(Ajâ€²oldâ€‹). We further have vi(Aiold)â‰¥vi(hi)>Ï•â‹…vi(h)v_i(A_i^{old})\ge v_i(h_i)\gt\phi\cdot v_i(h)viâ€‹(Aioldâ€‹)â‰¥viâ€‹(hiâ€‹)>Ï•â‹…viâ€‹(h), where the last inequality directly follows from part (a) of lemma 1. Putting everything together,

vi(Aj)=vi(Ajâ€²old)+vi(h)â‰¤(1+Ï•âˆ’1)vi(Aiold)â‰¤Ï•â‹…vi(Ai)â‡”vi(Ai)â‰¥(Ï•âˆ’1)â‹…vi(Aj) v_i(A_j)=v_i(A_{j'}^{old})+v_i(h)\le(1+\phi-1)v_i(A_i^{old})\le\phi\cdot v_i(A_i)\\ \Lrarr v_i(A_i)\ge(\phi-1)\cdot v_i(A_j)viâ€‹(Ajâ€‹)=viâ€‹(Ajâ€²oldâ€‹)+viâ€‹(h)â‰¤(1+Ï•âˆ’1)viâ€‹(Aioldâ€‹)â‰¤Ï•â‹…viâ€‹(Aiâ€‹)â‡”viâ€‹(Aiâ€‹)â‰¥(Ï•âˆ’1)â‹…viâ€‹(Ajâ€‹)

  1. iâˆˆÌ¸Li\not\in Liî€ âˆˆL and hhh added in second round-robin.

We have i,jâ€²âˆˆNâ•²Li,j'\in N\diagdown Li,jâ€²âˆˆNâ•²L and Aj={hjâ€²,hjâ€²â€²}A_j=\{h_{j'},h'_{j'}\}Ajâ€‹={hjâ€²â€‹,hjâ€²â€²â€‹}. If â„“[i]<â„“[jâ€²]\ell[i]\lt\ell[j']â„“[i]<â„“[jâ€²], then we proceed in a way similar to case 1:

vi(Ai)â‰¥vi(Aiold)â‰¥vi(hi)â‰¥maxâ¡{vi(hjâ€²),vi(hjâ€²â€²)}. v_i(A_i)\ge v_i(A_i^{old})\ge v_i(h_i)\ge\max\{v_i(h_{j'}),v_i(h'_{j'})\}.viâ€‹(Aiâ€‹)â‰¥viâ€‹(Aioldâ€‹)â‰¥viâ€‹(hiâ€‹)â‰¥max{viâ€‹(hjâ€²â€‹),viâ€‹(hjâ€²â€²â€‹)}.

So, assume that â„“[i]>â„“[jâ€²]\ell[i]\gt\ell[j']â„“[i]>â„“[jâ€²]. This means vi(hiâ€²)â‰¥vi(hjâ€²â€²)v_i(h_i')\ge v_i(h_{j'}')viâ€‹(hiâ€²â€‹)â‰¥viâ€‹(hjâ€²â€²â€‹). We have

vi(Ai)â‰¥vi(Aiold)â‰¥vi(hi)+vi(hiâ€²)â‰¥1Ï•vi(hjâ€²)+vi(hjâ€²â€²)â‰¥1Ï•(Vi(hjâ€²)+vi(hjâ€²â€²))=(Ï•âˆ’1)vi(Aj) v_i(A_i)\ge v_i(A_i^{old})\ge v_i(h_i)+v_i(h_i')\ge{1\over\phi}v_i(h_{j'})+v_i(h'_{j'})\\ \ge{1\over\phi}(V_i(h_{j'})+v_i(h'_{j'}))=(\phi-1)v_i(A_j)viâ€‹(Aiâ€‹)â‰¥viâ€‹(Aioldâ€‹)â‰¥viâ€‹(hiâ€‹)+viâ€‹(hiâ€²â€‹)â‰¥Ï•1â€‹viâ€‹(hjâ€²â€‹)+viâ€‹(hjâ€²â€²â€‹)â‰¥Ï•1â€‹(Viâ€‹(hjâ€²â€‹)+viâ€‹(hjâ€²â€²â€‹))=(Ï•âˆ’1)viâ€‹(Ajâ€‹)

where the third inequality directly follows from part (b) from lemma 1.

  1. iâˆˆÌ¸Li\not\in Liî€ âˆˆL and hhh added in envy-cycle elimination.

Arguing like in case 2, we have vi(Aiold)â‰¥vi(Ajâ€²old)v_i(A_i^{old})\ge v_i(A_{j'}^{old})viâ€‹(Aioldâ€‹)â‰¥viâ€‹(Ajâ€²oldâ€‹). Moreover, by the way round-robin works, we know that vi(hi)â‰¥vi(hiâ€²)â‰¥vi(h)v_i(h_i)\ge v_i(h'_i)\ge v_i(h)viâ€‹(hiâ€‹)â‰¥viâ€‹(hiâ€²â€‹)â‰¥viâ€‹(h). In particular, vi(h)â‰¤12vi({hi,hiâ€²})â‰¤12vi(Aiold)v_i(h)\le{1\over2}v_i(\{h_i,h_i'\})\le{1\over2}v_i(A_i^{old})viâ€‹(h)â‰¤21â€‹viâ€‹({hiâ€‹,hiâ€²â€‹})â‰¤21â€‹viâ€‹(Aioldâ€‹). Putting things together, we have

vi(Aj)=vi(Ajâ€²old)+vi(h)â‰¤(1+12)vi(Aiold)â‰¤Ï•â‹…vi(Ai)â‡”vi(Ai)â‰¥(Ï•âˆ’1)vi(Aj) v_i(A_j)=v_i(A_{j'}^{old})+v_i(h)\le(1+\frac{1}{2})v_i(A_i^{old})\le\phi\cdot v_i(A_i)\\ \Lrarr v_i(A_i)\ge(\phi-1)v_i(A_j)viâ€‹(Ajâ€‹)=viâ€‹(Ajâ€²oldâ€‹)+viâ€‹(h)â‰¤(1+21â€‹)viâ€‹(Aioldâ€‹)â‰¤Ï•â‹…viâ€‹(Aiâ€‹)â‡”viâ€‹(Aiâ€‹)â‰¥(Ï•âˆ’1)viâ€‹(Ajâ€‹)

The analysis is tight.

Groupwise Maximin Share Fairness

Every exact EFX allocation is also a 474\over774â€‹-GMMS allocation. (Amanatidis et al.)

â—ğŸ¤”Lemma 3: Suppose TâˆˆÎ n(M)\mathcal T\in\Pi_n(M)TâˆˆÎ nâ€‹(M) is an nnn-maximin share defining partition for agent iii. Then, for any set of goods SSS, such that there exists some jjj with SâŠ†TjS\subseteq T_jSâŠ†Tjâ€‹, it holds that Î¼i(nâˆ’1,Mâ•²S)â‰¥Î¼i(n,M)\mu_i(n-1,M\diagdown S)\ge\mu_i(n,M)Î¼iâ€‹(nâˆ’1,Mâ•²S)â‰¥Î¼iâ€‹(n,M).

â—ğŸ¤”Theorem 4: The allocation A=(A1,â‹¯â€‰,An)\mathcal A=(A_1,\cdots,A_n)A=(A1â€‹,â‹¯,Anâ€‹) returned by Draft and Eliminate Algorithm is a 2Ï•+22\over\phi+2Ï•+22â€‹-GMMS allocation.

To difficult for me! ğŸ˜­

Omitted

â—ğŸ¤” Theorem 5: Suppose we modified Draft and Eliminate Algorithm by changing Ï•\phiÏ• in preprocessing to 323\over223â€‹. Then the resulting allocation is a 4/74/74/7-GMMS allocation. It is also a 3/53/53/5-EFX, 2/32/32/3-PMMS, and EF1 allocation.

To difficult for me! ğŸ˜­

Omitted

Analysis are probably not tight, because both theorems is heavily based on EF and EFX guarantees we get in the various different cases.

â“Suspect: modified draft and eliminate algorithm produces 2/32/32/3-GMMS.

Pairwise Maximin Share Fairness

â—ğŸ¤”Theorem 6: The allocation A=(A1,â‹¯â€‰,An)\mathcal A=(A_1,\cdots,A_n)A=(A1â€‹,â‹¯,Anâ€‹) returned by Draft and Eliminate Algorithm is a 2/32/32/3-PMMS allocation.

Proof based on proof of theorem 3.

2/32/32/3 factor is tight. But if we manipulate envy-graph as following, the approximation ratio goes up to 2Ï•+1â‰ˆ0.764{2\over\phi+1}\approx0.764Ï•+12â€‹â‰ˆ0.764: Detail omitted

â—ğŸ¤”Theorem 7: Supposed we modified Draft and Eliminate Algorithm by using the Ï•âˆ’12\phi-{1\over2}Ï•âˆ’21â€‹-adjusted envy graph in Envy-graph Elimination. Then the resulting allocation is a 4Ï•âˆ’22Ï•+34\phi-2\over2\phi+32Ï•+34Ï•âˆ’2â€‹-PMMS and a 22Ï•âˆ’12\over2\phi-12Ï•âˆ’12â€‹-EF1 allocation. Moreover, the theorem 3 and theorem 4 are not affected.

Proof omitted.

GMMS, PMMS, and EFX with a few Goods

For the exact versions of fairness notions,

Draft Pack and Eliminate Pseudo Code

  1. Let â„“=(1,2,â‹¯â€‰,n)\ell=(1,2,\cdots,n)â„“=(1,2,â‹¯,n) and A=(âˆ…,â‹¯â€‰,âˆ…)\mathcal A=(\empty,\cdots,\empty)A=(âˆ…,â‹¯,âˆ…)
  2. (A,Mâ€²)=(\mathcal A,M')=(A,Mâ€²)= Round-Robin(N,A,M,â„“,nâˆ’1)(N,\mathcal A,M,\ell,n-1)(N,A,M,â„“,nâˆ’1)
  3. Create 2 virtual goods p,qp,qp,q, s.t. âˆ€iâˆˆN:vi(q)=minâ¡gâˆˆMâ€²\forall i\in N:v_i(q)=\min_{g\in M'}âˆ€iâˆˆN:viâ€‹(q)=mingâˆˆMâ€²â€‹ and vi(p)=vi(Mâ€²)âˆ’vi(q)v_i(p)=v_i(M')-v_i(q)viâ€‹(p)=viâ€‹(Mâ€²)âˆ’viâ€‹(q)
  4. Allocate ppp to agent nnn
  5. A=\mathcal A=A= Envy-Cycle Elimination(N,A,{q})(N,\mathcal A,\{q\})(N,A,{q})
  6. Give to the final owner of ppp her two favorite goods from Mâ€²M'Mâ€² and to the final owner of qqq the remaining good
  7. return A\mathcal AA.

â—ğŸ¤”Theorem 8: For instances with mâ‰¤n+2m\le n+2mâ‰¤n+2, a GMMS allocation always exists and can be efficiently computed.

When mâ‰¤nm\le nmâ‰¤n, we arbitrarily allocate one good to each agent, till there are no goods left, to produce A=(A1,â‹¯â€‰,An)\mathcal A=(A_1,\cdots,A_n)A=(A1â€‹,â‹¯,Anâ€‹). Fix a subset SSS of agents, and let iâˆˆNi\in NiâˆˆN. Then combined bundle of all agents in SSS either contains strictly less than âˆ£Sâˆ£|S|âˆ£Sâˆ£ goods or exactly âˆ£Sâˆ£|S|âˆ£Sâˆ£ goods.

  • In the first case, we trivially have Î¼i(âˆ£Sâˆ£,âˆªjâˆˆSAj)=0\mu_i(|S|,\cup_{j\in S}A_j)=0Î¼iâ€‹(âˆ£Sâˆ£,âˆªjâˆˆSâ€‹Ajâ€‹)=0.

  • In the second case, we have Î¼i(âˆ£Sâˆ£,âˆªjâˆˆSAj)=minâ¡gâˆˆâˆªjâˆˆSAjvi(g)\mu_i(|S|,\cup_{j\in S}A_j)=\min_{g\in\cup_{j\in S}A_j}v_i(g)Î¼iâ€‹(âˆ£Sâˆ£,âˆªjâˆˆSâ€‹Ajâ€‹)=mingâˆˆâˆªjâˆˆSâ€‹Ajâ€‹â€‹viâ€‹(g).

In both cases, we have vi(Ai)â‰¥Î¼i(âˆ£Sâˆ£,âˆªjâˆˆSAj)v_i(A_i)\ge\mu_i(|S|,\cup_{j\in S}A_j)viâ€‹(Aiâ€‹)â‰¥Î¼iâ€‹(âˆ£Sâˆ£,âˆªjâˆˆSâ€‹Ajâ€‹), and A\mathcal AA is a GMMS allocation.

For m>nm\gt nm>n, there are some simple observations.

â—ğŸ¤”Lemma 4: Let QâŠ†NQ\subseteq NQâŠ†N and TâŠ†MT\subseteq MTâŠ†M s.t. âˆ£Tâˆ£=2âˆ£Qâˆ£âˆ’1|T|=2|Q|-1âˆ£Tâˆ£=2âˆ£Qâˆ£âˆ’1. Then, for any iâˆˆQi\in QiâˆˆQ, we have maxâ¡gâˆˆTvi(g)â‰¥Î¼i(âˆ£Qâˆ£,T)\max_{g\in T}v_i(g)\ge\mu_i(|Q|,T)maxgâˆˆTâ€‹viâ€‹(g)â‰¥Î¼iâ€‹(âˆ£Qâˆ£,T).

By the pigeonhole principle, in any possible partition of TTT in âˆ£Qâˆ£|Q|âˆ£Qâˆ£ parts, at least one bundle will have at most 111 goods. So, in any âˆ£Qâˆ£|Q|âˆ£Qâˆ£-maximin share partition of TTT for an agent iâˆˆQi\in QiâˆˆQ, her worst bundleâ€™s worth is upper bounded by maxâ¡gâˆˆTvi(g)\max_{g\in T}v_i(g)maxgâˆˆTâ€‹viâ€‹(g).

â—ğŸ¤”Lemma 5: Let iâˆˆNi\in NiâˆˆN and T={g1,g2,g3,g4}âŠ†MT=\{g_1,g_2,g_3,g_4\}\subseteq MT={g1â€‹,g2â€‹,g3â€‹,g4â€‹}âŠ†M s.t. vi(g1)â‰¥vi(g2)â‰¥vi(g3)â‰¥vi(g4)v_i(g_1)\ge v_i(g_2)\ge v_i(g_3)\ge v_i(g_4)viâ€‹(g1â€‹)â‰¥viâ€‹(g2â€‹)â‰¥viâ€‹(g3â€‹)â‰¥viâ€‹(g4â€‹). Then

  1. vi({g1,g4})â‰¥Î¼i(2,T)v_i(\{g_1,g_4\})\ge\mu_i(2,T)viâ€‹({g1â€‹,g4â€‹})â‰¥Î¼iâ€‹(2,T)
  2. maxâ¡{vi(g1),vi({g2,g3})}â‰¥Î¼i(2,T)\max\{v_i(g_1),v_i(\{g_2,g_3\})\}\ge\mu_i(2,T)max{viâ€‹(g1â€‹),viâ€‹({g2â€‹,g3â€‹})}â‰¥Î¼iâ€‹(2,T)

Long proofâ€¦

Corollary: When mâ‰¤n+2m\le n+2mâ‰¤n+2, we can efficiently find PMMS and EFX allocations.

Proof omittedâ€¦

What should I get from this paper?

EF1â‡\Larrâ‡EFXâ‡\Larrâ‡PMMS, GMMS

EF1: Always exist.

EFX: 0.6180.6180.618

PMMS: 2/32/32/3

GMMS: Not always exist.

We are trying to relax the properties as less as possible so that a single allocation satisfies all relaxation, and if possible, with allocation computed is polynomial time.
