entry.title: æ•°æ®æŒ–æ˜ 3 Densiy-based Clustering
entry.content:
Density-based departs from the rigid geometrical structure of representative-based clustering and defines cluster as high-density regions separated by low density regions.

Density is number of points in a certain region in proportion to the size of the region. Different definition of density, different density-based approaches.

DBSCAN

A density-based clustering algorithm grounded into the intuition that a point in a cluster should be density reachable from any other point in that cluster, i.e., there should be â€œenoughâ€ points around each point in a cluster.

This standard does not include any specific on the shape of the cluster, but only constrains the neighborhood of a point. Thus, DBSCAN can handle clusters with arbitrary shape.

Definitions

Neighborhood: For each point x\mathbf xx, we define the neighborhood the set of points that are at distance at most Ïµ\epsilonÏµ from x\mathbf xx, formally NÏµ(x)={yâˆˆDâˆ£dist(x,y)â‰¤Ïµ}N_\epsilon(\mathbf x)=\{\mathbf y\in\mathcal D|dist(\mathbf x,\mathbf y)\le\epsilon\}NÏµâ€‹(x)={yâˆˆDâˆ£dist(x,y)â‰¤Ïµ}.

Additionally, a neighborhood is dense if it contains at least MinPtsMinPtsMinPts points, i.e., âˆ£NÏµ(x)âˆ£â‰¥MinPts|N_\epsilon(\mathbf x)|\ge MinPtsâˆ£NÏµâ€‹(x)âˆ£â‰¥MinPts.

Core object: A point x\mathbf xx whose neighborhood contains at least MinPtsMinPtsMinPts points.

Density-reachable: y\mathbf yy is directly density-reachable from x\mathbf xx within Ïµ,MinPts\epsilon,MinPtsÏµ,MinPts, if yâˆˆNÏµ(x)\mathbf y\in N_\epsilon(\mathbf x)yâˆˆNÏµâ€‹(x), and x\mathbf xx is a core-object.

A point p\mathbf pp is density reachable from x\mathbf xx if p\mathbf pp is directly density reachable from a point y\mathbf yy in the neighborhood NÏµ(x)N_\epsilon(\mathbf x)NÏµâ€‹(x). Density reachability is the transitive closure of directly density reachability. Note that the density reachability is not symmetric. In particular, since p\mathbf pp might not have MinPtsMinPtsMinPts in its neighborhood, it cannot â€œreachâ€ x\mathbf xx with a sequence of dense areas.

Density-connected: x\mathbf xx is density-connected to a point y\mathbf yy if there is a point p\mathbf pp such that both x\mathbf xx and y\mathbf yy are density-reachable from p\mathbf pp.

x\mathbf xx and y\mathbf yy are not necessarily density-reachable in this case.

Density-based cluster: a non-empty subset SâŠ†DS\subseteq\mathcal DSâŠ†D of the data D\mathcal DD that satisfies both

  • Maximality: If a point xâˆˆS\mathbf x\in SxâˆˆS and y\mathbf yy is density-reachable from x\mathbf xx, then yâˆˆS\mathbf y\in SyâˆˆS.
  • Connectivity: Each object in SSS is density-connected to all other objects.

A density-based clustering of a database D\mathcal DD is a partition {C1,â‹¯â€‰,Ck;N}\{C_1,\cdots,C_k;N\}{C1â€‹,â‹¯,Ckâ€‹;N} s.t. â‹ƒi=1kCiâˆªN=D\bigcup_{i=1}^kC_i\cup N=\mathcal Dâ‹ƒi=1kâ€‹Ciâ€‹âˆªN=D, Ciâˆ©Cj=âˆ…,j>i,i,jâˆˆ[1,k]C_i\cap C_j=\empty,j\gt i,i,j\in[1,k]Ciâ€‹âˆ©Cjâ€‹=âˆ…,j>i,i,jâˆˆ[1,k], and Ciâˆ©N=âˆ…C_i\cap N=\emptyCiâ€‹âˆ©N=âˆ…, where C1,â‹¯â€‰,CkC_1,\cdots,C_kC1â€‹,â‹¯,Ckâ€‹ are the density-based clusters. N=Dâ•²{C1,â‹¯â€‰,Ck}N=\mathcal D\diagdown\{C_1,\cdots,C_k\}N=Dâ•²{C1â€‹,â‹¯,Ckâ€‹} is the noise cluster of objects that do not belong to any cluster.

DBSCAN Algorithm

Pseudo code

Input: dataset D,Ïµ,MinPts\mathcal D,\epsilon,MinPtsD,Ïµ,MinPts

  • for each xâˆˆD\mathbf x\in \mathcal DxâˆˆD, do

    • if x\mathbf xx is not part of any cluster CCC then

      • if x\mathbf xx is a core project then

        Câ†C\larrCâ† Compute the density-reachable points from x\mathbf xx

        Create a new cluster CCC.

      • else

        Nâ†Nâˆª{x}N\larr N\cup\{x\}Nâ†Nâˆª{x}

The main theoretical idea behind the DBSCAN algorithm is that each object in a density-based cluster CCC is density-reachable from any of its core objects and nothing else is reachable from the core objects.

The DBSCAN is complete and ensures the two properties of maximality and connectivity. The DBSCAN algorithm is a simple iteration around the objects in the database, starting from a random point and finding all reachable points.

Density-reachable objects are collected by performing successive Ïµ\epsilonÏµ-neighborhood queries that find the points at distance Ïµ\epsilonÏµ from another point.

Complexity Analysis

When dimensionality is high, DBSCAN runs in O(n2)\mathcal O(n^2)O(n2). By using specialized indexes for spatial queries, e.g., Râˆ—R^*Râˆ— trees, DBSCAN can run faster than CLARANS that as a runtime complexity of O(k3+nk)\mathcal O(k^3+nk)O(k3+nk).

NÏµN_\epsilonNÏµâ€‹-queryDBSCAN
Without support (worst case)O(n)\mathcal O(n)O(n)O(n2)\mathcal O(n^2)O(n2)
Tree based support (e.g. Râˆ—R^*Râˆ—)O(logâ¡n)\mathcal O(\log n)O(logn)O(nlogâ¡n)\mathcal O(n\log n)O(nlogn)
Direct access to the neighborhoodO(1)\mathcal O(1)O(1)O(n)\mathcal O(n)O(n)

Tuning Ïµ\epsilonÏµ and MinPtsMinPtsMinPts

Before using DBSCAN, we need to decide on parameters Ïµ\epsilonÏµ and MinPtsMinPtsMinPts. This choice determines the shape and the number of clusters; low Ïµ\epsilonÏµ or high MinPtsMinPtsMinPts would find too many small clusters, a high Ïµ\epsilonÏµ might trivially terminate with a single cluster containing the entire dataset.

To find good Ïµ\epsilonÏµ and MinPtsMinPtsMinPts, there are some heuristics. For example, one could use the point density of the least dense cluster to determine the parameters. One common heuristic uses the distance from kkk-nearest neighbors.

  • kdist(x)kdist(\mathbf x)kdist(x) is the distance from x\mathbf xx to its kkk-nearest neighbor
  • kdistkdistkdist plot is a chart of the kkk-distances of all points, sorted in decreasing order of distance.

The heuristic works as follows

  • Fix a value for MinPtsMinPtsMinPts. If there is no domain knowledge available, a common choice is 2dâˆ’12d-12dâˆ’1 where ddd is the dimension.
  • Select a â€œborder objectâ€ x\mathbf xx from the MinPtsMinPtsMinPts distance polt, Ïµ\epsilonÏµ is set to MinPtsdist(x)MinPtsdist(\mathbf x)MinPtsdist(x)

Pros and Cons

ğŸ‘ Advantages:

  1. Does not require to specify number of clusters.
  2. Performs well with clusters of arbitrary shape.
  3. DBSCAN is robust to outlier and is able to handle them.

ğŸ‘Disadvantages:

  1. It requires domain knowledge for MinPtsMinPtsMinPts and it is not easy to determine Ïµ\epsilonÏµ.
  2. If clusters are very different in terms of in-cluster densities, then DBSCAN is not well suited to define clusters as it cannot generalize well to clusters with very different densities.

DENCLUE

DENCLUE detects dense regions without specifically specifying the size of the neighborhood.

Main idea: a generalization of neighborhood density in terms of density distribution.

Density Estimation

To estimate an unknown density function in a dataset.

â€œNon-parametricâ€

Density estimation:

  • determines an unknown probability density function
  • it is non-parametric and does not assume a fixed probability model
  • estimates the probability density at each point

Univariate density estimation

In one dimension, we can model the data as a random variable XXX.

Unidimensional data points can be treated as nnn samples or observations {xi}\{x_i\}{xiâ€‹} from such a random variable.

We can estimate the cumulative density function CDF by counting the number of points less than a certain value vvv

F^(v)=1nâˆ‘i=1nI(xiâ‰¤v)\hat F(v)=\frac{1}{n}\sum_{i=1}^nI(x_i\le v)F^(v)=n1â€‹i=1âˆ‘nâ€‹I(xiâ€‹â‰¤v)

where III is the indicator functions. which is 111 if the conditions inside the (â‹…)(\cdot)(â‹…) is satisfied and 000 otherwise.

The density function is then estimated by taking the derivative of the CDF

f^(x)=F^(x+h2)âˆ’F^(xâˆ’h2)h=k/nh=knh\hat f(x)=\frac{\hat F(x+{h\over2})-\hat F(x-{h\over2})}{h}={k/n\over h}={k\over nh}f^â€‹(x)=hF^(x+2hâ€‹)âˆ’F^(xâˆ’2hâ€‹)â€‹=hk/nâ€‹=nhkâ€‹

where kkk is the number of points in a window of width hhh centered on xxx. The density estimate is ratio of points in the window (k/n)(k/n)(k/n) to the volume of the window hhh.

Kernel density estimation: We need to be careful on the window size hhh. We define a kernel function KKK that is a probability density function: âš ï¸Donâ€™t mess up with kernel in k-means

  • non-negative K(x)â‰¥0K(x)\ge0K(x)â‰¥0
  • symmetric K(âˆ’x)=K(x)K(-x)=K(x)K(âˆ’x)=K(x)
  • integrates to 111, i.e., âˆ«K(x)dx=1\int K(x)dx=1âˆ«K(x)dx=1.

The discrete kernel is the simplest kernel and it corresponds to a degenerate uniform probability density function

K(z)={1Â ifÂ âˆ£zâˆ£â‰¤120Â otherwiseK(z)=\begin{cases}1\text{ if }|z|\le{1\over2}\\0\text{ otherwise}\end{cases}K(z)={1Â ifÂ âˆ£zâˆ£â‰¤21â€‹0Â otherwiseâ€‹

when âˆ£zâˆ£=xâˆ’xihâ‰¤12|z|=\frac{x-x_i}{h}\le{1\over2}âˆ£zâˆ£=hxâˆ’xiâ€‹â€‹â‰¤21â€‹, the point xix_ixiâ€‹ is inside a window of size hhh centered at point xxx. We can then rewrite the density estimator as

f^(x)=1nhâˆ‘i=1nK(xâˆ’xih)\hat f(x)=\frac{1}{nh}\sum_{i=1}^nK({x-x_i\over h})f^â€‹(x)=nh1â€‹i=1âˆ‘nâ€‹K(hxâˆ’xiâ€‹â€‹)

The discrete kernel is not smooth, meaning that the kernel estimate looks again like a histogram with the consequence that many useful calculus operator cannot be comfortably performed.

Gaussian kernel: Kernel used in DENCLUE. The Gaussian kernel is one of the most popular kernels and represents a Gaussian distribution centered around a point.

K(z)=12Ï€expâ¡(âˆ’z22).K(z)=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2\pi}}\exp(-{z^2\over2}).K(z)=2Ï€â€‹1â€‹exp(âˆ’2z2â€‹).

As usual, by z=xâˆ’xihz={x-x_i\over h}z=hxâˆ’xiâ€‹â€‹ we obtain

K(xâˆ’xih)=12Ï€expâ¡(âˆ’(xâˆ’xi)22h2)K({x-x_i\over h})=\frac{1}{\sqrt{2\pi}}\exp(-{(x-x_i)^2\over2h^2})K(hxâˆ’xiâ€‹â€‹)=2Ï€â€‹1â€‹exp(âˆ’2h2(xâˆ’xiâ€‹)2â€‹)

where xxx at the center of the window plays the role of the mean, and the window size hhh becomes standard deviation.

Multivariate density estimation

For ddd-dimensional data x=(x1,â‹¯â€‰,xd)\mathbf x=(x_1,\cdots,x_d)x=(x1â€‹,â‹¯,xdâ€‹), the window hhh becomes a hypercube centered at xxx with volume hhh, that is vol(Hd(h))=hdvol(H_d(h))=h^dvol(Hdâ€‹(h))=hd. Density estimation is the same:

f^(x)=1nhdâˆ‘i=1nK(xâˆ’xih)\hat f(x)=\frac{1}{nh^d}\sum_{i=1}^nK({x-x_i\over h})f^â€‹(x)=nhd1â€‹i=1âˆ‘nâ€‹K(hxâˆ’xiâ€‹â€‹)

where the multivariate kernel must preserve non-negativity, symmetry, and integrate to 1. It is then straightforward to redefine the discrete and Gaussian kernels.

Discrete multivariate kernel Similar to univariate counterpart, the multivariate kernel is

K(z)={1Â ifÂ âˆ£zâˆ£â‰¤12Â forÂ allÂ dimensions0Â otherwiseK(z)=\begin{cases}1\text{ if }|z|\le{1\over2}\text{ for all dimensions}\\0\text{ otherwise}\end{cases}K(z)={1Â ifÂ âˆ£zâˆ£â‰¤21â€‹Â forÂ allÂ dimensions0Â otherwiseâ€‹

The Gaussian kernel uses a equi-variate covariance matrix which translates into using the identity matrix Î£=I\Sigma=\mathbf IÎ£=I

K(z)=1(2Ï€)d2expâ¡(âˆ’zTz2)K(\mathbf z)=\frac{1}{(2\pi)^{d\over2}}\exp(-{\mathbf z^T\mathbf z\over2})K(z)=(2Ï€)2dâ€‹1â€‹exp(âˆ’2zTzâ€‹)

Nearest neighbor estimation

Instead of fixing the size hhh of the region, the nearest neighbor estimate fixes the number of points kkk in the neighborhood of a point x\mathbf xx and finds the size of the region.

KNN proceeds:

  1. Fix kkk, the minimum number of points that defines a dense region.
  2. Compute the volume vol(Sd(hx))vol(S_d(h_\mathbf x))vol(Sdâ€‹(hxâ€‹)) as a function of kkk.

Given kkk, we estimate density at x\mathbf xx as

f^(x)=knâ‹…vol(Sd(hx))\hat f(\mathbf x)={k\over n\cdot vol(S_d(h_\mathbf x))}f^â€‹(x)=nâ‹…vol(Sdâ€‹(hxâ€‹))kâ€‹

where hxh_\mathbf xhxâ€‹ is the distance from x\mathbf xx to its kkk-nearest neighbor. The volume is the volume of the ddd-dimensional hypersphere centered at x\mathbf xx.

Density Attractors

How can we find dense clusters?

Look at the density function and set a threshold Î¾\xiÎ¾ i.e. a horizontal line in a density points histogram. However, if so, some points in low-density regions might not be assigned to any cluster.

Density attractor: A point xâˆ—\mathbf x^*xâˆ— is a density attractor if it is a local maxima of the probability density function fff.

In order to discover these peaks in the density function, we need to compute its gradient.

\nabla\hat f(\mathbf x)={\part\over\part\mathbf x}\hat f(\mathbf x)={1\over nh^d}\sum_{i=1}^n{\part\over\part\mathbf x}K({\mathbf x-\mathbf x_i\over h})

For the Gaussian kernel, the gradient takes a particularly neat form

{\part\over\part\mathbf x}K({\mathbf x-\mathbf x_i\over h})=K({\mathbf x-\mathbf x_i\over h})\cdot({\mathbf x-\mathbf x_i\over h})\cdot({1\over h})

which yields

âˆ‡f^(x)=1nhd+2âˆ‘i=1nK(xâˆ’xih)â‹…(xiâˆ’x)\nabla\hat f(\mathbf x)={1\over nh^{d+2}}\sum_{i=1}^nK({\mathbf x-\mathbf x_i\over h})\cdot(\mathbf x_i-\mathbf x)âˆ‡f^â€‹(x)=nhd+21â€‹i=1âˆ‘nâ€‹K(hxâˆ’xiâ€‹â€‹)â‹…(xiâ€‹âˆ’x)

Density-based cluster: A set of CCC of data points from a data set D\mathcal DD is a density-based cluster w.r.t. some threshold Î¾\xiÎ¾ if there exist a set of attractors x1âˆ—,â‹¯â€‰,xkâˆ—\mathbf x_1^*,\cdots,\mathbf x_k^*x1âˆ—â€‹,â‹¯,xkâˆ—â€‹ if

  • Each point x\mathbf xx in CCC attracted to some attractor xiâˆ—\mathbf x_i^*xiâˆ—â€‹.
  • Each density attractor xiâˆ—\mathbf x_i^*xiâˆ—â€‹ exceeds some density threshold Î¾\xiÎ¾, i.e., f^(xiâˆ—)â‰¥Î¾\hat f(\mathbf x_i^*)\ge\xif^â€‹(xiâˆ—â€‹)â‰¥Î¾.
  • Any two density attractors xiâˆ—,xjâˆ—\mathbf x_i^*,\mathbf x_j^*xiâˆ—â€‹,xjâˆ—â€‹ are density reachable. That is, there exists a path from xiâˆ—\mathbf x_i^*xiâˆ—â€‹ to xjâˆ—\mathbf x_j^*xjâˆ—â€‹ such that for all points y\mathbf yy on the path, f^(y)â‰¥Î¾\hat f(\mathbf y)\ge\xif^â€‹(y)â‰¥Î¾.

Not all points will be part of a cluster. We treat them as noise.

The DENCLUE algorithm: For each point in the data, it finds a candidate attractor. If the attractorâ€™s density is above the threshold Î¾\xiÎ¾, it is added to the set AAA of attractors and the point is added to the set RRR of points attracted by xâˆ—\mathbf x^*xâˆ—. Then all the maximal sets of mutually density reachable attractors computed.

To find an attractor for a point x\mathbf xx we can solve âˆ‡f^(x)=0\nabla\hat f(\mathbf x)=0âˆ‡f^â€‹(x)=0, thus

1nhd+2âˆ‘i=1nK(xâˆ’xih)â‹…(xiâˆ’x)=0â‡’x=âˆ‘i=1nK(xâˆ’xih)xiâˆ‘i=1nK(xâˆ’xih){1\over nh^{d+2}}\sum_{i=1}^nK({\mathbf x-\mathbf x_i\over h})\cdot(\mathbf x_i-\mathbf x)=0\\\Rarr\mathbf x=\frac{\sum_{i=1}^nK({\mathbf x-\mathbf x_i\over h})\mathbf x_i}{\sum_{i=1}^nK({\mathbf x-\mathbf x_i\over h})}nhd+21â€‹i=1âˆ‘nâ€‹K(hxâˆ’xiâ€‹â€‹)â‹…(xiâ€‹âˆ’x)=0â‡’x=âˆ‘i=1nâ€‹K(hxâˆ’xiâ€‹â€‹)âˆ‘i=1nâ€‹K(hxâˆ’xiâ€‹â€‹)xiâ€‹â€‹

We can use it as iterative rule until convergence. The algorithm runs in O(n2T)\mathcal O(n^2T)O(n2T) where TTT is the number of iterations.

DENCLUE vs DBSCAN

DBSCAN corresponds to a discrete kernel, more efficient bit more rough. Ïµ,MinPts\epsilon,MinPtsÏµ,MinPts corresponds h,Î¾h,\xih,Î¾.

DENCLUE uses Gaussian kernel density based attractors, which is smooth model and more able to capture underlying data distribution than DBSCAN.

Pros and Cons

ğŸ‘ Advantages

  • Clusters can arbitrary shape and size, not necessarily be convex hull.
  • Number of clusters is determined automatically.
  • Can separate clusters from surrounding noise.
  • Can be supported by spatial index structures.

ğŸ‘Disadvantages

  • Input parameters may be difficult to determine
  • Can be sensitive to input parameter setting

Clustering Evaluation

External Measures

Take criteria into account that are not part of the clustering data.

Contingency Table

A rÃ—kr\times krÃ—k matrix N\mathbf NN s.t. (cluster CCC, ground-truth clustering TTT)

Nij=âˆ£Ciâˆ©Tjâˆ£\mathbf N_{ij}=|C_i\cap T_j|Nijâ€‹=âˆ£Ciâ€‹âˆ©Tjâ€‹âˆ£

Computing the contingency table takes O(nrk)\mathcal O(nrk)O(nrk)

Purity

To what extent a cluster CiC_iCiâ€‹ contains points only from one ground truth cluster.

purityi=1âˆ£Ciâˆ£maxâ¡j=1,â‹¯â€‰,k{nij}\text{purity}_i=\frac{1}{|C_i|}\max_{j=1,\cdots,k}\{n_{ij}\}purityiâ€‹=âˆ£Ciâ€‹âˆ£1â€‹j=1,â‹¯,kmaxâ€‹{nijâ€‹}

The purity of a clustering is the weighted sum of the purity of each cluster.

purity=âˆ‘ipurityi\text{purity}=\sum_i\text{purity}_ipurity=iâˆ‘â€‹purityiâ€‹

Maximum Matching

Consider a 1-to-1 assignment that maximizes the overall overlap between ground-truth clusters and computed clusters.

F-measure

precision and recall

Conditional Entropy

Internal Measures

Based only on clustering data

Silhouette coefficient

Davies-Bouldin index

â€¦

entry.title: éšæœºç®—æ³• 3 Hash Functions
entry.content:
Lecturer: Kasper

Lecture notes is based on High Speed Hashing for Integers and Strings by Mikkel Thorup

Hash Functions

Universe UUU. Mapping randomly to a range [m]={0,â‹¯â€‰,mâˆ’1}[m]=\{0,\cdots,m-1\}[m]={0,â‹¯,mâˆ’1}.

Truly random hash function h:Uâ†’[m]h:U\rarr[m]h:Uâ†’[m].

hhh is idealized, can not be implemented. To represent a truly random hash functions, we need to store at least âˆ£Uâˆ£logâ¡2m|U|\log_2mâˆ£Uâˆ£log2â€‹m bits. (too large, impossible!)

Idea: hash functions contain only a small element or seed of randomness so that the hash function is sufficiently random for the desired application. e.g. Prime number ppp, for random hash function h:[p]â†’[0,â‹¯â€‰,pâˆ’1]h:[p]\rarr[0,\cdots,p-1]h:[p]â†’[0,â‹¯,pâˆ’1] could be h(x)=(ax+b)modâ€‰â€‰ph(x)=(ax+b)\mod ph(x)=(ax+b)modp where a,ba,ba,b are random numbers that together form the random seed describing the function.

Definition and Properties

Definition 1: A hash function h:Uâ†’[m]h:U\rarr[m]h:Uâ†’[m] is a random variable in the class of all functions Uâ†’[m]U\rarr[m]Uâ†’[m], i.e., it consists of a random variable h(x)h(x)h(x) for each xâˆˆUx\in UxâˆˆU.

3 things we care about hhh:

  1. Space. The size of the random seed that is necessary to calculate h(x)h(x)h(x) given xxx.
  2. Speed. The time it takes to calculate h(x)h(x)h(x) given xxx.
  3. Properties of random variables.

Universal Hashing

To generate a random hash function h:Uâ†’[m]h:U\rarr[m]h:Uâ†’[m] from a key universe UUU to a set of hash values [m]={0,â‹¯â€‰,mâˆ’1}[m]=\{0,\cdots,m-1\}[m]={0,â‹¯,mâˆ’1}. We think of hhh as a random variable following some distribution over functions Uâ†’[m]U\rarr[m]Uâ†’[m]. We want hhh to be universal which means that for any given distinct keys x,yâˆˆUx,y\in Ux,yâˆˆU, when hhh is picked at random, we have low collision probability:

Prâ¡h[h(x)=h(y)]â‰¤1m\Pr_h[h(x)=h(y)]\le{1\over m}hPrâ€‹[h(x)=h(y)]â‰¤m1â€‹

For many applications, it suffices if for some c=O(1)c=O(1)c=O(1), we have

Prâ¡h[h(x)=h(y)]â‰¤cm\Pr_h[h(x)=h(y)]\le{c\over m}hPrâ€‹[h(x)=h(y)]â‰¤mcâ€‹

Then hhh is called c-approximately universal.

Exercise 2.1 Is the truly independent hash function h:Uâ†’[m]h : U \rarr [m]h:Uâ†’[m] universal?

Yes.

Exercise 2.2 If a hash function h:Uâ†’[m]h : U \rarr [m]h:Uâ†’[m] has collision probability 0, how large must mmm be?

mâ‰¥âˆ£Uâˆ£m\ge|U|mâ‰¥âˆ£Uâˆ£.

Exercise 2.3 Let uâ‰¤mu \le muâ‰¤m. Is the identity function f(x)=xf (x) = xf(x)=x a universal hash function [u]â†’[m][u] â†’ [m][u]â†’[m]?

Yes.

Applications

hash tables with chaining. (detail see in Lecture 2)

Multiply-mod-prime

Assume m<um\lt um<u and m>1m\gt1m>1.

The classic universal hash function is based on a prime number pâ‰¥up\ge upâ‰¥u. We pick a uniformly random aâˆˆ[p]+={1,â‹¯â€‰,pâˆ’1}a\in[p]_+=\{1,\cdots,p-1\}aâˆˆ[p]+â€‹={1,â‹¯,pâˆ’1} and bâˆˆ[p]={1,â‹¯â€‰,pâˆ’1}b\in[p]=\{1,\cdots,p-1\}bâˆˆ[p]={1,â‹¯,pâˆ’1}, and define ha,b:[u]â†’[m]h_{a,b}:[u]\rarr[m]ha,bâ€‹:[u]â†’[m] by

ha,b(x)=((ax+b)Â modÂ p)Â modÂ nh_{a,b}(x)=((ax+b)\text{ mod }p)\text{ mod }nha,bâ€‹(x)=((ax+b)Â modÂ p)Â modÂ n

Given any distinct x,yâˆˆ[u]âŠ†[p]x,y\in[u]\subseteq[p]x,yâˆˆ[u]âŠ†[p], we want for random a,ba,ba,b:

Prâ¡aâˆˆ[p]+,bâˆˆ[p][ha,b(x)=ha,b(y)]<1m\Pr_{a\in[p]_+,b\in[p]}[h_{a,b}(x)=h_{a,b}(y)]\lt{1\over m}aâˆˆ[p]+â€‹,bâˆˆ[p]Prâ€‹[ha,bâ€‹(x)=ha,bâ€‹(y)]<m1â€‹

âš ï¸Strict inequality! Strictly better.

Fact: If ppp is prime and Î±,Î²âˆˆ[p]+\alpha,\beta\in[p]_+Î±,Î²âˆˆ[p]+â€‹ then Î±Î²â‰¡Ì¸0Â modÂ p\alpha\beta\not\equiv0\text{ mod } pÎ±Î²î€ â‰¡0Â modÂ p.

Let x,yâˆˆ[p],xâ‰ yx,y\in[p],x\neq yx,yâˆˆ[p],xî€ =y be given. For given pair (a,b)âˆˆ[p]2(a,b)\in[p]^2(a,b)âˆˆ[p]2, define (q,r)âˆˆ[p]2(q,r)\in[p]^2(q,r)âˆˆ[p]2 by

(ax+b)Â modÂ p=q(ay+b)Â modÂ p=r(ax+b)\text{ mod }p=q\\(ay+b)\text{ mod }p=r(ax+b)Â modÂ p=q(ay+b)Â modÂ p=r

Lemma: These two equations define a 1-1 correspondence between pairs (a,b)(a,b)(a,b) and (q,r)(q,r)(q,r).

(Use Fact to prove)

Assmue that there exist two different pairs a,ba,ba,b and aâ€²,bâ€²a',b'aâ€²,bâ€² which corresponds to same q,rq,rq,r.

(ax+b)Â modÂ p=qÂ (1)(ay+b)Â modÂ p=rÂ (2)(aâ€²x+bâ€²)Â modÂ p=qÂ (3)(aâ€²y+bâ€²)Â modÂ p=rÂ (4)(ax+b)\text{ mod }p=q\ (1)\\(ay+b)\text{ mod }p=r\ (2)\\(a'x+b')\text{ mod }p=q\ (3)\\(a'y+b')\text{ mod }p=r\ (4)(ax+b)Â modÂ p=qÂ (1)(ay+b)Â modÂ p=rÂ (2)(aâ€²x+bâ€²)Â modÂ p=qÂ (3)(aâ€²y+bâ€²)Â modÂ p=rÂ (4)

For ((1)âˆ’(2))âˆ’((3)âˆ’(4))((1)-(2))-((3)-(4))((1)âˆ’(2))âˆ’((3)âˆ’(4)), by the Fact above, it yeilds aâˆ’aâ€²â‰¡0modâ€‰â€‰pa-a'\equiv0\mod paâˆ’aâ€²â‰¡0modp.

For ((1)âˆ’(3))âˆ’((2)âˆ’(4))((1)-(3))-((2)-(4))((1)âˆ’(3))âˆ’((2)âˆ’(4)), it yeilds bâˆ’bâ€²â‰¡0modâ€‰â€‰pb-b'\equiv0\mod pbâˆ’bâ€²â‰¡0modp.

Thus a=aâ€²,b=bâ€²a=a',b=b'a=aâ€²,b=bâ€² contradicts assmuption.

Thus its bijection.

Since xâ‰ yx\neq yxî€ =y, by Fact above, r=qâ‡”a=0r=q\Lrarr a=0r=qâ‡”a=0. Thus when we pick (a,b)âˆˆ[p]+Ã—[p](a,b)\in[p]_+\times[p](a,b)âˆˆ[p]+â€‹Ã—[p], we get râ‰ qr\neq qrî€ =q.

Why the inequality is strict?

We get a collision ha,b(x)=ha,b(y)h_{a,b}(x)=h_{a,b}(y)ha,bâ€‹(x)=ha,bâ€‹(y) iff qÂ modÂ m=rÂ modÂ mq\text{ mod }m=r\text{ mod }mqÂ modÂ m=rÂ modÂ m.

Let us fix qqq and set i=qÂ modÂ mi=q\text{ mod }mi=qÂ modÂ m. There are at most âŒˆp/mâŒ‰\lceil p/m\rceilâŒˆp/mâŒ‰ values râˆˆ[p]r\in[p]râˆˆ[p] with rÂ modÂ m=ir\text{ mod }m=irÂ modÂ m=i and one of them is r=qr=qr=q. Therefore, the number of râˆˆ[p]â•²{q}r\in[p]\diagdown\{q\}râˆˆ[p]â•²{q} with rÂ modÂ m=i=qÂ modÂ mr\text{ mod }m=i=q\text{ mod }mrÂ modÂ m=i=qÂ modÂ m is at most âŒˆp/mâŒ‰âˆ’1â‰¤(p+mâˆ’1)/mâˆ’1=(pâˆ’1)/m\lceil p/m\rceil-1\le(p+m-1)/m-1=(p-1)/mâŒˆp/mâŒ‰âˆ’1â‰¤(p+mâˆ’1)/mâˆ’1=(pâˆ’1)/m. However, there are values of iâ€²âˆˆ[m]i'\in[m]iâ€²âˆˆ[m] with only âŒŠp/mâŒ‹\lfloor p/m\rfloorâŒŠp/mâŒ‹ values of qâ€²âˆˆ[p]q'\in[p]qâ€²âˆˆ[p] with qâ€²Â modÂ m=iâ€²q'\text{ mod }m=i'qâ€²Â modÂ m=iâ€², and then the number of râ€²âˆˆ[p]â•²{qâ€²}r'\in[p]\diagdown\{q'\}râ€²âˆˆ[p]â•²{qâ€²} with râ€²Â modÂ m=iâ€²=qâ€²Â modÂ mr'\text{ mod }m=i'=q'\text{ mod }mrâ€²Â modÂ m=iâ€²=qâ€²Â modÂ m is âŒŠp/mâŒ‹âˆ’1<âŒˆp/mâŒ‰âˆ’1\lfloor p/m\rfloor-1\lt\lceil p/m\rceil-1âŒŠp/mâŒ‹âˆ’1<âŒˆp/mâŒ‰âˆ’1. Summing over all ppp values of qâˆˆ[p]q\in[p]qâˆˆ[p], we get that the number of râˆˆ[p]â•²{q}r\in[p]\diagdown\{q\}râˆˆ[p]â•²{q} with rÂ modÂ m=i=qÂ modÂ mr\text{ mod }m=i=q\text{ mod }mrÂ modÂ m=i=qÂ modÂ m is strictly less than p(âŒˆp/mâŒ‰âˆ’1)â‰¤p(pâˆ’1)/mp(\lceil p/m\rceil-1)\le p(p-1)/mp(âŒˆp/mâŒ‰âˆ’1)â‰¤p(pâˆ’1)/m. Then 1-1 correspondence implies that there are strictly less than p(pâˆ’1)/mp(p-1)/mp(pâˆ’1)/m collision pairs (a,b)âˆˆ[p]+Ã—[p](a,b)\in[p]_+\times[p](a,b)âˆˆ[p]+â€‹Ã—[p]. Since each of the p(pâˆ’1)p(p-1)p(pâˆ’1) pairs from [p]+Ã—[p][p]_+\times[p][p]+â€‹Ã—[p] are equally likely, we conclude that the collision probability is strictly below 1/m1/m1/m.

Implementation for 64-bit Keys

Hashing scheme

h(x)=((ax+b)Â modÂ p)Â modÂ mh(x)=((ax+b)\text{ mod }p)\text{ mod }mh(x)=((ax+b)Â modÂ p)Â modÂ m

u=264,m=220u=2^{64},m=2^{20}u=264,m=220.

Since p>u=264p\gt u=2^{64}p>u=264, we generally need to reserve more than 64 bits for aâˆˆ[p]+a\in[p]_+aâˆˆ[p]+â€‹, so the product axaxax has more than 128 bits. We can get the product of 32-bit numbers, representing them as 64-bit numbers, and getting the full 64-bit result. We need at least 6 such 64-bit multiplications to compute axaxax.

How do we compute axÂ modÂ pax\text{ mod }paxÂ modÂ p? For 64-bit numbers, we have a general mod-operation. Idea: Let ppp be a Mersenne prime p=2qâˆ’1p=2^q-1p=2qâˆ’1, e.g. 261âˆ’1,289âˆ’12^{61}-1,2^{89}-1261âˆ’1,289âˆ’1.

xâ‰¡(xÂ modÂ 2q+âŒŠx/2qâŒ‹)modâ€‰â€‰px\equiv(x\text{ mod }2^q+\lfloor x/2^q\rfloor)\mod pxâ‰¡(xÂ modÂ 2q+âŒŠx/2qâŒ‹)modp

To prove this, it suffices to prove: xÂ modÂ 2q+âŒŠx/2qâŒ‹=xâˆ’âŒŠx/2qâŒ‹px\text{ mod }2^q+\lfloor x/2^q\rfloor=x-\lfloor x/2^q\rfloor pxÂ modÂ 2q+âŒŠx/2qâŒ‹=xâˆ’âŒŠx/2qâŒ‹p. (Obviously)

Multiply-shift

Hashing from www-bit integers to â„“\ellâ„“-bit integers.

We pick a uniformly random odd www-bit integer aaa, and then we compute ha:[2w]â†’[2â„“]h_a:[2^w]\rarr[2^\ell]haâ€‹:[2w]â†’[2â„“], as

ha(x)=âŒŠ(axÂ modÂ 2w)/2wâˆ’â„“âŒ‹.h_a(x)=\lfloor(ax\text{ mod }2^w)/2^{w-\ell}\rfloor.haâ€‹(x)=âŒŠ(axÂ modÂ 2w)/2wâˆ’â„“âŒ‹.

This scheme is faster than ha,b(x)=((ax+b)Â modÂ p)Â modÂ nh_{a,b}(x)=((ax+b)\text{ mod }p)\text{ mod }nha,bâ€‹(x)=((ax+b)Â modÂ p)Â modÂ n. Numbers are stored as bit strings, with the least significant bit to the right. Integer division by a power of 2 is accomplished by a right shift. For hashing 64-bit integers, we further exploit that 64-bit multiplication automatically discards overflow, which is the same as multiplying modulo 2642^{64}264.

Multiply-shift is 2-approximately universal, i.e., for xâ‰ yx\neq yxî€ =y,

Prâ¡oddÂ aâˆˆ[2w][ha(x)=ha(y)]â‰¤2/2â„“=2/m\Pr_{\text{odd }a\in[2^w]}[h_a(x)=h_a(y)]\le2/2^\ell=2/moddÂ aâˆˆ[2w]Prâ€‹[haâ€‹(x)=haâ€‹(y)]â‰¤2/2â„“=2/m

To prove this, it suffices to prove that the probability that bis wâˆ’â„“,â‹¯â€‰,wâˆ’1w-\ell,\cdots,w-1wâˆ’â„“,â‹¯,wâˆ’1 of a(yâˆ’x)a(y-x)a(yâˆ’x) are all 0s or all 1s is at most 2/2â„“2/2^\ell2/2â„“.

Fact: If Î±\alphaÎ± is odd and Î²âˆˆ[2q]+\beta\in[2^q]_+Î²âˆˆ[2q]+â€‹, then Î±Î²â‰¡Ì¸0(Â modÂ 2q)\alpha\beta\not\equiv0(\text{ mod }2^q)Î±Î²î€ â‰¡0(Â modÂ 2q).

Proof omitted.

è¯æ˜çš„å¤§è‡´æ€è·¯ï¼šå‡è®¾ x<y,ha(x)=ha(y)x\lt y,h_a(x)=h_a(y)x<y,haâ€‹(x)=haâ€‹(y)ã€‚æ˜¾ç„¶ï¼Œå¦‚æœè¦ç¢°æ’ï¼Œé‚£ä¹ˆ ay=ax+a(yâˆ’x)ay=ax+a(y-x)ay=ax+a(yâˆ’x) ä¸­ï¼Œa(yâˆ’x)a(y-x)a(yâˆ’x) å¯¹åº”ç¬¬ wâˆ’â„“w-\ellwâˆ’â„“ åˆ°ç¬¬ wâˆ’1w-1wâˆ’1 è¿™ â„“\ellâ„“ ä½æ¯”ç‰¹å¿…é¡»å…¨ 0 æˆ–è€…å…¨ 1ã€‚å†è¯å…¨ 0 å’Œå…¨ 1 çš„æ¦‚ç‡æ˜¯ 2/2â„“2/2^\ell2/2â„“.

å†ç”¨ä¸Šé¢çš„ Fact â€œä»»ä½•å¥‡æ•°å’Œ 2 çš„å¤šæ¬¡å¹‚äº’è´¨â€è¯æ˜ a(yâˆ’x)a(y-x)a(yâˆ’x) å¯¹åº”ç¬¬ wâˆ’â„“w-\ellwâˆ’â„“ åˆ°ç¬¬ wâˆ’1w-1wâˆ’1 è¿™ â„“\ellâ„“ ä½æ¯”ç‰¹æ˜¯å‡åŒ€åˆ†å¸ƒå³å¯ã€‚

Strong Universality

Strong universality: For h:[u]â†’[m]h:[u]\rarr[m]h:[u]â†’[m], we consider pairwise events of the form that for given distinct keys x,yâˆˆ[u]x,y\in[u]x,yâˆˆ[u] and possibly non-distinct hash values q,râˆˆ[m]q,r\in[m]q,râˆˆ[m], we have h(x)=qh(x)=qh(x)=q and h(y)=rh(y)=rh(y)=r. We say a random hash function h:[u]â†’[m]h:[u]\rarr[m]h:[u]â†’[m] is strongly universal if the probability of every pairwise event is 1/m21/m^21/m2.

We note that if hhh is strongly universal, it is also universal since

\Pr[h(x)=h(y)]=\sum_{q\in[m]}\Pr[h(x)=q\and h(y)=q]=m/m^2=1/m

Observation: An equivalent definition of strong universality is that each key is hashed uniformly into [m][m][m], and that every two distinct keys are hashed independently.

Proof omitted.

Emphasizing the independence, strong universality is also called 2-independence, as it concerns a pair of two events. As for universality, we may accept some relaxed notion of strong universality e.g. 3-independence, k-independence

c-approximately strongly universality: h:[U]â†’[m]h:[U]\rarr[m]h:[U]â†’[m] is c-approximately strongly universal if

  1. hhh is c-approximately uniform, meaning for every xâˆˆUx\in UxâˆˆU and for every hash value qâˆˆ[m]q\in[m]qâˆˆ[m], we have Prâ¡[h(x)=q]â‰¤c/m\Pr[h(x)=q]\le c/mPr[h(x)=q]â‰¤c/m;
  2. Every pair of distinct keys hash independently.

Applications

Coordinated sampling: allocation of strongly universal hashing.

Basic idea: small samples can reason about the similarity of huge sets.

First we consider sampling from a single set AâŠ†UA\subseteq UAâŠ†U using a strongly universal hash function h:Uâ†’[m]h:U\rarr[m]h:Uâ†’[m] and a threshold tâˆˆ{0,â‹¯â€‰,m}t\in\{0,\cdots,m\}tâˆˆ{0,â‹¯,m}. We now sample xxx if h(x)<th(x)\lt th(x)<t, which by uniformity happens with probability t/mt/mt/m for any xxx.

Let Sh,t(A)={xâˆˆAâˆ£h(x)<t}S_{h,t}(A)=\{x\in A|h(x)\lt t\}Sh,tâ€‹(A)={xâˆˆAâˆ£h(x)<t} denote the resulting sample from AAA. Then by linearity of expectation, E[âˆ£Sh,t(A)âˆ£]=âˆ£Aâˆ£â‹…t/m\mathbb E[|S_{h,t}(A)|]=|A|\cdot t/mE[âˆ£Sh,tâ€‹(A)âˆ£]=âˆ£Aâˆ£â‹…t/m. Conversely, this means that if we have Sh,t(A)S_{h,t}(A)Sh,tâ€‹(A), then we can estimate âˆ£Aâˆ£|A|âˆ£Aâˆ£ as âˆ£Sh,t(A)âˆ£â‹…m/t|S_{h,t}(A)|\cdot m/tâˆ£Sh,tâ€‹(A)âˆ£â‹…m/t.

The important application is not just sampling from a single set, but rather the sampling from different sets BBB and CCC so that we can later reason about the similarity, estimating the sizes of their union BâˆªCB\cup CBâˆªC and intersection Bâˆ©CB\cap CBâˆ©C.

Sh,t(BâˆªC)=Sh,t(B)âˆªSh,t(C)Sh,t(Bâˆ©C)=Sh,t(B)âˆ©Sh,t(C)S_{h,t}(B\cup C)=S_{h,t}(B)\cup S_{h,t}(C)\\S_{h,t}(B\cap C)=S_{h,t}(B)\cap S_{h,t}(C)Sh,tâ€‹(BâˆªC)=Sh,tâ€‹(B)âˆªSh,tâ€‹(C)Sh,tâ€‹(Bâˆ©C)=Sh,tâ€‹(B)âˆ©Sh,tâ€‹(C)

We can then estimate the size of the union and intersection multiplying the corresponding sample sizes by m/tm/tm/t.

Sampling from different sets can be done in a distributed way.

Application: In machine learning, we can store the samples of many different large sets; On the Internet, routers can store samples of the packets passing through.

To get a fixed sampling probability t/mt/mt/m for each xâˆˆUx\in UxâˆˆU, we only need that h:Uâ†’[m]h:U\rarr[m]h:Uâ†’[m] is uniform. This ensures that the estimate âˆ£Sh,t(A)âˆ£â‹…m/t|S_{h,t}(A)|\cdot m/tâˆ£Sh,tâ€‹(A)âˆ£â‹…m/t of AAA is unbiased.

For aâˆˆAa\in AaâˆˆA, let Xa=[h(a)<t],X=âˆ‘aâˆˆAXaX_a=[h(a)\lt t],X=\sum_{a\in A}X_aXaâ€‹=[h(a)<t],X=âˆ‘aâˆˆAâ€‹Xaâ€‹. Then X=âˆ£Sh,t(A)âˆ£X=|S_{h,t}(A)|X=âˆ£Sh,tâ€‹(A)âˆ£, but the reasoning below applies when XaX_aXaâ€‹ is any 0-1 indicator variable that depends only h(a)h(a)h(a).

Because hhh is strongly universal, for any distinct a,bâˆˆAa,b\in Aa,bâˆˆA, we have that h(a),h(b)h(a),h(b)h(a),h(b) are independent, and hence so are Xa,XbX_a,X_bXaâ€‹,Xbâ€‹. Therefore X=âˆ‘aâˆˆAXaX=\sum_{a\in A}X_aX=âˆ‘aâˆˆAâ€‹Xaâ€‹ is the sum of pairwise independent 0-1 variables. Now the following concentration bound applies to XXX.

Lemma: Let X=âˆ‘aâˆˆAXaX=\sum_{a\in A}X_aX=âˆ‘aâˆˆAâ€‹Xaâ€‹ where XaX_aXaâ€‹ are pairwise independent 0-1 variables. Let Î¼=E[X]\mu=\mathbb E[X]Î¼=E[X]. Then Var(X)â‰¤Î¼\text{Var}(X)\le\muVar(X)â‰¤Î¼ and for any q>0q\gt0q>0,

Prâ¡[âˆ£Xâˆ’Î¼âˆ£â‰¥qÎ¼]â‰¤1/q2\Pr[|X-\mu|\ge q\sqrt\mu]\le1/q^2Pr[âˆ£Xâˆ’Î¼âˆ£â‰¥qÎ¼â€‹]â‰¤1/q2

Proof by Chebyshevâ€™s inequality

Multiply-mod-prime

The classic strongly universal hash scheme is a multiply-mod-prime scheme. For some prime ppp, uniformly at random we pick (a,b)âˆˆ[p]2(a,b)\in[p]^2(a,b)âˆˆ[p]2 and define ha,b:[p]â†’[p]h_{a,b}:[p]\rarr[p]ha,bâ€‹:[p]â†’[p] by

ha,b(x)=(ax+b)Â modÂ p.h_{a,b}(x)=(ax+b)\text{ mod }p.ha,bâ€‹(x)=(ax+b)Â modÂ p.

Each pair ha,b(x)=qh_{a,b}(x)=qha,bâ€‹(x)=q and ha,b(y)=rh_{a,b}(y)=rha,bâ€‹(y)=r happens with probability 1/p21/p^21/p2.

Multiply-shift

For any bit-string zzz and integers j>iâ‰¥0,z[i,j)=z[i,jâˆ’1]j\gt i\ge0,z[i,j)=z[i,j-1]j>iâ‰¥0,z[i,j)=z[i,jâˆ’1] denotes the number represented by bits i,â‹¯â€‰,jâˆ’1i,\cdots,j-1i,â‹¯,jâˆ’1, so

z[i,j)=âŒŠ(zÂ modÂ 2j)/2iâŒ‹.z[i,j)=\lfloor(z\text{ mod }2^j)/2^i\rfloor.z[i,j)=âŒŠ(zÂ modÂ 2j)/2iâŒ‹.

To get strongly universal hashing [2w]â†’[2â„“][2^w]\rarr[2^\ell][2w]â†’[2â„“], we may pick any wâ€¾â‰¥w+â„“âˆ’1\overline w\ge w+\ell-1wâ‰¥w+â„“âˆ’1. For any pair (a,b)âˆˆ[wâ€¾]2(a,b)\in[\overline w]^2(a,b)âˆˆ[w]2, we define ha,b:[2w]â†’[2â„“]h_{a,b}:[2^w]\rarr[2^\ell]ha,bâ€‹:[2w]â†’[2â„“] by

ha,b(x)=(ax+b)[wâ€¾âˆ’â„“,wâ€¾).h_{a,b}(x)=(ax+b)[\overline w-\ell,\overline w).ha,bâ€‹(x)=(ax+b)[wâˆ’â„“,w).

It is strongly universal, proof omitted.

Beyond Strong Universality

There are more advanced algorithmic applications that need more powerful hash functions.

k-independent hash functions: A hash random function H:Uâ†’[m]H:U\rarr[m]H:Uâ†’[m] is k-independent if for any distinct keys x1,â‹¯â€‰,xkâˆˆ[u]x_1,\cdots,x_k\in[u]x1â€‹,â‹¯,xkâ€‹âˆˆ[u], the hash values H(x1),â‹¯â€‰,H(xk)H(x_1),\cdots,H(x_k)H(x1â€‹),â‹¯,H(xkâ€‹) are independent random variables, each uniformly distributed in [m][m][m].

From prime ppp, we can implement a k-independent H:[p]â†’[p]H:[p]\rarr[p]H:[p]â†’[p] using kkk random coefficients a0,â‹¯â€‰,akâˆ’1âˆˆ[p]a_0,\cdots,a_{k-1}\in[p]a0â€‹,â‹¯,akâˆ’1â€‹âˆˆ[p], defining

H(x)=âˆ‘i=0kâˆ’1aixiÂ modÂ p.H(x)=\sum_{i=0}^{k-1}a_ix^i\text{ mod }p.H(x)=i=0âˆ‘kâˆ’1â€‹aiâ€‹xiÂ modÂ p.

However, there is no efficient implementation of k-independent hashing on complex objects such as variable length strings. What we can do instead is to use the signature idea from Section 2, and first hash the complex keys to unique hash values from a limited integer domain [u][u][u].

entry.title: æ•°æ®æŒ–æ˜ 2 Representation-based Clustering
entry.content:
What is Clustering

Grouping a set of data objects into clusters

  • Cluster: a collection of data objects
    1. Similar to one another within the same cluster
    2. Dissimilar to the objects in other clusters

Cluster = unsupervised classification no predefined classes

Usage

  1. Get insight into data distribution
  2. Preprocessing step for other algorithms

Application of Clustering

Pattern Recognition and Image Processing

Spatial Data Analysis

WWW

Biology

Information retrieval

Marketing

City-planning

Social networks

Basic Concept of Representative-based Approaches

Goal: Construct a partition of a database DDD of nnn objects into a set of kkk clusters minimizing an objective function

  • Exhaustively enumerating all possible partitions into kkk sets in order to find the global minimum is too expensive (exponential time)
  • Example objective: minimize the max distance (Manhattan, Euclidean, Geodesic, â€¦) among the points in the cluster

Heuristic methods:

  • Choose kkk representatives for clusters e.g. randomly
  • Improve there initial representatives iteratively
    • Assign each object to the cluster it fits best in the current clustering
    • Compute new cluster representatives based on these assignments
    • Repeat until the change in the objective function from one iteration to the next drops below a threshold

Types of cluster representatives

  • K-means: Each cluster is represented by the center of the cluster
  • K-medoid: Each cluster is represented by one of its objects.

K-means Clustering

Overview

Basic Ideas

For a given kkk, form kkk groups so that the sum of the distances between the mean of the groups (centroids) and their elements is minimal.

Basic Notions

Objects x=(x1,â‹¯â€‰,xd)\mathbf x=(x_1,\cdots,x_d)x=(x1â€‹,â‹¯,xdâ€‹) are points in a d-dimensional vector space

Centroid Î¼c\mu_cÎ¼câ€‹: Means of all points in a cluster CCC: Î¼c=1Câˆ‘xjâˆˆCxj\mu_c=\frac{1}{C}\sum_{x_j\in C}x_jÎ¼câ€‹=C1â€‹âˆ‘xjâ€‹âˆˆCâ€‹xjâ€‹.

Measure of the compactness (aka total distance) of a cluster CiC_iCiâ€‹:

TD(Ci)=âˆ‘xjâˆˆCidist(xj,Î¼Ci)2TD(C_i)=\sqrt{\sum_{x_j\in C_i}dist(x_j,\mu_{C_i})^2}TD(Ciâ€‹)=xjâ€‹âˆˆCiâ€‹âˆ‘â€‹dist(xjâ€‹,Î¼Ciâ€‹â€‹)2â€‹

Measure of the compactness of a clustering:

TD=âˆ‘i=1kTD2(Ci)TD=\sqrt{\sum_{i=1}^kTD^2(C_i)}TD=i=1âˆ‘kâ€‹TD2(Ciâ€‹)â€‹

The ideal clustering minimizes this objective function.

Lloydâ€™s Algorithm

Initialize: Partition the objects randomly into kkk non-empty subsets.

  1. Centroid Update: Compute the centroids of the clusters of the current partition. The centroid is the center of a cluster.
  2. Cluster Assignment: Assign each object to the cluster with the nearest representative.

Repeat Step 1 until representatives change.

Pros and Cons

Advantages ğŸ‘

  • Relatively efficient O(tkn)\mathcal O(tkn)O(tkn)

    nnn is # of objects, kkk is # of clusters, ttt is # of iterations.

  • Normally k,tâ‰ªnk,t\ll nk,tâ‰ªn.

  • Easy implementation

Disadvantages ğŸ‘

  • Applicable only when mean is defined
  • Need to specify kkk in advance
  • Sensitive to noisy data and outliers
  • Clusters are forced to have convex shapes.
  • Result and runtime are very dependent on initial partition; often terminates at a local optimum.

Variant of k-means, e.g. ISODATA (eliminate small clusters, merging and split of clusters)

Choice of Parameter kkk

Idea for a method:

  1. Determine a clustering for each k=2,â‹¯â€‰,nâˆ’1k=2,\cdots,n-1k=2,â‹¯,nâˆ’1
  2. Choose the best clustering

How to measure the quality of a clustering?

  • measure has to be independent of kkk!
  • The measures for the compactness of a clustering TD2TD^2TD2 and TDTDTD are monotonously decreasing with increasing value of kkk.

The Silhouette Coefficient

A measure to clustering

Basic idea:

  • Elements in cluster should be similar to their representative

  • Elements in different clusters should be dissimilar

int(o)int(o)int(o): average distance between object ooo and the objects in its cluster.

int(o)=1Ciâˆ‘xâˆˆC(o)â•²{o}dist(o,x)int(o)=\frac{1}{C_i}\sum_{x\in C(o)\diagdown\{o\}}dist(o,x)int(o)=Ciâ€‹1â€‹xâˆˆC(o)â•²{o}âˆ‘â€‹dist(o,x)

ext(o)ext(o)ext(o): average distance between object ooo and the objects in its â€œsecond closestâ€ cluster

ext(o)=minâ¡Ciâ‰ C(o)(1Ciâˆ‘xâˆˆCidist(o,x))ext(o)=\min_{C_i\neq C(o)}(\frac{1}{C_i}\sum_{x\in C_i}dist(o,x))ext(o)=Ciâ€‹î€ =C(o)minâ€‹(Ciâ€‹1â€‹xâˆˆCiâ€‹âˆ‘â€‹dist(o,x))

The silhouette of ooo is:

s(o)=ext(o)âˆ’int(o)maxâ¡{int(o),ext(o)}s(o)âˆˆ[âˆ’1,1]s(o)=\frac{ext(o)-int(o)}{\max\{int(o),ext(o)\}}\\s(o)\in[-1,1]s(o)=max{int(o),ext(o)}ext(o)âˆ’int(o)â€‹s(o)âˆˆ[âˆ’1,1]

How good is the assignment of ooo to its cluster?

s(o)â†’âˆ’1s(o)\rightarrow-1s(o)â†’âˆ’1: bad, on average cluster to members of second-closest cluster.

s(o)=0s(o)=0s(o)=0: o lies between two clusters.

s(o)â†’1s(o)\rightarrow1s(o)â†’1: good assignment of ooo to its cluster.

Silhouette coefficient sCs_CsCâ€‹ of a clustering is average silhouette of all objects

  • sCâˆˆ(0.7,1.0]s_C\in(0.7,1.0]sCâ€‹âˆˆ(0.7,1.0] implies strong structure.
  • sCâˆˆ(0.5,0.7]s_C\in(0.5,0.7]sCâ€‹âˆˆ(0.5,0.7] implies medium structure.
  • sCâˆˆ(0.25,0.5]s_C\in(0.25,0.5]sCâ€‹âˆˆ(0.25,0.5] implies weak structure.
  • sCâˆˆ[âˆ’1,0.25]s_C\in[-1,0.25]sCâ€‹âˆˆ[âˆ’1,0.25] implies no structure.

sCs_CsCâ€‹ is used for determining the best value of kkk.

Kernel K-means

Linearity of K-means: K-means assume the boundaries between the clusters are lines.

â“What if the boundaries are not lines? Use Kernel K-means.

Basic Idea

Use kernels to project points into another space

Separate the points with -means in the new space

Recall k-means objective: minâ¡Câˆ‘i=1kâˆ‘xjâˆˆCiâˆ£âˆ£xjâˆ’Î¼iâˆ£âˆ£2\min_C\sum_{i=1}^k\sum_{x_j\in C_i}||x_j-\mu_i||^2minCâ€‹âˆ‘i=1kâ€‹âˆ‘xjâ€‹âˆˆCiâ€‹â€‹âˆ£âˆ£xjâ€‹âˆ’Î¼iâ€‹âˆ£âˆ£2

Map every point xjx_jxjâ€‹ into a different space Ï•(xj)\phi(x_j)Ï•(xjâ€‹)

Recall that a kernel is a dot-product K(xi,xj)=Ï•(xi)TÏ•(xj)K(x_i,x_j)=\phi(x_i)^T\phi(x_j)K(xiâ€‹,xjâ€‹)=Ï•(xiâ€‹)TÏ•(xjâ€‹)

Thus,

minâ¡Câˆ‘i=1kâˆ‘xjâˆˆCiâˆ£âˆ£Ï•(xj)âˆ’Ï•(Î¼i)âˆ£âˆ£2=âˆ‘j=1nK(xj,xj)âˆ’âˆ‘i=1k1niâˆ‘xaâˆˆCiâˆ‘xbâˆˆCiK(xa,xb)\min_C\sum_{i=1}^k\sum_{x_j\in C_i}||\phi(x_j)-\phi(\mu_i)||^2\\=\sum_{j=1}^nK(x_j,x_j)-\sum_{i=1}^k\frac{1}{n_i}\sum_{x_a\in C_i}\sum_{x_b\in C_i}K(x_a,x_b)Cminâ€‹i=1âˆ‘kâ€‹xjâ€‹âˆˆCiâ€‹âˆ‘â€‹âˆ£âˆ£Ï•(xjâ€‹)âˆ’Ï•(Î¼iâ€‹)âˆ£âˆ£2=j=1âˆ‘nâ€‹K(xjâ€‹,xjâ€‹)âˆ’i=1âˆ‘kâ€‹niâ€‹1â€‹xaâ€‹âˆˆCiâ€‹âˆ‘â€‹xbâ€‹âˆˆCiâ€‹âˆ‘â€‹K(xaâ€‹,xbâ€‹)

Kernel K-means can generates non-linear boundaries.

Pro and Cons

Advantages ğŸ‘

  • Allow detection of clusters with arbitrary shape
  • Fits any possible kernel

Disadvantages ğŸ‘

  • Inefficient O(n2k)O(n^2k)O(n2k)
  • Like K-means: need to specify the number of clusters kkk in advance.
  • Requires the choice of a kernel

K-medoid

Motivation

K-means assumes Euclidean distance while K-medoid is more general.

  • Motivated by L1 norm (Manhattan distance)
  • Works also in space, where a mean is not defined
  • Only input is the possibility to compute pairwise distance

More robust to noise ğŸ‘

Lp Norms

General Lp-Metric (Minkowski-Distance)

dp(x,y)=(âˆ‘i=1dâˆ£xiâˆ’yiâˆ£p)1pd_p(x,y)=(\sum_{i=1}^d|x_i-y_i|^p)^{1\over p}dpâ€‹(x,y)=(i=1âˆ‘dâ€‹âˆ£xiâ€‹âˆ’yiâ€‹âˆ£p)p1â€‹

p=2p=2p=2: Euclidean Distance used in K-means

p=1p=1p=1 Manhattan Distance used in K-medoids

Basic Idea

Find kkk representatives in the dataset s.t., the sum of the distances between representatives and objects which are assigned to them is minimal.

Medoid: representative object â€œin the middleâ€

Notions

Requires arbitrary objects and a distance function

Medoid mCm_CmCâ€‹: representative object in a cluster CCC

Measure for the compactness of a cluster CCC:

TD(C)=âˆ‘xâˆˆCdist(x,mC)TD(C)=\sum_{x\in C}dist(x,m_C)TD(C)=xâˆˆCâˆ‘â€‹dist(x,mCâ€‹)

Measure for the compactness of a clustering

TD=âˆ‘i=1kTD(Ci)TD=\sum_{i=1}^kTD(C_i)TD=i=1âˆ‘kâ€‹TD(Ciâ€‹)

PAM Algorithm

Given kkk

  1. Select kkk objects arbitrarily as medoids; assign each remaining object to the cluster with the nearest representative, and compute current TDTDTD.
  2. For each pair medoid M and non-medoid N, compute the value TDMâ†”NTD_{M\lrarr N}TDMâ†”Nâ€‹.
  3. Select the non-medoid NNN for which TDMâ†”NTD_{M\lrarr N}TDMâ†”Nâ€‹ is minimum.
  4. If TDMâ†”NTD_{M\lrarr N}TDMâ†”Nâ€‹ is smaller than current TDTDTD
    • Swap MMM with NNN
    • Set current TD=TDMâ†”NTD=TD_{M\lrarr N}TD=TDMâ†”Nâ€‹.
    • Go back to step 2.
  5. Else stop

CLARA & CLARANS

CLARA

  • additional parameter: numlocal
  • Draws numlocal samples of the data set
  • applies PAM on each sample
  • returns the best of these sets of medoids as output

CLARANS

  • two additional parameters: maxneighbor and numlocal
  • at most maxneighbor many pairs are evaluated in the algorithm.
  • The first pair (M,N) for which TD is smaller than current one is swapped instead of finding the minimal one.
  • Finding the local minimum with this procedure is repeated numlocal times.

Efficiency: runtime(CLARANS) < runtime(CLARA) < runtime(PAM)

Pros and Cons

Advantages ğŸ‘

  • Applicable to arbitrary objects + distance functions
  • Not as sensitive to noisy data and outlier as K-means

Disadvantages ğŸ‘

  • Inefficient
  • Need to specify the number of clusters kkk in advance
  • Result and runtime for CLARA and CLARNAS may vary largely depend on randomization.

Expectation Maximization

Consider points xj=(x1,â‹¯â€‰,xd)\mathbf x_j=(x_1,\cdots,x_d)xjâ€‹=(x1â€‹,â‹¯,xdâ€‹) from a d-dimensional Euclidean vector space

Each cluster is represented by a probability distribution

Typically: mixture of Gaussian distributions

Single distribution to represent a cluster CiC_iCiâ€‹

  • Center point Î¼i\mu_iÎ¼iâ€‹ of all points in the cluster
  • Covariance matrix Î£i\Sigma_iÎ£iâ€‹ for the points in the cluster CiC_iCiâ€‹

f(xâˆ£Î¼i,Î£i)=1(2Ï€)dâˆ£Î£iâˆ£eâˆ’12(xâˆ’Î¼i)TÎ£iâˆ’1(xâˆ’Î¼i)f(\mathbf x|\mu_i,\Sigma_i)=\frac{1}{\sqrt{(2\pi)^d|\Sigma_i|}}e^{-\frac{1}{2}(\mathbf x-\mu_i)^T\Sigma_i^{-1}(\mathbf x-\mu_i)}f(xâˆ£Î¼iâ€‹,Î£iâ€‹)=(2Ï€)dâˆ£Î£iâ€‹âˆ£â€‹1â€‹eâˆ’21â€‹(xâˆ’Î¼iâ€‹)TÎ£iâˆ’1â€‹(xâˆ’Î¼iâ€‹)

The density for the clustering

f(x)=âˆ‘i=1kf(xâˆ£Î¼i,Î£i)P(Ci),âˆ‘i=1kP(Ci)=1f(\mathbf x)=\sum_{i=1}^kf(\mathbf x|\mu_i,\Sigma_i)P(C_i),\sum_{i=1}^kP(C_i)=1f(x)=i=1âˆ‘kâ€‹f(xâˆ£Î¼iâ€‹,Î£iâ€‹)P(Ciâ€‹),i=1âˆ‘kâ€‹P(Ciâ€‹)=1

â“ How do we find the parameters Î¸i=Î¼i,Î£i,P(Ci)\theta_i=\mu_i,\Sigma_i,P(C_i)Î¸iâ€‹=Î¼iâ€‹,Î£iâ€‹,P(Ciâ€‹)? Maximize the log-likelihood (MLE)

argâ¡maxâ¡Î¸1,â‹¯â€‰,Î¸klnâ¡P(Dâˆ£Î¸1,â‹¯â€‰,Î¸k)\arg\max_{\theta_1,\cdots,\theta_k}\ln P(\mathbf D|\theta_1,\cdots,\theta_k)argÎ¸1â€‹,â‹¯,Î¸kâ€‹maxâ€‹lnP(Dâˆ£Î¸1â€‹,â‹¯,Î¸kâ€‹)

where lnâ¡P(Dâˆ£Î¸1,â‹¯â€‰,Î¸k)=lnâ¡âˆj=1nf(xj)=âˆ‘j=1nlnâ¡f(xjs)\ln P(\mathbf D|\theta_1,\cdots,\theta_k)=\ln\prod_{j=1}^nf(\mathbf x_j)=\sum_{j=1}^n\ln f(\mathbf x_js)lnP(Dâˆ£Î¸1â€‹,â‹¯,Î¸kâ€‹)=lnâˆj=1nâ€‹f(xjâ€‹)=âˆ‘j=1nâ€‹lnf(xjâ€‹s)

=âˆ‘j=1nâˆ‘i=1klnâ¡f(xjâˆ£Î¼i,Î£i)P(Ci)=\sum_{j=1}^n\sum_{i=1}^k\ln f(x_j|\mu_i,\Sigma_i)P(C_i)=âˆ‘j=1nâ€‹âˆ‘i=1kâ€‹lnf(xjâ€‹âˆ£Î¼iâ€‹,Î£iâ€‹)P(Ciâ€‹)

EM algorithm

  1. Assume we have already computed the parameters Î¸1,â‹¯â€‰,Î¸k\theta_1,\cdots,\theta_kÎ¸1â€‹,â‹¯,Î¸kâ€‹
  2. Compute the probability of each cluster conditioned to each point
  3. Update the parameters Î¸1,â‹¯â€‰,Î¸k\theta_1,\cdots,\theta_kÎ¸1â€‹,â‹¯,Î¸kâ€‹.

Pros and Cons

Advantages ğŸ‘

  • Flexible and powerful probabilistic model
  • Captures overlapping clusters

Disadvantages ğŸ‘

  • Convergence to local minimum
  • Computation effort O(nkt)O(nkt)O(nkt)
  • Both result and runtime strongly depend on
    • initial assignment
    • a proper choice of parameter kkk
  • Modification to obtain a partitioning variant

entry.title: éšæœºç®—æ³• 2 Probabilistic Inequalities, Hashing with Chaining
entry.content:
This time: Kasper Green Larsen

No slides!

Basic Probabilistic Inequalities

The Dictionary Problem: set SSS of nnn keys: x1,â‹¯â€‰,xnx_1,\cdots,x_nx1â€‹,â‹¯,xnâ€‹ from a universe [U]={0,â‹¯â€‰,Uâˆ’1}[U]=\{0,\cdots,U-1\}[U]={0,â‹¯,Uâˆ’1}. Goal: To store SSS in a data structure s.t., given a query element xâˆˆ[U]x\in[U]xâˆˆ[U], we can quickly determine whether xâˆˆSx\in SxâˆˆS.

Hashing with Chaining: A data structure solves the dictionary problems: Construct an array AAA with mmm entries, denoted A[0],â‹¯â€‰,A[mâˆ’1]A[0],\cdots,A[m-1]A[0],â‹¯,A[mâˆ’1].

  • Each array entry stores an initially empty linked list.

  • Denote the list stored at entry iii by List(A[i])List(A[i])List(A[i]).

  • Pick a random hash function h:[U]â†’[m]h:[U]\rightarrow[m]h:[U]â†’[m]

    Assumption: hhh is truly random and can be evaluated in constant time, i.e.,

    1. âˆ€\forallâˆ€ set of distinct elements {x1,â‹¯â€‰,xk}âŠ†[U]\{x_1,\cdots,x_k\}\subseteq[U]{x1â€‹,â‹¯,xkâ€‹}âŠ†[U] and âˆ€\forallâˆ€ set of values v1,â‹¯â€‰,vkâˆˆ[m]v_1,\cdots,v_k\in[m]v1â€‹,â‹¯,vkâ€‹âˆˆ[m], we have \Pr_h[h(x_1)=v_1\and\cdots\and h(x_k)=v_k]=\frac{1}{m^k}.
    2. we can compute h(x)h(x)h(x) in O(1)O(1)O(1) time.

  • After choosing hhh, we process x1,â‹¯â€‰,xnx_1,\cdots,x_nx1â€‹,â‹¯,xnâ€‹ of SSS. For element xix_ixiâ€‹, we compute h(xi)h(x_i)h(xiâ€‹) and append xix_ixiâ€‹ to the list List(A[h(xi)])List(A[h(x_i)])List(A[h(xiâ€‹)]).

  • To answer whether an element xxx is in SSS, we simply compute h(x)h(x)h(x) and scan through the list List(A[h(x)])List(A[h(x)])List(A[h(x)]) to see if it is there.

  • Space: O(m+n)O(m+n)O(m+n).

Linearity of Expectation

Analyze the expected query time of hashing in chaining.

The work spend when answering the query xxx is proportional to the number of elements from SSS also stored in List(A[h(x)])List(A[h(x)])List(A[h(x)]).

Bad idea: compute E[List(A[h(x)])]\mathbb E[List(A[h(x)])]E[List(A[h(x)])] directly: (Too hard)

=âˆ‘i=0niâ‹…Prâ¡{i=List(A[h(x)])}=âˆ‘i=0niâ‹…(1m)i(1âˆ’1m)nâˆ’iCni=\sum_{i=0}^ni\cdot\Pr\{i=List(A[h(x)])\}\\=\sum_{i=0}^ni\cdot(\frac{1}{m})^i(1-\frac{1}{m})^{n-i}C_n^i=i=0âˆ‘nâ€‹iâ‹…Pr{i=List(A[h(x)])}=i=0âˆ‘nâ€‹iâ‹…(m1â€‹)i(1âˆ’m1â€‹)nâˆ’iCniâ€‹

Good idea: break down XXX.

Random variable XiX_iXiâ€‹ for each xix_ixiâ€‹, if h(xi)=h(x),Xi=1h(x_i)=h(x), X_i=1h(xiâ€‹)=h(x),Xiâ€‹=1, else Xi=0X_i=0Xiâ€‹=0.

The expected query time is O(Eh[âˆ‘iXi])O(\mathbb E_h[\sum_iX_i])O(Ehâ€‹[âˆ‘iâ€‹Xiâ€‹])

Definition of expectation: E[X]=âˆ‘xâˆˆXPr[X=x]â‹…x\mathbb E[X]=\sum_{x\in X}Pr[X=x]\cdot xE[X]=âˆ‘xâˆˆXâ€‹Pr[X=x]â‹…x

Linearity of expectation: E[âˆ‘ixi]=âˆ‘iE[xi]\mathbb E[\sum_ix_i]=\sum_i\mathbb E[x_i]E[âˆ‘iâ€‹xiâ€‹]=âˆ‘iâ€‹E[xiâ€‹]

Thus, by linearity of expectation,

Eh[âˆ‘iXi]=âˆ‘iEh[Xi]Eh[Xi]=Prâ¡[h(xi)=h(x)]â‹…1+Prâ¡[h(xi)â‰ h(x)]â‹…0=Prâ¡[h(xi)=h(x)]\mathbb E_h[\sum_iX_i]=\sum_i\mathbb E_h[X_i]\\\mathbb E_h[X_i]=\Pr[h(x_i)=h(x)]\cdot1+\Pr[h(x_i)\neq h(x)]\cdot0\\=\Pr[h(x_i)=h(x)]Ehâ€‹[iâˆ‘â€‹Xiâ€‹]=iâˆ‘â€‹Ehâ€‹[Xiâ€‹]Ehâ€‹[Xiâ€‹]=Pr[h(xiâ€‹)=h(x)]â‹…1+Pr[h(xiâ€‹)î€ =h(x)]â‹…0=Pr[h(xiâ€‹)=h(x)]

if xi=x,Prâ¡[h(xi)=h(x)]=1x_i=x,\Pr[h(x_i)=h(x)]=1xiâ€‹=x,Pr[h(xiâ€‹)=h(x)]=1. if xiâ‰ x,Prâ¡[h(xi)=h(x)]=1mx_i\neq x,\Pr[h(x_i)=h(x)]=\frac{1}{m}xiâ€‹î€ =x,Pr[h(xiâ€‹)=h(x)]=m1â€‹.

Thus,

âˆ‘iEh[Xi]â‰¤1+âˆ‘i:xiâ‰ xEh[Xi]â‰¤1+nm\sum_i\mathbb E_h[X_i]\le1+\sum_{i:x_i\neq x}\mathbb E_h[X_i]\le1+\frac{n}{m}iâˆ‘â€‹Ehâ€‹[Xiâ€‹]â‰¤1+i:xiâ€‹î€ =xâˆ‘â€‹Ehâ€‹[Xiâ€‹]â‰¤1+mnâ€‹

choose m=Î˜(n)m=\Theta(n)m=Î˜(n), then query time is O(1)O(1)O(1) and space usage is O(n)O(n)O(n).

Linearity of expectation is also valid if random variables are not independent!!!

Markovâ€™s Inequality

Let XXX be a non-negative discrete random variable. âˆ€t>0\forall t\gt0âˆ€t>0, we have Prâ¡[x>t]<E[X]t\Pr[x\gt t]\lt\frac{\mathbb E[X]}{t}Pr[x>t]<tE[X]â€‹ and Prâ¡[xâ‰¥t]â‰¤E[X]t\Pr[x\ge t]\le\frac{\mathbb E[X]}{t}Pr[xâ‰¥t]â‰¤tE[X]â€‹

Proof for continuous version

E[X]=âˆ«0âˆxf(x)dxâˆ€t>0,E[X]â‰¥âˆ«tâˆxf(x)dxâ‰¥âˆ«tâˆtf(x)dx=tâˆ«tâˆf(x)dx=tâ‹…Prâ¡(Xâ‰¥t)\mathbb E[X]=\int_0^\infty xf(x)dx\\\forall t>0,\mathbb E[X]\ge\int_t^\infty xf(x)dx\\\ge\int_t^\infty tf(x)dx=t\int_t^\infty f(x)dx=t\cdot\Pr(X\ge t)E[X]=âˆ«0âˆâ€‹xf(x)dxâˆ€t>0,E[X]â‰¥âˆ«tâˆâ€‹xf(x)dxâ‰¥âˆ«tâˆâ€‹tf(x)dx=tâˆ«tâˆâ€‹f(x)dx=tâ‹…Pr(Xâ‰¥t)

Conclusion: If we insert nnn elements into hashing with chaining data structure and then ask one query xxx, then the linked list List(A[h(x)])List(A[h(x)])List(A[h(x)]) that we have to scan through contains more than t(1+nm)t(1+\frac{n}{m})t(1+mnâ€‹) elements with probability less than 1t1\over tt1â€‹.

Prâ¡[X>t(1+nm)]<E[X]t(1+nm)â‰¤1+nmt(1+nm)=1t\Pr[X\gt t(1+\frac{n}{m})]\lt\frac{\mathbb E[X]}{t(1+\frac{n}{m})}\le\frac{1+\frac{n}{m}}{t(1+\frac{n}{m})}=\frac{1}{t}Pr[X>t(1+mnâ€‹)]<t(1+mnâ€‹)E[X]â€‹â‰¤t(1+mnâ€‹)1+mnâ€‹â€‹=t1â€‹

Markovâ€™s Inequality gives a loose bound: Prâ¡[List(A[h(x)])=n]â‰¤(1+n/m)/n=O(1/n)(m=Î˜(n))\Pr[List(A[h(x)])=n] \le(1+n/m)/n=O(1/n)(m=\Theta(n))Pr[List(A[h(x)])=n]â‰¤(1+n/m)/n=O(1/n)(m=Î˜(n))

Chernoff Bound

ğŸ˜°ğŸ˜°ğŸ˜°What the hell is this?!

Introducing random variable YjY_jYjâ€‹: Yj=1Y_j=1Yjâ€‹=1 if h(xj)=ih(x_j)=ih(xjâ€‹)=i else Yj=0Y_j=0Yjâ€‹=0.

We have âˆ£List(A[i])âˆ£=âˆ‘jYj|List(A[i])|=\sum_jY_jâˆ£List(A[i])âˆ£=âˆ‘jâ€‹Yjâ€‹.

YjY_jYjâ€‹s are independent and E[Yj]=1m\mathbb E[Y_j]=\frac{1}{m}E[Yjâ€‹]=m1â€‹.

Chernoff Bound: Let {Xi}\{X_i\}{Xiâ€‹} be a set of independent boolean random variables and let X=âˆ‘iXiX=\sum_iX_iX=âˆ‘iâ€‹Xiâ€‹. Then,

âˆ€Î¼â‰¤E[X],âˆ€0<Î´<1\forall\mu\le\mathbb E[X],\forall0\lt\delta\lt1âˆ€Î¼â‰¤E[X],âˆ€0<Î´<1 we have

Prâ¡[X<(1âˆ’Î´)Î¼]<eâˆ’Î´2Î¼2\Pr[X\lt(1-\delta)\mu]\lt e^{-\frac{\delta^2\mu}{2}}Pr[X<(1âˆ’Î´)Î¼]<eâˆ’2Î´2Î¼â€‹

âˆ€Î¼â‰¥E[X],âˆ€0<Î´<1\forall\mu\ge\mathbb E[X],\forall0\lt\delta\lt1âˆ€Î¼â‰¥E[X],âˆ€0<Î´<1 we have

Prâ¡[X>(1+Î´)Î¼]<eâˆ’Î´2Î¼3\Pr[X\gt(1+\delta)\mu]\lt e^{-\frac{\delta^2\mu}{3}}Pr[X>(1+Î´)Î¼]<eâˆ’3Î´2Î¼â€‹

Finally, âˆ€Î´â‰¥1,âˆ€Î¼â‰¥E[X]\forall\delta\ge1,\forall\mu\ge\mathbb E[X]âˆ€Î´â‰¥1,âˆ€Î¼â‰¥E[X], we have

Prâ¡[X>(1+Î´)Î¼]<(eÎ´(1+Î´)1+Î´)Î¼\Pr[X\gt(1+\delta)\mu]\lt(\frac{e^\delta}{(1+\delta)^{1+\delta}})^\muPr[X>(1+Î´)Î¼]<((1+Î´)1+Î´eÎ´â€‹)Î¼

We have E[Y]=nm\mathbb E[Y]=\frac{n}{m}E[Y]=mnâ€‹, âˆ€Î´â‰¥1\forall\delta\ge1âˆ€Î´â‰¥1, we have Chernoff Bound:

Prâ¡[Y>(1+Î´)nm]<(eÎ´(1+Î´)1+Î´)nm\Pr[Y\gt(1+\delta)\frac{n}{m}]\lt(\frac{e^\delta}{(1+\delta)^{1+\delta}})^{\frac{n}{m}}Pr[Y>(1+Î´)mnâ€‹]<((1+Î´)1+Î´eÎ´â€‹)mnâ€‹

Application in our scenario: m=n,t=(1+Î´)â‰¥2,Î¼=E[Y]=nm=O(1)m=n,t=(1+\delta)\ge2,\mu=\mathbb E[Y]={n\over m}=O(1)m=n,t=(1+Î´)â‰¥2,Î¼=E[Y]=mnâ€‹=O(1):

Prâ¡[âˆ£List(A[i])âˆ£>t]=Prâ¡[Y>t]<etâˆ’1tt<(et)t\Pr[|List(A[i])|\gt t]=\Pr[Y\gt t]\lt\frac{e^{t-1}}{t^t}\lt(\frac{e}{t})^tPr[âˆ£List(A[i])âˆ£>t]=Pr[Y>t]<ttetâˆ’1â€‹<(teâ€‹)t

Conclusion: we spend more than O(t)O(t)O(t) time with probability decreasing as fast as tâˆ’tt^{-t}tâˆ’t.

Proof of Chernoff Bound

By Markovâ€™s inequality,

âˆ€t>0:Prâ¡(x>a)=Prâ¡(etX>eta)<E[etX]etaDenoteÂ MX(t)=E[etX],MX(t)=âˆi=1nMXi(t)MX(t)=pet+(1âˆ’p)=1+p(etâˆ’1)â‰¤ep(etâˆ’1)âˆ´Prâ¡(X>(1+Î´)Î¼)<E[etX]et(1+Î´)Î¼=âˆi=1nMXi(t)et(1+Î´)Î¼â‰¤e(etâˆ’1)âˆ‘ipiet(1+Î´)Î¼=e(etâˆ’1)E[X]et(1+Î´)Î¼â‰¤[eetâˆ’1et(1+Î´)]Î¼\forall t\gt0:\Pr(x\gt a)=\Pr(e^{tX}\gt e^{ta})\lt\frac{\mathbb E[e^{tX}]}{e^{ta}}\\\text{Denote }M_X(t)=\mathbb E[e^{tX}], M_X(t)=\prod_{i=1}^nM_{X_i}(t)\\M_X(t)=pe^t+(1-p)=1+p(e^t-1)\le e^{p(e^t-1)}\\\therefore\Pr(X\gt(1+\delta)\mu)\lt\frac{\mathbb E[e^{tX}]}{e^{t(1+\delta)\mu}}=\frac{\prod_{i=1}^nM_{X_i}(t)}{e^{t(1+\delta)\mu}}\\\le\frac{e^{(e^t-1)\sum_ip_i}}{e^{t(1+\delta)\mu}}=\frac{e^{(e^t-1)\mathbb E[X]}}{e^{t(1+\delta)\mu}}\le[\frac{e^{e^t-1}}{e^{t(1+\delta)}}]^\mu\\âˆ€t>0:Pr(x>a)=Pr(etX>eta)<etaE[etX]â€‹DenoteÂ MXâ€‹(t)=E[etX],MXâ€‹(t)=i=1âˆnâ€‹MXiâ€‹â€‹(t)MXâ€‹(t)=pet+(1âˆ’p)=1+p(etâˆ’1)â‰¤ep(etâˆ’1)âˆ´Pr(X>(1+Î´)Î¼)<et(1+Î´)Î¼E[etX]â€‹=et(1+Î´)Î¼âˆi=1nâ€‹MXiâ€‹â€‹(t)â€‹â‰¤et(1+Î´)Î¼e(etâˆ’1)âˆ‘iâ€‹piâ€‹â€‹=et(1+Î´)Î¼e(etâˆ’1)E[X]â€‹â‰¤[et(1+Î´)eetâˆ’1â€‹]Î¼

Let t=lnâ¡(1+Î´)â‰¥0t=\ln(1+\delta)\ge0t=ln(1+Î´)â‰¥0, we have:

Prâ¡[X>(1+Î´)Î¼]<(eÎ´(1+Î´)1+Î´)Î¼â‡’lnâ¡[(eÎ´(1+Î´)1+Î´)Î¼]=Î¼(Î´âˆ’(1+Î´)lnâ¡(1+Î´))âˆµâˆ€xâ‰¥0,lnâ¡(1+x)â‰¥x1+x2âˆ´Î¼(Î´âˆ’(1+Î´)lnâ¡(1+Î´))â‰¤âˆ’Î´22+Î´Î¼<âˆ’Î¼Î´23(âˆµ0<Î´<1)Prâ¡[X>(1+Î´)Î¼]<eâˆ’Î´2Î¼3(0<Î´<1)\Pr[X\gt(1+\delta)\mu]\lt(\frac{e^\delta}{(1+\delta)^{1+\delta}})^\mu\\\Rightarrow\ln[(\frac{e^\delta}{(1+\delta)^{1+\delta}})^\mu]=\mu(\delta-(1+\delta)\ln(1+\delta))\\\because\forall x\ge0,\ln(1+x)\ge\frac{x}{1+\frac{x}{2}}\\\therefore\mu(\delta-(1+\delta)\ln(1+\delta))\le-\frac{\delta^2}{2+\delta}\mu\\\lt-\frac{\mu\delta^2}{3}(\because0\lt\delta\lt1)\\\Pr[X\gt(1+\delta)\mu]\lt e^{-\frac{\delta^2\mu}{3}}(0\lt\delta\lt1)Pr[X>(1+Î´)Î¼]<((1+Î´)1+Î´eÎ´â€‹)Î¼â‡’ln[((1+Î´)1+Î´eÎ´â€‹)Î¼]=Î¼(Î´âˆ’(1+Î´)ln(1+Î´))âˆµâˆ€xâ‰¥0,ln(1+x)â‰¥1+2xâ€‹xâ€‹âˆ´Î¼(Î´âˆ’(1+Î´)ln(1+Î´))â‰¤âˆ’2+Î´Î´2â€‹Î¼<âˆ’3Î¼Î´2â€‹(âˆµ0<Î´<1)Pr[X>(1+Î´)Î¼]<eâˆ’3Î´2Î¼â€‹(0<Î´<1)

Analogously, we have

âˆ€t>0:Prâ¡(x<a)=Prâ¡(eâˆ’tX>eâˆ’ta)<E[eâˆ’tX]eâˆ’taâ‡’â‹¯â‡’â‹¯â‡’Prâ¡[X<(1âˆ’Î´)Î¼]<(eeâˆ’tâˆ’1eâˆ’t(1âˆ’Î´))Î¼(âˆ—âˆ—)\forall t\gt0:\Pr(x\lt a)=\Pr(e^{-tX}\gt e^{-ta})\lt\frac{\mathbb E[e^{-tX}]}{e^{-ta}}\\\Rarr\cdots\Rarr\cdots\\\Rarr\Pr[X\lt(1-\delta)\mu]\lt(\frac{e^{e^{-t}-1}}{e^{-t(1-\delta)}})^\mu(**)\\âˆ€t>0:Pr(x<a)=Pr(eâˆ’tX>eâˆ’ta)<eâˆ’taE[eâˆ’tX]â€‹â‡’â‹¯â‡’â‹¯â‡’Pr[X<(1âˆ’Î´)Î¼]<(eâˆ’t(1âˆ’Î´)eeâˆ’tâˆ’1â€‹)Î¼(âˆ—âˆ—)

Let t=âˆ’lnâ¡(1âˆ’Î´)>0t=-\ln(1-\delta)\gt0t=âˆ’ln(1âˆ’Î´)>0,

(âˆ—âˆ—)=(eâˆ’Î´(1âˆ’Î´)1âˆ’Î´)Î¼(âˆ—)âˆµâˆ€0<Î´<1,(1âˆ’Î´)lnâ¡(1âˆ’Î´)>âˆ’Î´+Î´22âˆ´(âˆ—)â‰¤(eâˆ’Î´eâˆ’Î´+Î´22)Î¼=eâˆ’Î´2Î¼2â‡’Prâ¡[X<(1âˆ’Î´)Î¼]<eâˆ’Î´2Î¼2(**)=(\frac{e^{-\delta}}{(1-\delta)^{1-\delta}})^\mu(*)\\\because \forall0\lt\delta\lt1,(1-\delta)\ln(1-\delta)\gt-\delta+\frac{\delta^2}{2}\\\therefore(*)\le(\frac{e^{-\delta}}{e^{-\delta+\frac{\delta^2}{2}}})^\mu=e^{-\frac{\delta^2\mu}{2}}\\\Rightarrow\Pr[X\lt(1-\delta)\mu]\lt e^{-\frac{\delta^2\mu}{2}}(âˆ—âˆ—)=((1âˆ’Î´)1âˆ’Î´eâˆ’Î´â€‹)Î¼(âˆ—)âˆµâˆ€0<Î´<1,(1âˆ’Î´)ln(1âˆ’Î´)>âˆ’Î´+2Î´2â€‹âˆ´(âˆ—)â‰¤(eâˆ’Î´+2Î´2â€‹eâˆ’Î´â€‹)Î¼=eâˆ’2Î´2Î¼â€‹â‡’Pr[X<(1âˆ’Î´)Î¼]<eâˆ’2Î´2Î¼â€‹

Union Bound

Let {Ei}\{E_i\}{Eiâ€‹} be events, then

Prâ¡[â‹ƒiEi]â‰¤âˆ‘iPrâ¡[Ei]\Pr[\bigcup_iE_i]\le\sum_i\Pr[E_i]Pr[iâ‹ƒâ€‹Eiâ€‹]â‰¤iâˆ‘â€‹Pr[Eiâ€‹]

If we define EiE_iEiâ€‹ as event that âˆ£List(A[i])âˆ£>4lnâ¡nlnâ¡lnâ¡n|List(A[i])|\gt4\frac{\ln n}{\ln\ln n}âˆ£List(A[i])âˆ£>4lnlnnlnnâ€‹, then by Chernoff Bound,

Prâ¡[Ei]<((e/4)lnâ¡lnâ¡n/lnâ¡n)4lnâ¡n/lnâ¡lnâ¡n<(lnâ¡lnâ¡n/lnâ¡n)4lnâ¡n/lnâ¡lnâ¡n\Pr[E_i]\lt((e/4)\ln\ln n/\ln n)^{4\ln n/\ln\ln n}\lt(\ln\ln n/\ln n)^{4\ln n/\ln\ln n}Pr[Eiâ€‹]<((e/4)lnlnn/lnn)4lnn/lnlnn<(lnlnn/lnn)4lnn/lnlnn

(n>3>en\gt3\gt en>3>e is needed!)

ğŸ˜²CRAZY MATH!!!

âˆµlnâ¡lnâ¡nâ‰¤lnâ¡nâˆ´(lnâ¡lnâ¡nlnâ¡n)4lnâ¡nlnâ¡lnâ¡nâ‰¤(lnâ¡nlnâ¡n)4lnâ¡nlnâ¡lnâ¡n=(lnâ¡n)âˆ’2lnâ¡nlnâ¡lnâ¡n=(elnâ¡lnâ¡n)âˆ’2lnâ¡nlnâ¡lnâ¡n=eâˆ’2lnâ¡nlnâ¡lnâ¡nâ‹…lnâ¡lnâ¡n=nâˆ’2\because \ln\ln n\le\sqrt{\ln n}\\\therefore(\frac{\ln\ln n}{\ln n})^{\frac{4\ln n}{\ln\ln n}}\le(\frac{\sqrt{\ln n}}{\ln n})^{\frac{4\ln n}{\ln\ln n}}=(\ln n)^{-\frac{2\ln n}{\ln\ln n}}\\=(e^{\ln\ln n})^{-2\frac{\ln n}{\ln\ln n}}=e^{-2\frac{\ln n}{\ln\ln n}\cdot\ln\ln n}=n^{-2}âˆµlnlnnâ‰¤lnnâ€‹âˆ´(lnnlnlnnâ€‹)lnlnn4lnnâ€‹â‰¤(lnnlnnâ€‹â€‹)lnlnn4lnnâ€‹=(lnn)âˆ’lnlnn2lnnâ€‹=(elnlnn)âˆ’2lnlnnlnnâ€‹=eâˆ’2lnlnnlnnâ€‹â‹…lnlnn=nâˆ’2

By union bound, we have

Prâ¡[â‹ƒiEi]â‰¤âˆ‘inâˆ’2=nâˆ’1\Pr[\bigcup_iE_i]\le\sum_in^{-2}=n^{-1}Pr[iâ‹ƒâ€‹Eiâ€‹]â‰¤iâˆ‘â€‹nâˆ’2=nâˆ’1

This means with probability 1âˆ’1n1-\frac{1}{n}1âˆ’n1â€‹, there is not even a single list List(A[i])List(A[i])List(A[i]) with size more than 4lnâ¡nlnâ¡lnâ¡n4\frac{\ln n}{\ln\ln n}4lnlnnlnnâ€‹, assuming (nâ‰¥3)(n\ge3)(nâ‰¥3).

In this case, the worst case query time of the data structure is O(logâ¡nlogâ¡logâ¡n)O(\frac{\log n}{\log\log n})O(loglognlognâ€‹)

Hashing with Chaining with m=nm=nm=n, the worst query time is O(logâ¡nlogâ¡logâ¡n)O(\frac{\log n}{\log\log n})O(loglognlognâ€‹) with probability 1âˆ’1n1-\frac{1}{n}1âˆ’n1â€‹ when hhh is truly random.

The construction time is O(n)O(n)O(n) and the space is O(n)O(n)O(n).

Worst Case

After insert x1,â‹¯â€‰,xnx_1,\cdots,x_nx1â€‹,â‹¯,xnâ€‹, one of the list exceeds 4lnâ¡nlnâ¡lnâ¡n4\frac{\ln n}{\ln\ln n}4lnlnnlnnâ€‹, then we discard the current data structure and try again with a freshly chosen hhh.

This performs at least iii iterations with probability no more than (1n)iâˆ’1(\frac{1}{n})^{i-1}(n1â€‹)iâˆ’1, thus the expected construction time is upper bounded by

âˆ‘i=1âˆ(1/n)iâˆ’1â‹…O(n)=O(n)\sum_{i=1}^\infty(1/n)^{i-1}\cdot O(n)=O(n)i=1âˆ‘âˆâ€‹(1/n)iâˆ’1â‹…O(n)=O(n)

We have thus achieved a worst case query time of O(logâ¡n/logâ¡logâ¡n)O(\log n/\log\log n)O(logn/loglogn) with space O(n)O(n)O(n) and expected construction time O(n)O(n)O(n).

O-Notation

ä¸­æ–‡ä¸­æœ‰ä¸ªå¾ˆå¥½çš„å¯¹åº”æ¦‚å¿µâ€æ•°é‡çº§â€œ

For two functions f:Râ†’R,g:Râ†’Rf:\mathbb R\rightarrow\mathbb R,g:\mathbb R\rightarrow\mathbb Rf:Râ†’R,g:Râ†’R, we can write f(n)=O(g(n))f(n)=O(g(n))f(n)=O(g(n)) if:

  • There exists a constants n0âˆˆRn_0\in\mathbb Rn0â€‹âˆˆR and c>0c\gt0c>0, s.t. âˆ€n>n0\forall n\gt n_0âˆ€n>n0â€‹, we have f(n)â‰¤câ‹…g(n)f(n)\le c\cdot g(n)f(n)â‰¤câ‹…g(n).

    e.g. n3/6âˆ’n2/2=O(n3)n^3/6-n^2/2=O(n^3)n3/6âˆ’n2/2=O(n3)

Sum of same magnitude. if âˆ€i=1,â‹¯â€‰,k,fi(n)=O(g(n))\forall i=1,\cdots,k,f_i(n)=O(g(n))âˆ€i=1,â‹¯,k,fiâ€‹(n)=O(g(n)), then âˆ‘i=1kfi(n)=O(g(n))\sum_{i=1}^kf_i(n)=O(g(n))âˆ‘i=1kâ€‹fiâ€‹(n)=O(g(n))

Constants donâ€™t matter!

Products. if f(n)=O(h(n)),g(n)=O(l(n))f(n)=O(h(n)),g(n)=O(l(n))f(n)=O(h(n)),g(n)=O(l(n)) then

f(n)g(n)=O(h(n)l(n))f(n)g(n)=O(h(n)l(n))f(n)g(n)=O(h(n)l(n))

Base of Logs. The base of logarithms donâ€™t matter! We only use f(n)=O(logâ¡n)f(n)=O(\log n)f(n)=O(logn).

Careful with exponents!!! 2logâ¡2n=O(logâ¡n)2\log_2n=O(\log n)2log2â€‹n=O(logn), but 22logâ¡2n=O(n2)2^{2\log_2n}=O(n^2)22log2â€‹n=O(n2)

1b/3 Was erfahren Sie Ã¼ber Fahim Yusufzai?

  • die im Einkaufszentrum erwischten Jugendlichen kÃ¶nnen wÃ¤hlen, ob er sie zur Polizei bringt oder ob sie zu ihm in den Verein kommen

1d Wie finden Sie dieses Projekt?

4-5 Armut

die Armut-/ è´«ç©·ï¼Œè´«å›°

Unter Armut verstehe ich, von wichtigen Dingen genug zu haben oder ganz verzichten zu mÃ¼ssen.

Wer arm ist, hat zum Beispiel zu wenig Geld, um sich Essen oder ein Zuhause zu leisten.

Und es gibt verschiedene Formen von Armut: absolute, relative Armut sowie Kinderarmut oder Altersarmut.

Absolute Armut bedeutet, dass ein Mensch aus materiellen GrÃ¼nden nicht in der Lage ist, seine GrundbedÃ¼rfnisse zu befriedigen.

Die Weltbank definiert einen Menschen als extrem arm, wenn ihm pro Tag weniger als 1,90 US-Dollar zur VerfÃ¼gung stehen.

entry.title: å…¬å¹³åˆ†é… 1 Survey Study
entry.content:
åœ¨å’Œæ‰¬å°¼æ–¯æ•™æˆäº¤æµåï¼Œæˆ‘ç¡®å®šäº† 24 Spring è¿™ 10 ECT çš„ Projektarbejde i Datalogi çš„å…·ä½“æ–¹å‘ä¸ºâ€œä¸å¯åˆ†å‰²ç‰©å“çš„å…¬å¹³åˆ†é…åšå¼ˆâ€ Fair Division with Indivisible Items

ç¾ç¾è€ƒå®Œç®—æ³•åšå¼ˆè®ºï¼Œä»æ‰¬å°¼æ–¯æ•™æˆè¿™æ‹¿äº† 12 åˆ†ä¹‹åï¼Œæˆ‘å°±å¾—å¼€æ Projekt äº†ã€‚

Objective

Gain familiarity with fairness notions and key results in fair division with indivisible items.

Fairness Notions

Denotation

Set NNN of nnn agents

Set MMM of mmm indivisible goods

For agent iii:

  • Valuation function vi:2Mâ†’Râ‰¥0v_i:2^M\rightarrow\mathbb R_{\ge0}viâ€‹:2Mâ†’Râ‰¥0â€‹.

    vi(âˆ…)=0,vi(S)â‰¤vi(T)âˆ€SâŠ†TâŠ†Mv_i(\emptyset)=0,v_i(S)\le v_i(T)\forall S\subseteq T\subseteq Mviâ€‹(âˆ…)=0,viâ€‹(S)â‰¤viâ€‹(T)âˆ€SâŠ†TâŠ†M

    Assume valuation function are additive vi(S)=â‹ƒgâˆˆSvi(g)v_i(S)=\bigcup_{g\in S}v_i(g)viâ€‹(S)=â‹ƒgâˆˆSâ€‹viâ€‹(g) (My question: Does this imply single parameter environment? Why?)

Allocation instance I=(N,M,v)I=(N,M,v)I=(N,M,v), v=(v1,â‹¯â€‰,vn)v=(v_1,\cdots,v_n)v=(v1â€‹,â‹¯,vnâ€‹) is the vector of valuation functions.

Allocation A=(A1,â‹¯â€‰,An)A=(A_1,\cdots,A_n)A=(A1â€‹,â‹¯,Anâ€‹) s. t. each agent iii receive the bundle AiâŠ†MA_i\subseteq MAiâ€‹âŠ†M, Aiâˆ©Aj=âˆ…âˆ€iâ‰ jA_i\cap A_j=\emptyset\forall i\neq jAiâ€‹âˆ©Ajâ€‹=âˆ…âˆ€iî€ =j, â‹ƒiâˆˆNAi=M\bigcup_{i\in N}A_i=Mâ‹ƒiâˆˆNâ€‹Aiâ€‹=M.

If â‹ƒiâˆˆNAiâŠŠM\bigcup_{i\in N}A_i\subsetneq Mâ‹ƒiâˆˆNâ€‹Aiâ€‹âŠŠM, the allocation is called partial.

Familiy of Envy-freeness

Envy-freeness

AAA is EF if âˆ€i,jâˆˆN\forall i,j\in Nâˆ€i,jâˆˆN, vi(Ai)â‰¥vi(Aj)v_i(A_i)\ge v_i(A_j)viâ€‹(Aiâ€‹)â‰¥viâ€‹(Ajâ€‹).

Deciding whether an instance admits EF is NP-complete.

EF is not always exist.

Envy-freeness up to one good

EF1, a relaxation of EF.

AAA is EF1 if âˆ€i,jâˆˆN\forall i,j\in Nâˆ€i,jâˆˆN, vi(Ai)â‰¥vi(Ajâ•²{g})v_i(A_i)\ge v_i(A_j\diagdown\{g\})viâ€‹(Aiâ€‹)â‰¥viâ€‹(Ajâ€‹â•²{g}) for some gâˆˆAjg\in A_jgâˆˆAjâ€‹.

Very weak notion: ggg maybe high-valued.

My difinition: AAA is EF1 if âˆ€i,jâˆˆN,vi(Ai)â‰¥vi(Aiâ•²{g})\forall i,j\in N,v_i(A_i)\ge v_i(A_i\diagdown\{g\})âˆ€i,jâˆˆN,viâ€‹(Aiâ€‹)â‰¥viâ€‹(Aiâ€‹â•²{g}) for g=argâ¡maxâ¡tâˆˆAjvi(t)g=\arg\max_{t\in A_j}v_i(t)g=argmaxtâˆˆAjâ€‹â€‹viâ€‹(t)

Computing EF1

Round Robin Algoithm

Envy-Cycle elimination

EF1 and Pareto Optimality

MNW allocation: an allocation AAA is MNW if

  1. It maximizes number of agents with positive value
  2. It maximizes the Nash welfare (the product of valuation) for agents with positive value.

MNWâ†’\rightarrowâ†’EF1+PO

â“Can EF1+PO be computed in P time?

Envy-freeness up to any good

EFX, a relaxation of EF stricter than EF1.

AAA is EFX if âˆ€i,jâˆˆN\forall i,j\in Nâˆ€i,jâˆˆN, vi(Ai)â‰¥vi(Ajâ•²{g})v_i(A_i)\ge v_i(A_j\diagdown\{g\})viâ€‹(Aiâ€‹)â‰¥viâ€‹(Ajâ€‹â•²{g}) for any gâˆˆAjg\in A_jgâˆˆAjâ€‹.

â“Open problem: The existence of EFX? (nâ‰¥4n\ge4nâ‰¥4? Unrestricted additive valuations?)

My difinition: AAA is EFX if âˆ€i,jâˆˆN,vi(Ai)â‰¥vi(Aiâ•²{g})\forall i,j\in N,v_i(A_i)\ge v_i(A_i\diagdown\{g\})âˆ€i,jâˆˆN,viâ€‹(Aiâ€‹)â‰¥viâ€‹(Aiâ€‹â•²{g}) for g=argâ¡minâ¡tâˆˆAjvi(t)g=\arg\min_{t\in A_j}v_i(t)g=argmintâˆˆAjâ€‹â€‹viâ€‹(t)

Approximately EFX

Î±\alphaÎ±-EFX: Î±âˆˆ[0,1]\alpha\in[0,1]Î±âˆˆ[0,1] if âˆ€i,jâˆˆN\forall i,j\in Nâˆ€i,jâˆˆN, vi(Ai)â‰¥Î±Ã—vi(Ajâ•²{g})v_i(A_i)\ge\alpha\times v_i(A_j\diagdown\{g\})viâ€‹(Aiâ€‹)â‰¥Î±Ã—viâ€‹(Ajâ€‹â•²{g}) for any gâˆˆAjg\in A_jgâˆˆAjâ€‹.

12\frac{1}{2}21â€‹-EFX always exists for sub-additive valuation functions.

Envy-Cycle Elimination algorithm computes 121\over221â€‹-EFX allocations.

â“What is the best possible Î±\alphaÎ± for Î±\alphaÎ±-EFX allocation?

Loose: must allocate all goodsâ†’\rightarrowâ†’allocate part of goods.

â“Is it possible to achieve an exact EFX allocation by donating a sub-linear number of goods?

Other types of Envy-freeness

Envy-freeness up to one less-preferred good. EFL, between EF1 and EFX.

  • EFL always exists, can be computed using a variant of Envy-Cycle Elimination.

Envy-freeness up to a random good. EFR

  • Randomized version.
  • 0.730.730.73-EFR allocation can be computed in polynomial time.

â“Do EFR allocations always exist?

Epistemic Fairness

  • Agents donâ€™t have complete knowledge about allcation.

Familiy of Proportionality

Proportionality

AAA is PROP if âˆ€iâˆˆN\forall i\in Nâˆ€iâˆˆN, vi(Ai)â‰¥vi(M)nv_i(A_i)\ge\frac{v_i(M)}{n}viâ€‹(Aiâ€‹)â‰¥nviâ€‹(M)â€‹.

Obviously EFâ†’\rightarrowâ†’PROP, PROPâ†’Ì¸\not\rightarrowî€ â†’EF.

Deciding whether an instance admits PROP is also NP-complete.

Prop1

Propotionality up to one good

Prop1+PO always exists, can be computed in P time.

PropX

Propotionality up to any good

Can not always be guaranteed.

PropM

Propotionality up to maximin good

Between Prop1 and PropX

The value of a maximin good for iii is di(A)=maxâ¡jâ‰ iminâ¡gâˆˆAjvi(g)d_i(A)=\max_{j\neq i}\min_{g\in A_j}v_i(g)diâ€‹(A)=maxjî€ =iâ€‹mingâˆˆAjâ€‹â€‹viâ€‹(g)

AAA is called PropM if vi(Ai)+di(A)â‰¥vi(M)nv_i(A_i)+d_i(A)\ge\frac{v_i(M)}{n}viâ€‹(Aiâ€‹)+diâ€‹(A)â‰¥nviâ€‹(M)â€‹,

PropM always exists, can be computed in P time.

Maximin Share Fairness

MMS, a relaxation of PROP, is trying to give each agent iii bundles of value at least as her maximin share Î¼in(M)\mu_i^n(M)Î¼inâ€‹(M).

Maximin share is the worst value agent can guarantee for herself by partitioning MMM into nnn disjoint bundles and keeping the worst of them.

Let An(M)\mathcal A_n(M)Anâ€‹(M) be te collection of possible allocations of the goods in MMM to nnn agents.

AAA is MMS if âˆ€iâˆˆN\forall i\in Nâˆ€iâˆˆN:

vi(Ai)â‰¥Î¼in(M)=maxâ¡BâˆˆAn(M)minâ¡SâˆˆBvi(S)v_i(A_i)\ge\mu_i^n(M)=\max_{B\in\mathcal A_n(M)}\min_{S\in B}v_i(S)viâ€‹(Aiâ€‹)â‰¥Î¼inâ€‹(M)=BâˆˆAnâ€‹(M)maxâ€‹SâˆˆBminâ€‹viâ€‹(S)

Computing MMS even Maximin share of an agent is NP-hard.

MMS donâ€™t always exist when there are more than 2 agents.

Approximately MMS

Î±\alphaÎ±-MMS: âˆ€iâˆˆN\forall i\in Nâˆ€iâˆˆN, vi(Ai)â‰¥Î±Ã—Î¼in(M)v_i(A_i)\ge\alpha\times\mu_i^n(M)viâ€‹(Aiâ€‹)â‰¥Î±Ã—Î¼inâ€‹(M)

â“Is it possible to improve upon the bound of 34+112n\frac{3}{4}+\frac{1}{12n}43â€‹+12n1â€‹ for additive valuations? Is there a stronger inapproximability bound than 394039\over404039â€‹?

â“Are there other class of structured valuations for which MMS is guaranteed to exist?

PMMS

Pairwise maximin share fairness

âˆ€i,jâˆˆN,vi(Ai)â‰¥maxâ¡Aiâ€²âˆªAjâ€²=AiâˆªAjminâ¡{vi(Aiâ€²),vi(Ajâ€²)}\forall i,j\in N,v_i(A_i)\ge\max_{A_i'\cup A_j'=A_i\cup A_j}\min\{v_i(A_i'),v_i(A_j')\}âˆ€i,jâˆˆN,viâ€‹(Aiâ€‹)â‰¥Aiâ€²â€‹âˆªAjâ€²â€‹=Aiâ€‹âˆªAjâ€‹maxâ€‹min{viâ€‹(Aiâ€²â€‹),viâ€‹(Ajâ€²â€‹)}

Î±\alphaÎ±-PMMS

â“Do PMMS allocations always exist?

GMMS

Groupwise maximin share fairness

Î±\alphaÎ±-GMMS: if âˆ€iâˆˆN\forall i\in Nâˆ€iâˆˆN, vi(Ai)â‰¥Î±â‹…GMMSiv_i(A_i)\ge\alpha\cdot\text{GMMS}_iviâ€‹(Aiâ€‹)â‰¥Î±â‹…GMMSiâ€‹

GMMSi=maxâ¡SâŠ†N:iâˆˆSÎ¼iâˆ£Sâˆ£(â‹ƒjâˆˆSAj)\text{GMMS}_i=\max_{S\subseteq N:i\in S}\mu_i^{|S|}(\bigcup_{j\in S}A_j)GMMSiâ€‹=SâŠ†N:iâˆˆSmaxâ€‹Î¼iâˆ£Sâˆ£â€‹(jâˆˆSâ‹ƒâ€‹Ajâ€‹)

Best known: 474\over774â€‹-GMMS

â“Whatâ€™s the best possibe Î±\alphaÎ± for Î±\alphaÎ±-GMMS?

Efficiency and Incentives

Fair and Pareto Optimal Allocations

Approximating the Nash Welfare

Price of Fairness

PoF=supâ¡Iminâ¡AâˆˆF(O)OPT(I)SW(A)=maxâ¡DâˆˆDivisionSW(D)maxâ¡SâˆˆFairÂ DivisionSW(S)\text{PoF}=\sup_I\min_{A\in F(O)}\frac{OPT(I)}{SW(A)}\\=\frac{\max_{D\in\text{Division}}SW(D)}{\max_{S\in\text{Fair Division}}SW(S)}PoF=Isupâ€‹AâˆˆF(O)minâ€‹SW(A)OPT(I)â€‹=maxSâˆˆFairÂ Divisionâ€‹SW(S)maxDâˆˆDivisionâ€‹SW(D)â€‹

entry.title: æ•°æ®æŒ–æ˜ 1 Introduction
entry.content:
Brief Introduction to This Course

3 Modules

  1. Clustering - 4 Lectures
    • Representative-based
    • Density-based
    • Hierarchical and Subspace
    • Outlier Detection
  2. Graph Mining - 5 Lectures
    • Spectral Theory and Clustering
    • Community Detection
    • Link Analysis
    • Similarities and Graph Embeddings
    • Graph Convolutional Networks
  3. Pattern Mining - 3 Lectures
    • Frequent Subgraph Mining
    • Frequent Items and Association Rules
    • Sequence Mining
    • Similarities and Stream Mining

Three hand-ins (âš ï¸Graded 10% each) for each topic.

Oral exam 70%

  • A number of topics covering the 3 modules
  • 20 min in total
    • 10 min presentation
    • 8 min questions
    • 2 min grading

Introduction to Data Mining

Why data mining?

Data explosion problem. Desideratum: Useful knowledge!

Solution: Data mining and data warehousing, i.e., extraction of interesting knowledge from data in large databases.

Definition of Data Mining

  • Given lots of data
  • Discover patterns and models that are:
    • Valid: hold on new data with some certainty
    • Useful: should be possible to act on the item
    • Unexpected: non-obvious to the system
    • Understandable: humans should be able to interpret the pattern

Whatâ€™s not data mining?

  • deductive query processing
  • expert system or small ML/statistical programs

To extract the knowledge data needs to be:

  1. stored - systems
  2. managed - databases and data management
  3. analyzed - this class

âœ… Data Mining â‰ˆ Big Data â‰ˆ Predictive Analytics â‰ˆ Data Science

Applications

Database Analysis and Decision Support

Market analysis and management

Risk analysis and management

Fraud detection and management

Other Applications

Text mining and web analysis

Intelligent query answering

The KDD (knowledge discovery in databases) process:

  1. Data cleaning/integration in databases/info repositories
  2. Selections/projections/transformations in data warehouse
  3. task relevant data fed into data mining methods, gains patterns
  4. Pattens after visualization and evaluation, gains knowledge.

Basic Data Mining Tasks

Clustering

Association Rules (Frequent Pattern Mining)

Outlier Detection

Other methods

  • Concept Characterization and Discrimination
  • Sequential Patterns
  • Trends and Analysis of Changes
  • Methods for special data types e.g. Spatial data mining, web mining

Clustering

â—Class labels are unknown.

Task: Group objects into sub-groups (clusters)

  • Similarity function to measure similarity between objects (distance)
  • Objective: maximize intra-class similarity and minimize interclass similarity

Applications

  • Customer profiling/segmentation
  • Document or image collections
  • Web access patterns

Compare: Classification

â— Class labels are known.

  • Task is to distinguish classes
  • predict class membership for new objects

Supervised vs Unsupervised

Supervised: classification - known labels

Unsupervised: clustering - unknown label

Outlier Detection

What is outlier?

An object that deviates so much from the rest of the data set as to arouse suspicion that it was generated by a different mechanism.

Application

  • Credit card fraud detection
  • Telecom fraud detection
  • Customer segmentation
  • Medical analysis

(Mostly unsupervised, but can also be supervised or semi-supervised)

Graph Mining

Graph: Structure that models connections between data objects

Data mining on graphs finds additional types of patterns

Association Rules

Association rule mining: find frequent patterns, associations, correlations, or causal structures among sets of items in transactions or other information repositories.

æŸ¥æ‰¾äº¤æ˜“æˆ–å…¶ä»–ä¿¡æ¯å­˜å‚¨åº“ä¸­çš„é¡¹ç›®é›†ä¹‹é—´çš„é¢‘ç¹æ¨¡å¼ã€å…³è”ã€ç›¸å…³æ€§æˆ–å› æœç»“æ„ã€‚

  • Rule form: Body â†’ Head

  • Applications: market-basket analysis, cross-marketing, catalog design

  • Transaction database

  • Associations:

    buys(butter) â†’ buys(milk), buys(butter) â†’ buys(sugar)

Data exploration: explore data attributes individually or extract key characteristics of a data sample

Large part of data mining is data pre-processing ğŸ˜”

Bonferroniâ€™s principle: Roughly, if you look in more places for interesting patterns than your amount of data will support, you are bound to find crap

ç²—ç•¥åœ°è¯´ï¼Œå¦‚æœåœ¨æ›´å¤šåœ°æ–¹å¯»æ‰¾æœ‰è¶£çš„æ¨¡å¼ï¼Œä½†è¶…å‡ºäº†æ•°æ®é‡æ‰€èƒ½æ”¯æŒçš„èŒƒå›´ï¼Œé‚£ä¸€å®šä¼šå‘ç°åƒåœ¾ã€‚

Thousand of patterns: not all of them are interesting ğŸ˜”

A pattern is interesting if it is easily understood by humans, valid on test data, potentially useful, novel or validates some hypothesis that a user seeks to confirm

Objective vs. subjective interestingness measures

  • Objective: based on statistics and structures of patterns, e.g., support, confidence etc.
  • Subjective: based on usersâ€™ belief in the data, e.g., unexpectedness, novelty, action-ability etc.

Statistic for Exploratory Data Analysis

entry.summary: Brief Introduction to

entry.title: éšæœºç®—æ³• 1 Examples of Randomized Algorithm
entry.content:
Course Info

3 Project - 30% (A group of 3 people)

Oral Exam - 70%

Prof. Ioannis Caragiannis and Prof. Kasper Green Larsen

Randomization

Randomization algorithms use random coins, dice, card shuffling etc.

Assumptions

Fair coins Prâ¡[HEADS]=Prâ¡[TAILS]=1@\Pr[HEADS]=\Pr[TAILS]=\frac{1}{@}Pr[HEADS]=Pr[TAILS]=@1â€‹

More complicated operations

  • Random selection among a finite set of items
  • Access to a random permutation of elements
  • Selection of a random point in the interval [0,1][0,1][0,1]
  • Selection from a finite or infinite set according to a non-uniform probability distribution

We donâ€™t care about implementation issues in this courseâ—

Main Characteristics

Deterministic algorithms: same step in any execution on the same input.

Randomized algorithms

  • different outputs in different executions
  • running time may not always the same

Why randomization

  1. Simple
  2. Well on average or with high probability
  3. Insights to the design of better deterministic algorithms derandomization

Examples of Randomized Algorithm

Content resolution

2-nodes communication, collision happens when both send message at the same time.

Protocol make sure message will be sent correctly

If use fixed waiting time. the collision will happen again and again.

Solution: use a random period of time.

Max Cut

Given a graph, partition the node into 2 disjoint set, trying to maximize on-cut edges between nodes at different subsets.

Max Cut: NP-Complete

Polynomial approximation

examine the nodes in an arbitrary order

for each node, decide its side in the bipartition greedily

Much simpler algorithm

for each node, decide its side in the bipartition randomly

  • Each edge is in the cut with probability 121\over221â€‹
  • On average, half of the edges will be in the cut

E[C]=E[âˆ‘eâˆˆEXe]=âˆ‘Prâ¡[Xe=1]=âˆ£Eâˆ£2â‰¥OPT2\mathbb E[C]=\mathbb E[\sum_{e\in E}X_e]=\sum\Pr[X_e=1]=\frac{|E|}{2}\ge\frac{OPT}{2}E[C]=E[eâˆˆEâˆ‘â€‹Xeâ€‹]=âˆ‘Pr[Xeâ€‹=1]=2âˆ£Eâˆ£â€‹â‰¥2OPTâ€‹

half-optimal on average, with high probability

second best known approximation

Best known approximation: semidefinite programming 0.878

Quicksort

Main idea

Recursively call a fast subroutine for partial sorting

  1. select a pivot element
  2. reorganize around the pivot

subroutine takes O(n)O(n)O(n) steps

pivot element is in the final position

sorting is reduced to two smaller sorting problem

Whatâ€™s the problem

If the input is inversed, picking the first (also largest) as pivot, it will need Î˜(n2)\Theta(n^2)Î˜(n2) time.

How to improve

Selecting better pivot!

Make median-number pivot?

T(n)=2â‹…T(n2)+Tpartition(n)+Tmedian(n)Tpartition(n)=O(n)T(n)=2\cdot T(\frac{n}{2})+T_{partition}(n)+T_{median}(n)\\T_{partition}(n)=O(n)T(n)=2â‹…T(2nâ€‹)+Tpartitionâ€‹(n)+Tmedianâ€‹(n)Tpartitionâ€‹(n)=O(n)

There exists linear-time algorithm for median, thus

T(n)=2â‹…T(n2)+O(n)â‡’T(n)=O(nlogâ¡n)T(n)=2\cdot T(\frac{n}{2})+O(n)\\\Rightarrow T(n)=O(n\log n)T(n)=2â‹…T(2nâ€‹)+O(n)â‡’T(n)=O(nlogn)

How good is Quicksort so far

Best possible running time

low space

but complicated

Randomized Quicksort

Randomly choose pivot

On average, random pivot gives 25% - 75% split

T(n)=T(3n/4)+T(n/4)+O(n)â‡’T(n)=O(nlogâ¡n)T(n)=T(3n/4)+T(n/4)+O(n)\\\Rightarrow T(n)=O(n\log n)T(n)=T(3n/4)+T(n/4)+O(n)â‡’T(n)=O(nlogn)

Analysis of Random Quicksort

Expected number of comparisons in the calls of partition

Typically, the uniform selection of a pivot among nnn elements can be implemented with O(logâ¡n)O(\log n)O(logn) coin tosses, on average

So the time for selecting pivots is at most O(nlogâ¡n)O(n\log n)O(nlogn)

Notation

ziz_iziâ€‹ denotes iii-th smallest element

i<j,Xiji<j,X_{ij}i<j,Xijâ€‹ as the r.v. denoting the number of times the element ziz_iziâ€‹ and zjz_jzjâ€‹ get compared by Quicksort

XijX_{ij}Xijâ€‹ is 1 if ziz_iziâ€‹ and zjz_jzjâ€‹ both belong to the same subarray when some of them is selected as pivot, otherwise it is 0.

Then the # of comparisons in the calls of partition is

C=âˆ‘i=1nâˆ’1âˆ‘j=i+1nXijC=\sum_{i=1}^{n-1}\sum_{j=i+1}^nX_{ij}C=i=1âˆ‘nâˆ’1â€‹j=i+1âˆ‘nâ€‹Xijâ€‹

No good sorting algorithm should perform the same comparison twice.

Bounding the expectation of CCC

E[C]=E[âˆ‘i=1nâˆ’1âˆ‘j=i+1nXij]=âˆ‘i=1nâˆ’1âˆ‘j=i+1nE[Xij]=âˆ‘i=1nâˆ’1âˆ‘j=i+1nPrâ¡[Xij=1]\mathbb E[C]=\mathbb E[\sum_{i=1}^{n-1}\sum_{j=i+1}^nX_{ij}]=\sum_{i=1}^{n-1}\sum_{j=i+1}^n\mathbb E[X_{ij}]=\sum_{i=1}^{n-1}\sum_{j=i+1}^n\Pr[X_{ij}=1]E[C]=E[i=1âˆ‘nâˆ’1â€‹j=i+1âˆ‘nâ€‹Xijâ€‹]=i=1âˆ‘nâˆ’1â€‹j=i+1âˆ‘nâ€‹E[Xijâ€‹]=i=1âˆ‘nâˆ’1â€‹j=i+1âˆ‘nâ€‹Pr[Xijâ€‹=1]

What is Prâ¡[Xij=1]\Pr[X_{ij}=1]Pr[Xijâ€‹=1]?

  • Prâ¡[X1n=1]=2n\Pr[X_{1n}=1]=\frac{2}{n}Pr[X1nâ€‹=1]=n2â€‹

    1. z1z_1z1â€‹ selected as pivot. Prâ¡=1n\Pr=\frac{1}{n}Pr=n1â€‹
    2. znz_nznâ€‹ selected as pivot. Prâ¡=1n\Pr=\frac{1}{n}Pr=n1â€‹
    3. neither selected, they will put into different subarrays, will never be compared.

  • Prâ¡[Xij=1]=2jâˆ’i+1\Pr[X_{ij}=1]=\frac{2}{j-i+1}Pr[Xijâ€‹=1]=jâˆ’i+12â€‹

Thus

E[C]=âˆ‘i=1nâˆ’1âˆ‘j=i+1n2jâˆ’i+1=âˆ‘i=1nâˆ’1âˆ‘k=2nâˆ’i+12kâ‰¤2âˆ‘i=1nâˆ’1Hnâ‰¤2nHn\mathbb E[C]=\sum_{i=1}^{n-1}\sum_{j=i+1}^n\frac{2}{j-i+1}=\sum_{i=1}^{n-1}\sum_{k=2}^{n-i+1}\frac{2}{k}\le2\sum_{i=1}^{n-1}H_n\le2nH_nE[C]=i=1âˆ‘nâˆ’1â€‹j=i+1âˆ‘nâ€‹jâˆ’i+12â€‹=i=1âˆ‘nâˆ’1â€‹k=2âˆ‘nâˆ’i+1â€‹k2â€‹â‰¤2i=1âˆ‘nâˆ’1â€‹Hnâ€‹â‰¤2nHnâ€‹

i.e., E[C]=O(nlogâ¡n)\mathbb E[C]=O(n\log n)E[C]=O(nlogn) (HnH_nHnâ€‹ is harmonic number lnâ¡(n+1)â‰¤Hnâ‰¤1+lnâ¡n\ln(n+1)\le H_n\le1+\ln nln(n+1)â‰¤Hnâ€‹â‰¤1+lnn)

Reference Literature

Lecture notes by Nick Harvey from UBC

What are randomized algorithms?

âŒ average-case analysis

âœ… worst-case analysis

May either run for long time, or output wrong answer. Possible to make these cases very tiny likelihood.

Why RA?

Compared with deterministic algorithm, RA are often:

  • simpler
  • more efficient (in space or time)
  • in many scenarios: provably better
  • in many scenarios: RA can do something DA canâ€™t do.
  • ideas lead to DA design.

Example: Max Cut

Want to find an polynomial-time algorithm for which âˆ£Î´(G)âˆ£â‰¥Î±OPT|\delta(G)|\ge\alpha OPTâˆ£Î´(G)âˆ£â‰¥Î±OPT.

If we use random algorithm, randomly split the vertices into 2 sides, then E[âˆ£Î´(Gâˆ£]â‰¥12OPT\mathbb E[|\delta(G|]\ge\frac{1}{2}OPTE[âˆ£Î´(Gâˆ£]â‰¥21â€‹OPT.

Lecture notes by Manuel Blum from CMU

Probabilistic Analysis and Randomized Quicksort

Basic-Quicksort: if every round the pivot choose unfortunately the maximum, the running time is Î˜(n2)\Theta(n^2)Î˜(n2).

Randomized-Quicksort: The worst-case expected-time bound is O(nlogâ¡n)O(n\log n)O(nlogn) by randomly choose the pivot.

Theorem: The expected number of comparisons made by randomized quicksort on an array of size nnn is at most 2nlnâ¡n2n\ln n2nlnn.
